item.title: SMC Did Not Recommend BOTOX (Migraine) for Reimbursement
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: In April, the Scottish Medicines Consortium (SMC) did not recommend the drug for the prophylaxis of headaches in adults with chronic migraine.
The supporting evidence came from two Phase III studies: PREEMPT 1 and 2.
The SMC considered that pooled analysis of the two pivotal studies showed that Botox significantly reduced the frequency of headache days in comparison to placebo.
The cost-utility analysis submitted by the company estimated the base-case incremental cost per QALY to be GBP12,176, based on an incremental cost of GBP1,012 and a QALY gain of 0.08.
However, the sensitivity analyses showed that the results were sensitive to the assumed transitional probabilities, changes in utility values, the time horizon, the stopping criteria and cost of Botox, and its administration.
Given the uncertainties, the economic case was not considered to be demonstrated.
Source: Global Insight

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Highlights from Anti-aging Medicine World Congress (AMWC) – Focus on Competitors
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Allergan had a strong presence with an all day Master Class Sympo, a Come Meet the Experts area on its booth, and an Expert Meeting in Cannes. Merz presented its new free online platform, celebrated the 10 years of Radiesse(R), and dedicated its two-hour sympo to “Real world meets ideal world”. Medy-Tox celebrated with champagne the completion of its second plant (for the EU market), and Hugel promoted Dermalax™, its new CE certified HA filler. More details are provided below.
Launched in Paris in 2003 and taking place annually in Monaco since 2005, the Anti-aging Medicine World Congress (AMWC) has over the last 10 years become the largest world congress in this area. Over 7500 participants from >120 countries WW were expected.
This year, the congress has honored Russian Federation. The 1st AMWC EEU will take place in Moscow (June 14-15, 2013).
Booth
Sympo
- The satellite symposium entitled “The Power of V4 in facial rejuvenation: a new “whole face” approach” was relayed live on Allegan’s booth. It was centered on anatomy of the face and linked with techniques of injection for toxin and fillers, and organized in 3 sessions:
The “perioral area”, the “midface area” and the “periorbital” sessions were organized in the same way: first part dedicated to an Allergan product, the second to anatomy, physiology and the effect of aging, and the third to a live demonstration.
- At the end of the congress Allergan sponsored its first Expert Meeting of 2013 in Cannes. The objectives of this meeting were to provide with knowledge on how to educate and train others on the strategies used to treat the perioral, midface and periorbital areas, first individually and then as part of the whole face approach, and guidance on how to deliver high-quality and engaging presentations.
Poster
Key posters which show studies conducted by very well-known KOLs from US and Canada:
A Multi-center Randomized, Placebo-controlled Study to Evaluate the Efficacy and Safety of repeat with onabotulinumtoxinA Jean Carruthers The conclusions indicate that repeated onabotulinumtoxinA of CFL alone or concurrently with GL are associated with significantly reduced CFL severity as well as significantly higher subject satisfaction and additional patient-reported outcomes. The safety profile was consistent with the approved GL indication.
()
Safety and Efficacy Study of Botulinum Toxin Type A for the Dr Nowell Solish
Study design: http://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT01391299?term=NCT01391299&rank=1
()
On the Booth
Sympo
The fully attended symposium titled “Real world meets ideal world — from single syringe to multiple injectables” was chaired by Prof N. Zerbani (Italy) and co-chaired by Dr T. Pavicic (Germany).
The objectives were to provide insights into how best to inject Radiesse, and the considerations to take into account when shaping the face with Bocouture, Glytone and Radiesse.
Dr K. Goldie (UK), Dr M. Imhof (Germany), and Dr M. Landau (Israel) shared their best injection practice of Radiesse. Dr J. van Loghem (Netherlands) demonstrated how to combine the 3 products for a full face approach.
The free online platform (www.merzaesthetics.eu/expertsarea) presented in the Expert’s area of the booth, is an interactive tool (such as treatment test, a personalized library) and contains videos and pictures for physicians. A Doc Check account is necessary to access it.
Hugel Pharma Presence
Booth
Dermalax Technology
  • Crosslinked HA soft tissue filler
  • Duration: >12 months
  • The company indicated that 'Dermalax Deep' already is CE ceritifed, and that others will be around Q3:13.
With many thanks to the Aesthetic Franchise for their reading and additional comments and feedback.

item.title: Roche & ISIS Enter Huntington's Disease Drug Development Deal Valued At > $390m
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Roche & ISIS Pharmaceuticals announced a deal late yesterday to develop a treatment for Huntington's disease combining ISIS's antisense technology with Roche's brain shuttle programme. The latter facilitates the penetration of drugs into the brain.
Deal Terms
Roche has agreed to make a $30m upfront payment securing the option to license the developed drugs through the completion of the first phase I trial. Isis will be eligible to receive up to $362m in milestone payments as well as tiered royalties on sales.
Initial Focus Of The Collaboration
Isis's drug candidates ISIS-388241, ISIS-387898 and ISIS-408737 that block all forms of the huntingtin protein will form part of the initial focus of the collaboration. If Roche exercises its option, it will assume responsibiliity for all global development regulatory and commercialisation activitities. Meanwhile, ISIS will be responsible for the discovery and development of candidates prior to Roche exercising its option.
Preclinical Data On The ISIS Drugs
In October 2012, preclinical data were presented at the 42nd Annual SFN Meeting in New Orleans, LA. In primary paired cortical neurons from YAC18 and BACHD mice, the lead ASO showed mutant huntingtin protein (HTT) knockdown from 39 to 68% and negligible wild-type HTT knockdown. In the humanized cell line, Hu97/18, without induction of CNS toxicity, intracerebroventricular injection of the lead ASOs exhibited 70 to 85% mutant HTT knockdown and 0 to 24% wild-type HTT knockdown.
Commenting on its preclinical data Frank Bennett Senior VP of Research noted:-
"Over the past several years, we've been working closely with Dr. Don Cleveland at the Ludwig Institute at UCSD and the CHDI Foundation to develop antisense drugs that have demonstrated activity in animal models of the disease. In these studies, we've been able to demonstrate that inhibiting production of both forms of the huntingtin protein reverses Huntington's disease-like signs in these models."

"This work, which was published in Neuron last year, is encouraging and suggests that simultaneously inhibiting or reducing both the normal and the abnormal huntingtin protein could halt disease progression without any deleterious effects. We believe that this approach could be therapeutically beneficial for all patients with Huntington's disease."

"In parallel, in conjunction with Dr. David Corey of the University of Texas Southwest (sic) [Southwestern] (09:46) Medical School and other collaborators, we have developed antisense drugs that selectively inhibit the production of only the abnormal huntingtin protein, leaving the normal form of the protein alone. This personalized approach would target subsets of Huntington's patients based upon the sequence of their huntingtin gene and could be used to develop a suite of antisense drugs each unique to particular huntingtin gene sequence."

"While this approach would require us to develop and test several drugs, it offers the best opportunity to selectively reduce abnormal huntingtin protein in the patient without affecting levels of the normal huntingtin protein."

Other Companies With An Antisense/siRNA Therapeutic Approach
Amongst the raft of other companies focused on the development of drug's for Huntington's Disease those targeting suprrsion of the Huntington protein with either an antisense or siRNA therapeutic approaches include Alnylam.. Benitiec, Sangamo, and Lundbeck. All candidates are currently in preclinical development.
Commenting on the differences between the two approaches Stanley Cooke Chairman & CEO of ISIS stated
"Of course, the mechanisms are similar in that you're using oligonucleotides to target an RNA and cause its degradation. Beyond that, though, there are very meaningful differences. siRNA – traditional siRNA, other than the single-strand siRNA that we created, uses double-stranded RNA molecules. And as a consequence of the physical chemical properties of those molecules, the challenges of delivery of siRNA are still substantial and require either lipid formulations o r for the liver at least, GalNAc.".

"Looking in the brain, the distribution of single-strand antisense drugs that we're using in this program is much broader. And as a consequence, we see much greater efficacy and breadth of utility in the central nervous system than I think has been seen with siRNA."

Current Status Of The Progamme

The program is apparently still in the discovery phase – late-discovery phase. So, the next step is to select the first development candidate and then moving into toxicology. When the lead candidate does enter phI which is still some time away it is likely to be tested in patients not in human volunteers because of the intrathecal nature of the administration.

Clinical development will begin, as is typical, in patients with significant disease. As more is known about whether the drug is bringing benefit and what the side effects are, ISIS is confident that over time the drugs will be used earlier and earlier in the disease.

Source: www.isis.com

item.title: re: Recent published results about two innovative pharmaceutical forms of leuprorelin
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Very interesting paper which shows that a 5mg dose of leuprorelin could be sufficient to cover a 3 month release in achievieng testosterone suppression . For the ones which were part of the "microimplant" IPSEN project of Barcelona some years ago , similar results were obtained in phase 1. In a nutsheel , if the SR formulation is able to limit / suppress the initial release of LHRH analog (called "burst") , then it looks possible to reduce the amount of API in the formulation .... 
Interesting data to support the difference in API concentration between the implant and microsphere leuprolide formulations.
In Greece the leuprolide implant product is under the brand name Prostaplant and is marketed by local company Lavipharm. it was launched Dec 2011 and end of 2012
reached a 3.2% MS in volumes.

item.title: Paper Clarifies Biological Activity of Daewoong's BoNT-A
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The paper shows that the characteristics of Botox(R) and DWP450 are almost the same. The effectiveness was evaluated in terms of the compound muscle action potential (CMAP) and conduction velocity after injection. Authors conclude that DWP450 used in this electrophysiological study had similar effect compared with Botox(R), and propose that a split-body electrophysiological protocol will be useful in establishing the comparative effectiveness of new BTX products.
Of note, the research received no specific grant from any funding.

item.title: Highlights from Anti-aging Medicine World Congress (AMWC) – Focus on Botulinum Toxin
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: This report provides key messages from the four-hour session on botulinum toxin, such as the results from a small pilot study using the micro droplet technique for crow’s feet using (incobotulinumtoxinA), the outcomes of a Swiss study on the QoL before and after treatment of focal hyperhidrosis, and the safety of toxin and HA in the same syringe presented by A Pickett. In order to get the best of muscular balance, many speakers did emphasize the importance of a good knowledge in anatomy and physiology as well as injection technique. Of note the Myoscience’s Focused Cold Therapy, once again presented as an alternative treatment to neurotoxin, expected to reach the EU market this year.
Launched in Paris in 2003 and taking place annually in Monaco since 2005, the Anti-aging Medicine World Congress (AMWC) has over the last 10 years become the largest world congress in this area. Over 7500 participants from >120 countries WW were expected.
This year, the congress has honored Russian Federation. The 1st AMWC EEU will take place in Moscow (June 14-15, 2013).
Comment: Micro droplet technique with BoNT-A is a common treatment option in skin rejuvenation. Nevertheless scientific data are rare.
presented selected results from a small pilot study titled “Micro droplet Technique with incobotulinumtoxinA for the treatment of crow’s feet” (submitted). Study design:
  • Recruitment: 4 women aged 18-85 years with moderate to severe LCL (CF) at maximum expression (Merz’ scale severity score 3 to 4) and in a stable medical condition.
  • Objective: to investigate the efficacy and safety of the addition of the micro droplet technique to conventional injections for the treatment of CF with botulinum toxin type A, free from complexing proteins (incobotulinumtoxinA).
  • Time of investigation: Day 0 (visit 1); week 4 (visit 2); week 12 (visit 3).
  • Subject assessment and investigator assessment (see below) were evaluated.
His conclusion is that the addition of the micro droplet technique to standard practice for injecting incobotulinumtoxinA is a promising procedure for the treatment of CF in women with moderate to severe wrinkles, and that the technique is well tolerated and safe.
He added that although this is a limited set of data, it provides insights into the potential for this technique and should serve as a stimulus for larger studies to evaluate the benefits of the microdroplet technique for CF as well as rhytides in other facial areas.
concluded her presentation outlining that botulinum toxin probably works for very fine lines, whereas for severe peri-oral wrinkles combination therapy is required.
presented the challenge of BoNT in the lower face such as the difficulty to identify the specific muscles (more subcutaneous tissue in the lower face, thicker dermis, proximity between antagonistic muscles) that can lead to injection in the wrong muscle.
He highlighted considerable risk of side effects. He also warned on the importance of the patient selection and suggested a combination of filler, surgery and BoNT-A for the best clinical results.
presented selected results from a Swiss cross selectional longitudinal study on the life quality before and after treatment of focal hyperhidrosis. Key slides are presented below:
Dilution: Because injection of the toxin is painful, he suggested the reconstitution of the toxin with preserved saline (“Pain difference associated with injection of abobotulinumtoxinA reconstituted with preserved saline and preservative-free saline: a prospective, randomized, side-by-side, double-blind study”. Allen SB; Goldberg NA — Dermatol Surg 2012).
presented:
- the results of a small pilot study in 5 patients, treated for CG +/- glabella with Perlane and Dysport in the same syringe. After 8 weeks of observation, subjects reported they were all pleased with their results. (Hyaluronic Acide Filler and Botulinum Neurotoxin Delivered Simultaneously in the Same Syringe for Effective and Convenient Combination Aesthetic Rejuvenation Therapy - J Drugs Dermatol. 2010 Sep;9(9):1135-8.).
- the “pretty good” results obtained for “scratched faces” in 25 patients treated with 3 different BoNT, 3 different HA and different injection techniques, with a follow-up from 3 to 18 months (B. Môle - Treatment of Dynamic Facial Wrinkles Through the Simultaneous Combined Use of Botulinum Toxin A and Hyaluronic Acid - Ann Chir Plast Esthet. 2012 Jun;57(3):194-201. doi: 10.1016/j.anplas.2012.02.001. Epub 2012 Mar 7.).
When it comes to the safety, A. Pickett concluded that those are preliminary studies only, and that great care is needed in BoNT dosage. Also, HA properties are highly specific and adjusted to use, and that dilution may not give desired results. In conclusion, he highlighted that more work is needed in controlled trials.
With many thanks to the Aesthetic Franchise for their reading and additional comments and feedback.

item.title: Bavarian Nordic Takes Steps to Try & Shorten The Development Time Of Prostvac
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Bavarian Nordic has reported on an agreed and updated statistical analysis plan with the FDA for its on-going PROSPECT PhIII trial of Prostvac in CRPC patients with metastatic disease, The trial now includes a pre-specified interim analysis of the data to evaluate whether the trial should be stopped early for efficacy reasons. In the event of the latter a BLA could be filed earlier than anticipated.
There have been some issues with enrollment into the PROSPECT trial which is currently ongoing at almost 100 sites in 10 countries. The new President of Bavarian Nordics Immunotherapeutics has recently taken steps to try and enhance recruitment. Specifially efforst are now being directed towards high performing centres. These new measures are aimed at completing enrolment within the next year.
Source: www.bavarian.nordic.com

In 2012, Ambrx had similar agreement with BMS and Merck KGaA
Upfront payment: Ambrx will receive $15M as well as >$285M in potential near and long term research, development, regulatory and sales based milestones for an undisclosed number of targets for ADCs in oncology.
Territory: Astellas will receive worldwide rights to develop and commercialize ADCs for oncology.

item.title: re: Recent published results about two innovative pharmaceutical forms of leuprorelin
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Recent published results about two innovative pharmaceutical forms of leuprorelin 
Comment : Two innovative pharmaceutical forms of leuprorelin acetate have been developed as 1-month and 3-month implants for the treatment of advanced hormone-dependent prostate cancer. Results of clinical studies have been described in two recent publications.  ...
Very interesting paper which shows that a 5mg dose of leuprorelin could be sufficient to cover a 3 month release in achievieng testosterone suppression . For the ones which were part of the "microimplant" IPSEN project of Barcelona some years ago , similar results were obtained in phase 1. In a nutsheel , if the SR formulation is able to limit / suppress the initial release of LHRH analog (called "burst") , then it looks possible to reduce the amount of API in the formulation ....
Interesting data to support the difference in API concentration between the implant and microsphere leuprolide formulations.
In Greece the leuprolide implant product is under the brand name Prostaplant and is marketed by local company Lavipharm. it was launched Dec 2011 and end of 2012
reached a 3.2% MS in volumes.

item.title: Recent published results about two innovative pharmaceutical forms of leuprorelin
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment : Two innovative pharmaceutical forms of leuprorelin acetate have been developed as 1-month and 3-month implants for the treatment of advanced hormone-dependent prostate cancer. Results of clinical studies have been described in two recent publications.
Implants have been probably formulated by Hexal company. Hexal is a part of the Sandoz division of Novartis. It is specialized in biosimilar products and in subcutaneous formulation. In 2007 Hexal brought on the German market the first Leuprorelin depot for the treatment of advanced hormone-dependant prostate cancer.
The first paper is a large post marketing surveillance study. It assessed 818 patients with advanced hormone-dependent prostate cancer who were treated with three injections of either the 1-month or 3-month implant.
Compared with baseline, a significant decrease in both testosterone and PSA levels were measured after the first and second injections of leuprorelin implant. These results were confirmed for both the 1-month and 3-month implants in separate analyses. Switching, without treatment interruption, from Trenantone® (Takeda Pharma GmBH, Aachen, Germany) to the leuprorelin implant resulted in a significant decrease in the mean serum testosterone concentrations (P < 0.05) and a nonsignificant increase in the proportion of patients reaching castrate testosterone levels, while the number of patients with PSA values ≤4 ng/mL significantly increased (P = 0.045).
In the second paper, two therapeutic studies of the 1-month implant were performed: a randomized, controlled study comparing the leuprorelin implant with leuprorelin prolonged-release microspheres (Enantone) as the active control; and a single-arm study of the leuprorelin implant. For the 3-month implant, four therapeutic studies were performed: a randomized, controlled study comparing the leuprorelin implant with leuprorelin prolonged-release microspheres (Trenantone) as the active control; a single-arm study of the leuprorelin implant; and two long-term studies with the 3-month implant administered twice, either 12 or 16 weeks apart.
In the comparator-controlled studies, both implants were as effective as the microspheres for achieving successful testosterone suppression and normalization of prostate-specific antigen (PSA) levels.
Leuprorelin from the 3-month implant has an approximately fourfold higher bioavailability than in the prolonged-release microspheres; this explains why the 3-month implant formulation is at least as effective in achieving successful testosterone suppression despite containing less than half the amount of active substance.
Studies were funded by Sandoz International GmbH.
Second paper coauthors are employees of Hexal AG.
Source : http://link.springer.com/article/10.1007%2Fs12325-013-0010-y
and http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3547534/pdf/10.1177_1756287212471096.pdf

Comments
Very interesting paper which shows that a 5mg dose of leuprorelin could be sufficient to cover a 3 month release in achievieng testosterone suppression . For the ones which were part of the "microimplant" IPSEN project of Barcelona some years ago , similar results were obtained in phase 1. In a nutsheel , if the SR formulation is able to limit / suppress the initial release of LHRH analog (called "burst") , then it looks possible to reduce the amount of API in the formulation ....
Interesting data to support the difference in API concentration between the implant and microsphere leuprolide formulations.
In Greece the leuprolide implant product is under the brand name Prostaplant and is marketed by local company Lavipharm. it was launched Dec 2011 and end of 2012
reached a 3.2% MS in volumes.

item.title: Has NanoMedicine Reached An Inflection Point?
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment This is the question raised by two major collaborations struck within the first 14 weeks of the year, one with Amgen and the other with Pfizer. Both deals signed with a private company Bind Therapeutics cover the development of so called "Accurins". small molecule extended release formulations.
Deal Terms
The Amgen partnership covering an undisclosed proprietary kinase inhibitor involved a $46.5m upfront payment and development milestones of $134m
The Pfizer partnership, by contrast, covering multiple undisclosed molecules was secured with a $50m upfront and milestones of $160m
The Technology Platform
Bind's technology is based around surrounding active ingredients with a capsule that contains targeting ligands and a resorbably shell that can disintegrate on a site-or disease -specific basis. A surface layer of polyethylene glycol attracts water and makes the drug appear to immune cells as a water droplet and thus evades the body's resistance mechanisms.
The Accurins can incorporate a broad range of therapeutic payloads including small moleucules, peptides, proteins and nucleic acids such as siRNA and mRNA.
Bind's own drug candidate BIND-014 is an Accurin that delivers docetaxel through targeting prostate-specific membrane antigen (PSMA). BIND is presenting phI data with this product at the AACR meeting next week and has just started phII development.
Company Background
Bind Therapeutics, based in Cambridge Masachusetts and a MIT spin-out, has raised more than $70m through venture financing since it was founded in 2007 including a $35m series D financing in 2011. Backers include Polaris Venture Partners and ARCH Venture Partners.

item.title: Mutlinationals Turn Their Focus To Acquiring In Brazil
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Three large multinationals are reportedly in a race to acquired the Brazilian company Ache Laboratories in a deal that could be worth over $5bn. All three companies are eager to growh their business in Latin America particularly in Brazil.
Ache which was established in 1966 posesses over 260 brands marketed in appox 605 dosage forms and covering 120 therapeutic classes. Prescription products constitute over 80% of Ache's sales making it the leading supplier of prescription medicines in the country. the group has over 3,300 employees including a sales force of over 1,800 professionals and a presence in various other Latin Amercian countries outside Brazil including Mexico, Colombia & Venezuela.
Source: Pharma-E-Track

item.title: New Medullary Thyroid Cancer Agent Moves Into PhII Development
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: GlobeImmune has initiated a phII trial to evaluate its immunotherapy GI-6207 in patients with medullary thyroid cancer. The drug is being developed as part of a collaborative R&D agreement between the NCI and GlobeImmune.
Study Design
The phII cross-over trial will enroll a total of 34 patients. Patients will be treated with either GI-6207 for one year or be observed for six months and then treated with CI-6207 for one year. The primary endpoint for the study will be the effect of FI-6207 on changes in calcitonin leves after 6 months of treatment versus observation. Calcitonin is a tumour marker that correlates with tumour size in MTC.
Observation is the current standard of care for minimally symptomatic MTC with low tumour burden. However, in this setting GlobeImmune believes it will be able to evaluted GI-6207 induced immune responses and potentially correlate them with calcitonin levels in a short time-frame.
What Is GI-6207
The product consists of whole, heat-killed recombinant S.cerevisiae yeast genetically engineered to express a modified version of the human carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) protein as the target cancer antigen. CEA is over-expressed in multiple human epithelial cancers including MTC, where CEA is almost universally expressed and is a diagnostic marker of disease. Preclinical studies have shown that GI-6207 can induce an immune respnose to CEA as well as therapeutic anti-tumour responses. A previous phI study of monotherapy GI-6207 demonstrated preliminary safety and tolerability, enhanced immune responses and stable disease in 20% (5/25) of subjects beyond three months.

item.title: Zytiga's Authorisation & Reimbursement In Italy
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Thanks to Davide Pugliese (Product Manager Italy), we have learnt that on the 22nd March, Zytiga's authorisation and price agreement was published in the Official Gazette for the post-docetaxel setting. The ex-factory price negotiation is € 3850 (not including law discounts 5% +5%) for 1 month of therapy (120 tablet of 250 mg/tablet).
In addition there was a negotiation on additional discounts (not public). It 'also provided a system of payment by result and it was set an expenditure ceiling of € 33 million (for 12 months of sales), renewable on the same terms.
If the company wants to renegotiate the ceiling (33 Mio), the price will need to be renegotiated accordingly.
Note: the drug was considered a potential pharmacological innovation, but despite this, it’s under mandatory law discounts of 5% +5% (usually innovative medicines are excluded from these discounts).

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Auxilium To Advance The Development Of Xiaflex For Frozen Shoulder Syndrome
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Auxillium recently announced positive top-line data from a Xiaflex Frozen Shoulder Syndrome PhIIa study noting a statistical significant improvement in range of motion compared to exercise only. The drug will now progress into a placebo controlled study in the 2H2013.
What Is Frozen Shoulder Syndrome
FSS is a common, prolonged, painful condition of the shoulder in which increased capsular collagen thickening and subsequent capsular contraction in the shoulder joint is thought to cause a loss of range of motion in the shoulder. The condition is believed to affect approximately two to five percent of the general adult population and the full duration of the disease can last from approximately 1 year to up to 3.5 years.1 The majority of cases are currently managed conservatively with prolonged physical therapy and occasionally with steroid injections. It is estimated that approximately 300,000 cases of FSS are diagnosed annually and approximately 10% are treated with an invasive intervention (surgery or manipulation under anesthesia) on an annual basis.2
Study Design
The phase IIa study was an open-label, controlled dose-ranging study designed to assess the safety and efficacy of CCH for the treatment of Stage 2 unilateral idiopathic FSS in comparison to an exercise-only control group. The study involved 50 adult men and women at 11 sites throughout the U.S. Four cohorts of 10 patients each received up to three ultrasound-guided extraarticular injections of varying doses of CCH (ranging from 0.29 mg to 0.58 mg in three different volumes; 0.5, 1.0, or 2.0 mL), separated by a minimum of 21 days. All patients were instructed to perform home shoulder exercises. The fifth cohort of ten patients received no CCH injections and only performed home shoulder exercises. The study's primary endpoint was the change (in degrees) from baseline to the day 92 follow-up in active forward flexion in the affected shoulder compared to the exercise-only cohort. Safety assessments were made during all study visits and immunogenicity testing was performed at screening and day 92.
Key Study Findings
Both the 0.58mg(1mL) and 0.58mg(2mL) dosing arms showed positive, statistically significant improvement from baseline in forward flexion vs. the exercise-only group. The 0.58mg(1mL) dosing arm also showed statistically significant improvement from baseline in shoulder abduction vs. the exercise-only group. Positive trends with improvement in degrees were also seen in other active range of motion ("AROM") assessments vs. the exercise-only group. Twenty-nine study patients (72.5%) received three CCH injections with 5 subjects receiving two injections and 6 subjects receiving one injection only.
Commenting on the results Dr James Tursi Auxilium's CMO stated
"We are very pleased with study results demonstrating a dose response with CCH, significant improvement in multiple range of motion measurements and a well-tolerated safety profile in this phase IIa study. We look forward to advancing the clinical development of CCH in Frozen Shoulder syndrome and are currently assessing options to determine the safest and optimal path forward in development."
Source: auxillium.com

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Registration Trial of Bayer's Visanne(R) Has Started in China
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The Ph3 study, started this month, will evaluate efficacy and safety of dienogest 2 mg oral tablets in the treatment of endometriosis. PE will assess change of endometriosis associated pelvic pain (EAPP) measured by visual analog scale (VAS) from baseline to 24 weeks.
2 study phases: a double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled, parallel-group phase over 24 weeks, and an open-label extension phase with 2 mg DNG daily p.o. over 28 weeks for all subjects who completed the double-blind phase, irrespective of their treatment assignment in the first study phase.
Recruitment: 250 women
  • between 18 and 45 years of age, inclusive
  • with endometriosis confirmed by laparoscopy or laparotomy within five years but no later than 2 weeks before the Screening Visit
  • A score of at least 30 on a 100 mm visual analog scale (VAS) for endometriosis-associated pelvic pain at Screening Visit and Baseline Visit
  • Good general health (except for findings related to endometriosis, with or without infertility), as evidenced by medical history and complete physical and gynecological examination
  • Willingness to use a barrier method of contraception is required
Completion date: July 2014 - Feb 2015
Location: China (20 sites)

item.title: Cytokinetics Advances 2nd Neuromuscular Dysfunction Drug Into Clinic
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Cytokinetics has announced the initiation of a first-in-humans, Phase I clinical trial of CK-2127107 in healthy male volunteers. The drug is a novel small molecule activator of the fast skeletal muscle troponin complex, for the potential improvement of skeletal muscle function in diseases associated with neuromuscular dysfunction, muscular weakness, and/or muscle fatigue e.g. ALS.
Like tirasemtiv, the lead drug candidate from the company’s skeletal muscle activator program, CK-2127107 slows the rate of calcium release from the regulatory troponin complex of fast skeletal muscle fibers, which sensitizes the sarcomere to calcium.
CK-2127107 was discovered in connection with Cytokinetics’ optimization of a different chemical series than that which produced tirasemtiv, which is currently being evaluated in BENEFIT-ALS (Blinded Evaluation of Neuromuscular Effects and Functional Improvement with Tirasemtiv in ALS). BENEFIT-ALS is an international, double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled, Phase IIb clinical trial designed to evaluate the safety, tolerability and potential efficacy of tirasemtiv in patients with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS).
Advancing CK-2127107 to Phase I evaluation in healthy subjects is consistent with Cytokinetics’ corporate strategy to characterize a potential back-up compound to tirasemtiv in humans and to enable the evaluation of fast skeletal muscle troponin activation in a potentially broader set of clinical indications.
About Cytokinetics
Cytokinetics is a clinical-stage biopharmaceutical company focused on the discovery and development of novel small molecule therapeutics that modulate muscle function for Cytokinetics' lead drug candidate from its cardiac muscle contractility program, omecamtiv mecarbil, is in Phase II clinical development for the potential treatment of heart failure. Amgen Inc. holds an exclusive worldwide license (excluding Japan) to develop and commercialize omecamtiv mecarbil and related compounds. Cytokinetics is independently developing tirasemtiv and CK-2127107. Tirasemtiv is currently the subject of a Phase II clinical trials program and has been granted orphan drug designation and fast track status by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration and orphan medicinal product designation by the European Medicines Agency for the potential treatment of ALS.

item.title: Results of the Phase II Subcutaneous Pasireotide Extension Study in Acromegaly
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The full biochemichal control* at 6 months was met in 6 of the 26 evaluable patients (23%) .The authors concluded that the response rate observed in this extension study is similar to that seen in the core study after 3 months of pasireotide (27%) and is consistent with the results of earlier studies of somatostatin analogues.
The 30 patients were selected for their response to pasireotide (biochemichal or clinical) at any of the 3 doses tested (200, 400 or 600 microg bid ) in the core study. Dose adjustments were permitted up to 900 microg bid
The proportions of patients with control of GH alone or IGF1 alone were also recorded at 6 months : 13/26 (50%) achieved normal IGF1 and 12/26 GH<=2.5 microg/l.
*GH<=2.5 microg/l and IGF1 within age and sex matched limits.
Long-term efficacy and safety of subcutaneous pasireotide in acromegaly: results from an open-ended, multicenter, Phase II extension study. (NCT00171730)
Authors Petersenn S ET AL. Pituitary, 2013;():.Electronic publication http://dx.doi.org/10.1007/s11102-013-0478-0
Pasireotide has a broader somatostatin receptor binding profile than other somatostatin analogues. A 16-week, Phase II trial showed that pasireotide may be an effective treatment for acromegaly. An extension to this trial assessed the long-term efficacy and safety of pasireotide. This study was an open-label, single-arm, open-ended extension study (primary efficacy and safety evaluated at month 6). Patients could enter the extension if they achieved biochemical control (GH <= 2.5 microg/L and normal IGF-1) or showed clinically relevant improvements during the core study. Thirty of the 60 patients who received pasireotide (200-900 microg bid) in the core study entered the extension. At extension month 6, of the 26 evaluable patients, six were biochemically controlled, of whom five had achieved control during the core study. Normal IGF-1 was achieved by 13/26 patients and GH <= 2.5 microg/L by 12/26 at month 6. Nine patients received pasireotide for >=24 months in the extension; three who were biochemically controlled at month 24 had achieved control during the core study. Of 29 patients with MRI data, nine had significant (>=20 %) tumor volume reduction during the core study; an additional eight had significant reduction during the extension. The most common adverse events were transient gastrointestinal disturbances; hyperglycemia-related events occurred in 14 patients. Twenty patients had fasting plasma glucose shifted to a higher category during the extension. However, last available glucose measurements were normal for 17 patients. Pasireotide has the potential to be an effective, long-term medical treatment for acromegaly, providing sustained biochemical control and significant reductions in tumor volume
Pasireotide (SOM230) demonstrates efficacy and safety in patients with acromegaly: a randomized, multicenter, phase II trial. (NCT00088582
Petersenn S; Schopohl J; ET AL J Clin Endocrinol Metab, Jun 2010: vol. 95: no. 6: p. 2781-9) http://jcem.endojournals.org/content/95/6/2781.full.pdf

item.title: PROVENGE DTC Ads Are Stimulating Patient Interest
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Leerink & Swann published an investment note yesterday highlighting the positive impact Dendreon's DTC advertising is having on Google search on the drug with numbers at a two year high and surpassing the search record for Zytiga and Xtandi.
The analysts examined this data as an early indicator of the effectivenss of the campaign. Although the early trends are encouragin and suggest DTC is having the intended impact, it remains to be seen if this increased search volume will yield more patients requensting and ultiately receiving the drug, particularly as such a campaign is untested in the oncology market.
Dendreon has stated that its expected television budget is $5m per quarter.

item.title: Valeant Tops its Offer for the Acquisition of Obagi
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Valeant and Obagi have executed an amendment to their Agreement and Plan of Merger, dated March 29th as Valeant has come back with a higher bid. The new offer now is $24.00 per share in cash (vs $19.75, and $22.00 for Merz).
According to analysts,
- With its network of over 6,500 physicians, Obagi is valuable to any serious aesthetic company that is trying to establish a U.S. presence. From a Merz perspective, this physician network could strengthen the company's attempts to establish newly launched Xeomin as well as its dermal filler portfolio.
- To Valeant, Obagi's physician network may be a way to defend its recently acquired Medicis relationships.
Source: Cantor; Valeant

item.title: Aspireo Reports Results of Ph2a Study in Acromegaly Patients
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Analysis of the results shows that Somatoprim demonstrated a dose-dependent effect on lowering excess hGH on treatment-naïve patients with acromegaly.
NOTE
  • Screening of the publication did not provide any additional information on the results.
  • Aspireo's PR seems to be the unique source of information.
  • Data may be presented at the next ECE congress (end of April 2013 in Copenhagen).
- to assess safety, tolerability and efficacy of single ascending doses of Somatoprim in up to 20 treatment-naïve acromegaly patients.
No SAEs were reported, and the reported AEs were mild to moderate and of transient nature.
Please see Endocrinology7158: Aspireo Starts Ph2a Study with Somatoprim for Acromegaly.

item.title: Revance Therapeutics Secures Financing For PhIII BoNT-A Trials
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Revance has announced today that it has raised $33 million in a Series E financing and the conversion of $71 million in convertible debt into the Series E preferred stock. The financing included significant investment from new and old investors.
The proceeds of the financing will be used to support the recently announced Phase 3 trials for the topical delivery of the botulinum toxin type A RT-001 to reduce the severity of crow’s feet wrinkles (see Neurology6894: Revance Progress with its Topical Toxin for Moderate to Severe Crow's Feet Lines). Additionaly, it will be used to support the development of the injectable toxin RT002.
Venture Financing Scources
Revance’s investors include Essex Woodlands, NovaQuest Pharma Opportunities Fund, Delphi Ventures, Vivo Ventures, Technology Partners, Shepherd Ventures, Bio*One Capital and Pac-Link Ventures, Palo Alto Fund and other leading institutional investors.
Status of Other Development Programmes
RT001 is also currently in Phase 2 trials for the topical treatment of hyperhidrosis and chronic migraine headache.
RT002 is currently in Phase 1/2 trials.
Source: www.revance.com

item.title: Merck Co Inc Signs 200 Million Peptide Deal With Ra Pharma
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment Ra Pharmaceuticals today has entered into a collaboration with Merck, focused on the development of Cyclomimetics™, a new class of peptide-like compounds that have the diversity and specificity of antibodies whilst retaining many of the charactersitics of small molecules.
Under the agreement, Ra Pharmaceuticals will use its proprietary Extreme Diversity™ platform to develop Cyclomimetic candidates for protein targets in multiple therapeutic areas.
Deal Terms
Under the terms of the agreement, Ra Pharmaceuticals is eligible to receive up to $200 million in payments, including up-front and research funding, as well as upon the achievement of discovery, development, regulatory and commercialization milestones for multiple targets.
About Cyclomimetics™
Cyclomimetics™ are peptide-like molecules characterized by their cyclic structure and backbone and side-chain modifications that provide unique, beneficial properties not found in natural peptides. The result is a highly specific and stable molecule with improved cell permeability and the potential for greatly increased bioavailability.
Cyclomimetics are generated using the Company’s proprietary Extreme Diversity™ platform. The platform is unique in that it combines in vitro display technology, a completely defined translation system and a wide variety of non-natural amino acids. Unlike certain other display technologies, in vitro display does not require the use of a bacterial or yeast host, and it can produce libraries of 10 to 100 trillion members. Further, the technology has the potential to address protein-protein interactions and other previously undruggable targets.
About Ra Pharmaceuticals
Ra Pharma was incorporated in 2008 and secured a $27M Series A in February of 2010 led by New Enterprise Associates with Morgenthaler Ventures, Novartis Venture Funds and Amgen Ventures participating.
Source: www.merck.com

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Merz Overbids Valeant's Offer with a "Superior Proposal" for the Acquisition of Obagi
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Merz Pharma today outlined a proposal to acquire all of the outstanding common stock of Obagi for $22 per share in cash (end of March, Valeant offered $19.75$ per share in cash).This proposal represents a 58% premium to Obagi’s closing share price on Thursday, March 14, 2013. In a letter sent to the Board of Directors of Obagi, Merz CEO highlighted that 'the company has the necessary cash on hand to fund the transaction', with 'absolutely no financing risk'.
- Given Merz’s portfolio of injectables, Obagi is a natural fit for Merz.
- This acquisition would also expand Merz U.S. market presence, and strengthen and diversify its dermatology portfolio through additional quality skin care options.
In the Merz PR, it is reported that : On March 20, 2013, Obagi announced that it entered into a definitive merger agreement with Valeant Pharmaceuticals International, Inc. At that time, Merz was engaged in ongoing discussions with Obagi regarding a potential combination, and was not made aware that Obagi was contemplating signing a deal with another party on an accelerated timeframe. Merz has delivered its proposal to Obagi’s Board and believes it constitutes a “Superior Proposal” under the terms of the Obagi/Valeant merger agreement. Importantly, the Merz proposal also represents a significant premium to the offer from Valeant".
Reference in Traction CI, please See Neurology6866: Valeant to Acquire Obagi Medical for $344M.
Source: Merz

item.title: Medivation/Astellas Provide Update on PREVAIL
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: On a PR issued April 1st, Astellas announced that the companies have established an updated interim analysis plan expected to occur in 2013.
- PREVAIL Design: http://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT01212991?term=prevail&rank=6.
- Final Recruitment: 1,717
- Sites :
Source: Astellas

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Industry's Largest Growth Drivers Through to 2017
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Among the 10 products listed by First Word, one can note the Biogen Idec's Tecfidera (oral MS therapy), and Medivation/Astellas' Xtandi. The biggest growth driver is yet to launch (initial roll-out is expected in 2014). Additionnal information as well as highlights on key points about Tecfidera, which is expected to become the first choice of treatment for MS, are provided below.
- Gilead's Sofosbuvir (for hepatitis C) - sales growth 2012-2017 +4.3 billion)
- Roche's Perjeta (for HER2-positive breast cancer)
- Merck's Januvia (for type 2 diabetes)
- Biogen Idec's Tecfidera for MS - sales expected to reach approx. $3.3 billion by 2017
Approved last month, consensus among analysts, KOLs and physicians indicates the drug will emerge as the 1st-line treatment of choice for the condition over the next few years, despite being the third-to-market oral treatment (behind Novartis' Gilenya and Sanofi's Aubagio).
  • DRUG POSITION- Of 300 neurologists polled by FirstWord in 2012, 44% indicated that Tecfidera would likely be the oral MS therapy they would be prescribing the most in 2 years time.
  • DRUG EFFICAY/SAFETY- Consensus suggests that efficacy is comparable to Gilenya, but with superior safety.
  • DRUG INDICATION- Tecfidera and Gilenya expected to vie for 1st-line status. The drug will primarily assume market share from older injectable therapies (Avonex, Betaseron, Copaxone and Rebif collectively known as the ABCRs). A recent poll of US-based neurologists demonstrated that 66% of respondents expect to first use Tecfidera at the expense of ABCR therapies.
  • COST OF TREATMENT- The drug will be priced @ $54 900 per patient per year (lower that the $60 000 annual cost for Novartis' Gilenya, higher than Sanofi's Aubagio which costs $ 45 000 annually).
- AbbVie's Humira (for RA)
- BMS' Eliquis for VT
- Regeneron/Bayer's Eylea for AMD
- Celgene's Revlimid for MM
- Gilead's Stribild for HIV
- Medivation/Astellas' Xtandi for prostate cancer - Second-to-market behind Zytiga
Source: FirstWord

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Sanofi Reports Strategy to Grow Double-digit Sales in China
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Sanofi CEO reported the company expects that its sales in China will grow by more than 10% over the next 5 years thanks to the expansion of the animal health and vaccines business in the country. Globally, the group's ambitions is to reach double digit growth in emerging markets, rare diseases and multiple sclerosis (with the new Genszyme). Additional steps are provided below.
- Opening of 4 new manufacturing plants in 2013 to increase th eproduction of vaccines, drug, consumer HC and animal health products.
- Increasing the presence in China's smaller cities, as the government builds new hospitals and clinics.
- Discussion around the creation of a system with Chinese officials that would allow higher prices for medicines with longer development times, and larger investments.
Emerging markets, including China, accounted for 31.9% of the company's revenue.
Sales in China recorded > $1.28 billion.
Growth ambition by Growth Platform (March 25th presentation):
Source: Sanofi; Wall Street Journal

item.title: EAU Highlights - Allergan Overview
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Allergan will be launching their new MS screening tool next month and introduced the delegates to the BoNee Needle to aid injecting into the bladder.
Intelligence uncovered regarding TheraCoat’s TC-3 Gel — a novel Internal Cavity Drug Retention (ICDR) system via reverse thermal gelation technology (which is being mixed with mitomycin for NMIBC) is also being looked at in the US as a potential needle-free alternative to Botox for use in NDO or IOAB pts. This study is investigator sponsored and at this time no results are available. Allergan has not been in discussion with the company.
*Full company/product slide deck available upon request*
Allergan’s symposia was dedicated to discussing the DIGNITY data, injection tips and a patient video of injecting BOTOX with the BoNee needle. The CI team was unable to attend but did speak to a representative on the stand who discussed the new MS Urinary Function Screening Tool which will be launched next month.
The stand had LCD screens showing DIGNITY data as well as a light panel highlighting the countries in the EU where Botox has been approved for NDO and iOAB.
BoNee Needle
The BoNee Needle was designed with Urologists to facilitate bladder wall injection. It is not clear at this stage what the agreement or collaboration with Porges (a division of Coloplast) and Allergan is. Both parties funded the symposia.
MS Screening Tool
The screening tool is self-administered to help identify MS patients who could benefit from urologic evaluation.
Any checked box in the 3rd or 4th right hand column would incur a point. A score of ≥3 would indicate that the patient may need further evaluation of their bladder health.

item.title: Rituximab to be Investigated as Neoadjuvant Therapy for Prostate Cancer
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The small pilot study in 18 patients will determine whether depletion of B cells by rituximab will result in a decrease in the extent of B cell infiltration of the prostatic cancer. PE will measure hsitologic RR after one cycle of the drug.
There is now substantial evidence that B cells are recruited into prostate cancers by CXCL13 released by the tumor cells. B cells release lymphotoxin which drives malignant cell proliferation through the NFkB pathway.
Sponsor: St Howell, M.D (U of California, San Diego)
Collaborator: Genentech
Start date: March 2013
Completion date: March 2016 / March 2017
Location: USA
Source: clinicaltrials.gov

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Eisai's NerBloc® Launched in Japan for Cervical Dystonia
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Eisai launched NerBloc® Intramuscular Injection 2500 Units (botulinum toxin type B) on March 27 as a treatment for cervical dystonia. The drug's efficacy was proved in the double-blind Study 131 trial against placebo, with the most common adverse events including difficulty in swallowing, dry mouth, and thirst.
28,902 yen ($306.54) per vial containing 2500U.
Eisai acquired the exclusive rights to develop and market NerBloc in Japan from Elan in September 2000 and was approved as the marketing authorization holder following product development.
NerBloc was then listed on the National Health Insurance (NHI) drug price list on February 22, 2013.
  • Study Design: Multicenter, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, parallel, dose-response trial
  • Eligibility:   130 Patients with cervical dystonia (between 20 and 74 years old, inclusive)
  • Primary Objective:   Evaluation of safety and efficacy of botulinum toxin type B
  • Study Arms:   Botulinum toxin type B 2500, 5000 and 10000 units, placebo
  • Duration:   Single-dose administration
In a double-blind, placebo-controlled trial (Study 131) conducted by Eisai in Japan in patients with CD, NerBloc showed statistically significant improvement in TWSTRS (Toronto Western Spasmodic Torticollis Rating Scale) total score from baseline to week four versus placebo.
No serious side effects were reported, with the most common adverse events being difficulty in swallowing, dry mouth and thirst.
Source: Eisai

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: EAU Highlights - Enzalutamide and TAK700 Data
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Both Takeda with TAK700 and Astellas with Enzalutamide (XTANDI) highlighted their desire to move into additional earlier disease treatment settings, TAK700 into nmCPRC and enzalutamide into the hormone naive segement., The unmet need in the growing nmCRPC was highlighted by Axel Heindenreich, GTx's poster on Capesaris also garnered much attention due to the low rate of flushing observed compared to Lupron therapy.
Enzalutamide had little presence at this meeting with one phase II poster in hormone naïve pts . During the Astellas symposia, the link was made between enzalutamide's profile and the unmet needs in the pre-chemo CRPC setting with the slide below highlighted followed by a slide depicting the study schema for the PREVAIL trial.
Intelligence uncovered by a PI with the PREVAIL study (pre-chemo) noted that the trial had completed enrollment in September 2012 and should read out after the summer. This is slightly earlier than Medivation's recent guidance which pointed to a possible December timeframe (see Oncology8831: Medivation Guidance on PREVAIL & New Registrational Trials In Earlier Treatment Settings).
The TERRAIN study (schema below) has reached 85% enrollment and should be fully enrolled in the next 3-4 months and hopefully read out at the beginning of 2014. Druing Cora Steinberg’s presentation, she mentioned that enzalutamide was 8x more potent that bicalutamide.
Poster 674 Enzalutamide Monotherapy: Results from a P2 study in hormone naïve PCa pts
§ Primary objectives — effect of ENZ on PSA. Secondary objectives included evaluation of effects on endocrine hormone levels and BMD, lean and fat body mass and safety/tolerability.
§ 25 wk open label single arm study conducted across 12 sites in Austria, Belgium, Denmark, Czech Republic and Germany
Finally, during Axel wrap up session, he presented ‘what is new with enzalutamide’
TAK700 also had little on display with a phase 2 poster in nmCRPC pts. However, during Axel Heidenreich’s talk, which provided a round up of activities in the CRPC space the unmet need in this area was mentioned. Attached is a recent poster from ESMO which highlights the growing prevalence in the European markets.
Poster 100: A phase II study of TAK700 in nmCRPC and rising PSA pts. Data are presented as of 25th Jan 2013 and the study is currently ongoing
An interesting phase II poster presented with GTx-758 (Capesaris®) a selective estrogen receptor (ER) alpha agonist. This poster was selected as one of the best posters at the EAU and was garnering much attention from the delegates.
A new phase 2 study will start in the autumn looking at lower doses as they have seen the same effect with 125mg-500mg as with the 1000mg. The author stated the PSA change is nothing to write home about yet, it’s really the side effect profile, "hot flashes in particular we are excited about."

item.title: Record Gene Haul Points To Better Screening In Breast, Prostate & Ovarian Cancer
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: New research published yesterday has nearly doubled the number of genetic variations implicated in a number of key cancers offering fresh avenues for screening at-risk patients. The largest every study which has analysed the DNA of 200,000 people (50% with cancer) has identified 74 gene changes associated with three hormone-related cancers.
Ros Eeles of the UK Institute of Cancer Research is quoted as saying that the new findings represent the biggest lead forward yet in our understanding of the genetic basis of prostate cancer. The study found 23 new genetic variations (SNPs0 linked to prostate cancer 16 of which were linked to the more aggressive form of the disease.
Doug Easton from the University of Cambridge, the lead researcher on the project believes that new cancer screening programmes will arise from this research and that within 10 years this might be commonly used paving the way for identification of men at very high risk of developing prostate cancer during their lifetime.
The new research has been published in a series of papers in Nature Genetics, Nature Communications, PLOS Genetics and the American Journal of Human Genetics and Human Molecular Genetics
Source: reuters.com

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Clinical Progress with Omeros' PDE10 for Huntington Disease
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: OMS824’s emerging profile in Phase 1 suggests oral, once-daily dosing, which predictably reaches therapeutic levels in the brain and could be potent. Analyst at Wedbush believe the clean Ph1 results create a strong foundation for testing efficacy in Ph2 trials for HD followed by schizophrenia. Trial could begin in H2 2013 and provide results in H1 2014.
Omeros' PDE10 program is supported by funds from The Stanley Medical Research Institute, a non-profit corporation that supports research on the causes and treatment of schizophrenia and bipolar disorder.
- to obtain orphan Drug designation in the US (which could result in a premium pricing).
PDE10 is an enzyme that is expressed in areas of the brain strongly linked to schizophrenia and other psychotic disorders. PDE10 inhibitors have been shown to be as effective in vivo as current anti-psychotic drugs.
As of February 15, 2012, Omeros owned one issued patent and four pending patent applications in the US and nine pending patent application in foreign markets that claim proprietary PDE10 inhibitors.
Pfizer recently announced the start of a Ph2 with its drug candidate - PF-02545920 is an oral, twice-daily phosphodiesterase 10A (PDE10A) inhibitor. Biochemical and behavioral data indicate that PDE10A inhibition activates cAMP/PKA signalling in the basal ganglia, leading to the potentiation of dopamine D₁ receptor signalling, and concomitant inhibition of dopamine D₂receptor signalling - (see Neurology6860: Pfizer's PDE10 Inhibitor to Enter Ph2 for Early Huntington's Disease).
Source: Omeros; Thomson One

item.title: PROLOR Reinforces its Patent Portfolio for its Long-Acting hGH
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: PROLOR has received a notice of allowance from the USPTO for a new patent application covering the company's hGH-CTP for decreasing body fat. Treatment with human growth hormone may help decrease the excessive body fat that can characterize growth hormone deficiency in adults.
- the fifth for hGH-CTP since 2009
- expected to issue in the next few months
- March 2012 Initiation of a Phase II trial in children with growth hormone deficiency. This trial is currently expected to conclude in 2013.
- May 2012 - top-line results from the four–month treatment extension of Phase II Clinical Trial, which demonstrated that a single weekly injection of hGH-CTP has the potential to replace seven consecutive daily injections of currently marketed hGH. These results further validate the dosing regimen for Phase III trial.
Source: PROLOR Biotech

item.title: Evotec Reports Strong Progress in All Units of its "Action Plan 2016"
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Evotec achieved continued profitable growth in 2012 with revenues up 9% to EUR 87.3 m (2011: EUR 80.1 m). Management reported that the three business units of the 'Action Plan 2016', Evotec 1-Execute/2-Integrate/3-Innovate, achieved strong progress during 2012. Key slides highlighting the group's activities in Huntington's disease and endometriosis are provided below.
aims to deliver cost efficient and industrialised services for drug discovery on a fee-for-service basis.
Evotec looks for continued 2-digit revenue growth and gross margin expansion in this lower value, fee for service business in 2013.
Examples for Strategic Collaborations
is the systematic approach to progress targets through the pre-clinic, on a research payments, milestones and royalties success basis.
Evotec anticipates further new partnerships (including expanded customer reach to biotech/small-midsized pharma) and more milestones in ongoing alliances as to underpin the shift to higher value, integrated drug discovery alliances.
involves accelerating promising drug discovery ideas and assets to partnerships with upfront payments, premium research fees, milestones.
Evotec expects the start of several clinical trials within existing drug discovery alliances (e.g. MedImmune, Boehringer Ingelheim, J&J), while also targeting one ‘rollover/ commercialization’.
Source: Evotec

item.title: First FFA2 Inhibitor to be Evaluated Clinically
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Galapagos reported that the positive outcome of the phase 1 study with GLPG0974 supports progression to a POC trial next month for ulcerative colitis (UC).
GLPG0974 is an orally available small molecule that reduces migration of neutrophils by potent inhibition of FFA2 (free fatty acid receptor 2, formerly known as GPR43).
Overactivity of neutrophils is a cause of tissue damage in illnesses such as inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).
A reduction of neutrophil activation and migration by inhibition of FFA2 may provide for a novel anti-inflammatory treatment approach.
By inhibiting FFA2, GLPG0974 prevents free fatty acid-induced activation and migration of neutrophils towards an inflammatory site, such as in the gut of patients with inflammatory bowel disease.
Source: Galapagos

Comments
The drug has entered into the first Ph2 trial for testing safety and efficacy, with top-line results expected Q1:14.
Trial Details
  • Design: Four-week study with approx. 45 patients with mild to moderate UC
  • Objective: to assess efficacy, effects on selected biomarkers, afety and tolerability and PK.
  • Regimen: patients will receive either 200 mg of the drug twice-daily or placebo for a period of 4 weeks.
  • Location: Belgium; Latvia; Czech Rep. and Slovakia.
Source: Galapagos

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Otsuka Cements The Largest Deal This Year With Lundbeck
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Otsuka has signed a deal worth $825m with Lundbeck covering a CNS-based alliance centred around Lundbeck's Alzheimer's and schizophrenia candidate LuAE58054 a selective 5HT-6 receptor antagonist. The total upfront fee was $150m.
The long-term collaborators have seen some success with their neurological efforts, most recently with the US approval of the long-acting schizophrenia product Abilify.
However, sceptics suggest that Alzheimer's is a tougher prospect and with the drug yet to start phIII $825m looks a little racy. The plan is to commence a phIII programme in more than 2500 patients during the course of 2013.
Deal Terms
Under the terms of the agreement, Lundbeck will grant Otsuka co-development and co-commercialisation rights to LiAE58054 in the US, Canada, East Asia including Japan, major European countries and Nordic countries.
Both companies will share the sales, development and commercialisation costs, whilst Lundbeck is entitled to up to $675m in regulatory and sales milestones. Additional specific financial terms of the agreement remain undisclosed.
Source: www.lundbeck.com

Recruitment: approx. 280 (18 to 49 years at screening)
Start date: March 2013

item.title: Key Messages from Aeterna Zentaris Earning Conference Call
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Alongside its financial results, management highlighted that 2012 was a challenging year for the company as it had to face disappointing Ph3 results for perifosine (in colorectal cancer). It highlighted near-term value drivers are AEZS-108 (specifically targets LHRH receptors which are present in endometrial, breast, bladder, and ovarian cancer), and AEZS-130 (first oral diagnostic for adult growth hormone deficiency ; preparation of the marketing and launch strategy). Of note, the progression of AEZS-120 (oral tumour vaccine candidate for prostate cancer).
- pre-clinical data presented at the Congress of the Societe Internationale d'Urologie in Japan. The presentation underlines the feasibility of an oral therapeutic vaccination approach against prostate cancer. The production, pharmacology, safety, and toxicology program was conducted and successfully finalized in agreement with the regulatory authorities. This program was partially sponsored by a grant from the German government.
Status/Indication: EMA classification as advanced therapeutic medicinal product (ATMP); EMA Scientific Advice received with no principle objectives with respect to start Ph1; CTA/IND filing in preparation.
Status/Indication: Ph1/ph2 in castration-and taxane resistant prostate cancer internalization in circulating tumor cells (CTCs). The Ph1 portion of the NIH funded Ph1/ph2 has been completed and recruitment for the Ph2 portion.
Status/Indication: Ph3 - Diagnostic test for AGHD

item.title: Nomura Highlights Medy-Tox As One Of Its Top Buys Due To Export Growth & Emerging Potential Of Next Generation Toxin
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: After a recent company visit, Nomura's bullish investment report on Medy-Tox highlights some key points about market entry of the group's next generation freeze-dried toxin formulation, expected in Korea Q413 and launches elsewhere of Neuronox. It believes any licensing deal covering EU & US market entry (expected mid-2013) will prove to be a share price catalyst.
Neuronox Launch Sequence
Medytox expects to get product registration for Neuronox in Russia in Q213, Mexico in 1H13 and Columbia 2H13. It views approval in Russia as a promising event for the company since Russia has a KRW60bn aesthetic market with predicted CAGR of 14% over the next few year.
Market Entry Of Daewoong's Product
Commenting on the market entry of Daewoong's botulinum toxin which is expected in September this year, Nomura believes the real impact of the product will not be felt until FY14 when Medytox's domestic contribution from sales of Neuronox is likely to be 38%. DWP's target is to garner 18% market share in FY14.
Launch Of Next Generation Medy-Tox Toxin
However to counter this impact, Medy-Tox expects to launch its next generation product in Korea in Q413. The company has apparently already submitted an application to the KDFA w/c 4th March (seemingly based on a phII trial which completed in November 2012) and is expecting approval later this year. This next generation product is a freeze dried product which is HSA free. It is not a liquid formulation as development of the latter is running about 1.5-2 years behind the freeze dried preparation. The new formulation is expected to be marketed at higher price than the company's current product.
Source: Nomura Report 11.03.13

item.title: NPS Enters Into Global Commercialisation Deal With Takeda
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: NPS has entered into a deal with Takeda to regain ex-US rights to tedlutide for short bowel syndrome and Preotact for osteoporosis. This will strengthen its footprint as a global commercial rare disease company. The company's 2013 priorities remain the successful US launch of Gattex for short bowel syndrome and the submission of the US marketing application for its parathyroid hormone (PTH 1-84) for hyperparathyroidism.
Deal Terms
NSP has reqacquired the rights for $50m upfront in the form of common stock of NPSP. Additionally its is to receive milestone payment of $30m in the first calendar year that combined sales exceed $750m.
Commenting on the divestment Frank Morich, CCO of Takeda said: "Orphan drugs like teduglutide , serve high unmet needs. We are confident that as an orphan and specialty company NPS is best suited to maximise the value of teduglutide and PTH 1-84. The structure of this transaction allows us to particiapte in NPS's future success with these products.
Current Regulatory Status of The Two Products
Teduglutide, marketed in the U.S. under the trade name Gattex, is approved in Europe under the trade name Revestive Teduglutide was approved in the European Union and the U.S. in August and December 2012, respectively. PTH 1-84 is approved for post-menopausal osteoporosis in the European Union since April 2006, where it is known under the trade name Preotact®. NPS is developing PTH 1-84 under the brand name Natpara in the U.S. for the treatment of hypoparathyroidism
Next Steps
Having completed this transformational event, NPS has retained the consulting services of Sandy Smith, who served as Executive Vice President and President of Genzyme's International Group. Under Sandy's leadership, Genzyme's International revenue grew to 65% of Genzyme's nearly $5 billion in revenues. He was also responsible for Genzyme's successful global launch of 12 new products.

Sandy will work to lay the foundation of NPS international expansion and position PTH and teduglutide for global commercial success. Over the next few months, it is planned that he will focus on the following three priorities.

  • designing and implementomg NPS global corporate structure;.
  • defining the group's global business model iendtifying key leaders of the international organization; and
  • thirdly develop global product strategies that maximize the commercial value of teduglutide and PTH.
Source: www.npsp.com

item.title: New MOA To Target All Forms Of DMD
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Summit Corporation, a UK based drug discovery and development company has outlined its plans for the continued development of utrophin modulators for the treatment of Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy. It believes these modulators, in contrast, to more late stage development candidats have the ability to treat all genetic forms of the disease.
Summit's lead candidate SMT C1100 is expected to eneter clinical development in the 2H2013. There are also earlier-stage next generation molecules that are being developed to add further value to the programme.
Teh clinnical programme hopes to quickly establish POC through the use of novel biomarkers developed specifically to measure aspects of muscle health.
Summit intends to present its utrophin modulation programme and biomarker development at the upcoming Muscular Dystrophy Association Confernece in April in Wahsington (April 21st to 24th).
Source: www.summit.com

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: AZ Signs New Technology Deal
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: AstraZeneca has announced an exclusive agreement with Moderna Therapeutics to discover, develop and commercialise pioneering messenger RNA therapeutics™ for the treatment of serious cardiovascular, metabolic and renal diseases as well as cancer. Through this agreement AZ will have the option to select up to 40 drug products for clinical development.

Deal Terms

Under the terms of the agreement, AstraZeneca will make a large upfront payment of $240 million. AstraZeneca will have exclusive access to select any target of its choice in cardiometabolic diseases, as well as selected targets in oncology, over a period of up to five years for subsequent development of messenger RNA.

Additionally, Moderna is entitled to an additional $180 million for the achievement of three technical milestones. Moderna will also be entitled to development and commercial milestone payments as well as royalties on drug sales ranging from high single digits to low double digits for each product.

AstraZeneca will lead the preclinical, clinical development and commercialisation of therapeutics resulting from the agreement and Moderna will be responsible for designing and manufacturing the messenger RNA against selected targets.

Nature of Moderna' s Technology

Moderna’s uses proprietary messenger RNA containing naturally occurring nucleotide analogues, which are designed to stimulate the body’s natural ability to produce intracellular and secreted therapeutic proteins without triggering an innate immune response.

The secreted proteins will be released into the bloodstream to potentially restore function elsewhere in the body. Using messenger RNA also has the potential advantage of dramatically reducing the time and expense associated with creating therapeutic proteins using current recombinant technologies.

Commenting on the deal Pascal Soriot, Chief Executive Officer of AstraZeneca, said:

“Today’s agreement signals an exciting move for AstraZeneca and our focus on innovation. Together with Moderna, we are pushing the boundaries of science in the pioneering field of messenger RNA therapeutics™. Where current drug discovery technologies can target only a fraction of the disease-relevant proteins in the human genome, we have the potential to create completely new medicines to treat patients with serious cardiometabolic diseases and cancer.”

Source: www.astrazeneca.com


Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: J&J Expects to Seek U.S. Approval of its Botulinum Toxin in 2014
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The J&J "product" will target medical aesthetic first and could be available in the US in 2015, overseas a few years later, the company said. The data from completed late-stage trials has not yet been unveiled, but David Wilson, president of J&J's Mentor division, told Reuters he was pleased with the results. Valeant and Merz did not comment on the potential J&J threat.
Wilson reported that:
- "J&J aims to leapfrog Dsyport and Xeomin and become a solid No. 2 in the market".
- “What we hope to offer is a product of certainly comparable quality to Botox...to basically be on par with them” in terms of effectiveness and safety".
The fiercest competition between the products will likely occur in emerging markets such as China and South America, where Botox is not firmly entrenched. (Morningstar's Waterhouse).
Analysts and dermatologists said J&J's product would need to work faster, last longer or be significantly cheaper than Botox in order to wrest market share from the original injectable wrinkle fighter.
Patients aren't quick to switch from something with which they are familiar (Dermatologist in West Palm Beach, Florida).
Source: TAL_Traction
Q113 earnings conference call (April 16).
Source: Thomson One

item.title: Merck's China Trials Offshoring Saves 30%
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Dr. Peter Aurup, Head of Global Clinical Trial Operations (GCTO) at Merck Research Laboratories has revealed that the company realized a 25-30% cost saving after establishing a data management center in China, as part of Merck's expanded global reach through both outsourcing and offshoring. Notably, the center features 5% foreign professionals who assist in training local staff.
Nevertheless, Aurup remarked that the 20% turnover rate presents a specific challenge, as do expectations placed on local employees tasked with project responsibilities.
Merck has increased the number of outsourced clinical trials to 50% from 10% in 2008 and 2009, including trials for biosimilar, respiratory, diabetes and hypertension drug development programs.
Source: GBI

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: BMS to Launch at Least 4 New Diabetes Drugs in China by 2015
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: BMS China President Jean-Christophe Pointeau underscored that diabetes is one of BMS China's most significant business areas, in line with Chinese government policies designed to boost chronic disease prevention and treatment and medical insurance coverage expansion.
The China National Plan for Chronic Disease Prevention and Treatment (2012-2015) lists diabetes as a top priority, and according to a National People's Congress report, China will increase its healthcare expenditure by 27.1% YOY in 2013. The Chinese diabetic population has been projected to rise from 92.4 million to 130 million by 2030.
Competition is expected from Sanofi (NYSE: SNY) and Novo Nordisk (NYSE: NVO), which are both increasing emerging market diabetes R&D investment.
Source: GBI

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Key Messages from Bayer Meet Management Conference
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The healthcare sessions were presided over by the interim divisional head, Wolfgang Plischke. The sessions focused on the roll out of the key late-stage assets, with Xarelto leading the way. Emerging markets continue to be very important contributors for growth (37% of 2012 sales).
