item.title: Key Messages from AstraZeneca Investor Day
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Management highlighted 3 ambitions for the group (Focus, Accelerate and Transform), its focus in 3 therapy areas (cardio-metabolism; oncology and respiratory/inflammation), driven by infection and vaccines and neuroscience, the increase proximity to bioscience clusters around 3 strategic sites (Gaithersburg; Cambridge, Mölndal), and its focus on 5 growth platforms (Cardiovascular; Diabetes; Emerging Markets; Respiratory; Japan). Business development activity, which will be lead by newly appointed Marc Dunoyer (ex GSK), was cited as being a key priority. Restructuring strategy as well as key slides are provided below.
In addition to R&D reshaping program ($1.4bn cost, 1,600 positions, $190m benefits from 2016), SG&A headcount will be reduced by 2,300 (EU field force, back office). Combined with the balance of the Ph III program, headcount will reduce by 5,050 through 2016, at a cost of $2.3bn ($1.7bn cash). Astra expects benefits of $800m per annum from 2016 (c5% of current cost base).
Marc Dunoyer (newly created role of Executive VP, Global Portfolio & Product Strategy) will be responsible for driving business strategy, including business development, mergers and acquisitions, portfolio and product strategies.
His most critical priorities will be to bolster the core growth platforms and therapy areas through well executed business development initiatives and leadership of internal efforts.
- Upcoming Major Events to 2017 from 2013
A key growth platform for AZ.
Basically, 2 drugs being developed for prostate cancer:
Olaparib
  • Five Phase III in ovarian, gastric and breast
  • Three Phase II in lung
  • Two Phase IB in prostate
AZD5363 (AKT inhibitor)
  • Personalized strategy (See Oncology8491: AstraZeneca AKT Inhibitor to Enter Ph1 for mCRPC).

item.title: Nice Rejects Novartis' Afinitor for Breast Cancer
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The drug has been rejected due to uncertainty over its survival benefits in the condition. During its FY12 financial results, management reported that Afinitor has the potential to exceed sales of USD 2 bn in breast cancer alone by 2017.
Afinitor (everolimus) is the 1st mTOR inhibitor to be approved for post-menopausal women with advanced-receptor positive, HER2-negative breast cancer.
- approved in July 2012 in the US abd EU for HR+/HER2-advanced breast cancer.
- Launched in the US, Germany, Austria, Argentina, UK and Canada.
- Afinitor 2012 sales grew 85% vs previous year and reached $797M.
Source: Biocentury; Novartis

item.title: Retrospective Review of BOTOX® and Xeomin® for Blepharospasm and Cervical Dystonia
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Allergan is sponsoring a retrospective chart review to evaluate the doses of the different toxins used for the treatment of cervical dystonia and blepharospasm in clinica practice. PE will assess dose of botulinum toxin used to treat the conditions.
Recruitment: approx 90 men/women (18 years and older)
  • confirmed primary diagnosis of idiopathic cervical dystonia or blepharospasm for at least 2 years
  • treatment with Xeomin® and BOTOX® for at least 1 year each
Start date: Jan. 2013 - Completion date: June 2013
Source: clinicaltrials.gov

item.title: BOTOX® After Laser Resurfacing in Chinese Men/Women with Glabellar Lines
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: A new Ph4 trial has started in Beijing to evaluate safety and efficacy of the treatment. PE will measure investigator's assessment of the severity of frown lines at maximum contraction using the 4-point facial wrinkle scale.
ecruitment: approx. 200 men/women (18 years to 60 years).
Completion dates: Feb. 2014 / May 2014.
Inclusion criteria: moderate to severe frown lines - facial laser treatment between 4 to 8 weeks prior to Day 1.
Source: clinicaltrials.gov

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: PhII Localised Prostate Cancer Treatment Trial Continues To Progress Well
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Nymox Corporation has announced that the IDMC for the Company's Phase 2 study of NX-1207 for low risk localized prostate cancer (NX03-0040) has reported a third positive analysis of safety data from the clinical trial. The 150 patient trial is due to complete in terms of its efficacy endpoint in April 2013.
Study Design
The NX03-0040 study tests both low and high doses of NX-1207 for their effect on low grade localized prostate cancer. In the study, the NX-1207 dose is administered directly into the area of the prostate where the cancer was detected.
The procedure is performed by a urologist in an office setting, does not require anaesthesia, sedation, or catheterization, takes only a few minutes and involves minimal discomfort to the patient.
Patients in the study are randomly allocated to either low or high dose NX-1207 or to active surveillance (no treatment). Patients undergoing active surveillance in the trial also have the opportunity to receive NX-1207 after their trial active surveillance participation is completed.
Localised Cancer Statistics
The American Cancer Society estimates that in 2012 more than 240,000 men in the United States will be newly diagnosed with prostate cancer and more than 28,000 men will die from the disease. Most cases are detected via prostate-specific antigen (PSA) screening and usually found to have localized tumors.
Other Developments With NX-1207
NX-1207 is also in late stage Phase 3 development in the U.S. for the treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia. Phase 3 trial activities of NX-1207 for BPH have recently begun in Europe sponsored by Recordati S.p.A., the company's European licensing partner for the BPH indication.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Valeant to Acquire Obagi Medical for $344M
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Valeant has a long story of acquisitions. It recently purchased Medicis which provides the company with a good branded US dermatology platform. With Obagi, it will have access to proprietary topical aesthetic and therapeutic prescription-strength skin care systems in the physician-dispensed market.
Valeant will acquire all of the outstanding common stock of Obagi for $19.75 per share in cash, which represents a 42% premium to Obagi’s closing share price on Thursday, March 14, 2013, the last trading day prior to the disclosure of its fourth quarter and full year 2012 earnings, and a 40% premium to the thirty day prior stock price.
Using its Penetrating Therapeutics™ technologies, Obagi Medical's products are designed to improve penetration of agents across the skin barrier for common and visible skin conditions in adult skin including premature aging, photodamage, hyperpigmentation, acne, sun damage, rosacea, and soft tissue deficits, such as fine lines and wrinkles.
- Product lines: please see @ http://www.obagi.com/patients/product-line
  • cosmetic, over-the-counter and prescription products, including 4% hydroquinone.
Products are sold and promoted only through physician offices and requires education by a physician on proper use.
Reference on Valeant in Traction CI please see Neurology6837: Key Takeaways from Valeant Q4 and FY12 Results.

item.title: Almirall May Discontinue Selling Sativex for Spasticity in Germany
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The drug was launched in July 2011 after obtaining approval in May. Since June 2012 Almirall has been in price negotiations and unable to a agree satisfactory price with the German National Association of Statutory Health Insurance Funds.
GW Pharm.'s management reported that " ... the decision in Germany is in distinct contrast to the price agreed in every other EU country to date".
Almirall plans to take all necessary steps to challenge the decision, which may include suspension or withdrawal of supply.
Noting that Sativex is already approved in 20 countries, with marketing already having started in 8 of them, Almirall presents the decision by the GKV as a contrast from the way the drug has been received in other European countries.
This may reflect the efforts being made by the company to protect its price in the European countries that use Germany as a reference market; with no exact information on the price offered by the GKV, it is hard to assess how much of a gap there is between the German price offer and the prices the drug has secured in other countries. However, this situation is certainly indicative of a harshening regulatory situation in Germany.The product has not bee approved in the US, where it is currently in Ph3 for advanced cancer pain.

item.title: Bayer's Radium-223 Dichloride to be Tested for mCRPC with Bone Metastasis in Asia
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The Ph3 study is expected to last 4 years, and recruit patients in China, South Korea, Taiwan and Singapore. Primary endpoint will assess OS, and safety variables will be summarized in a descriptive manner based on AEs collection, laboratory changes, changes in vital signs and ECG.
Recruitment: approx. 150
Start date: March 2013
Completion dates: April 2017
Protocol: Radium-223 dichloride, 50 kBq/kg body weight, will be administered as a slow bolus IV injection at 4 week intervals for up to 6 doses.
Source: clinicaltrials.gov

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Significant Milestone for BMS and Merck Serono in China
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Merck Serono and BMS have signed a collaboration agreement for the promotion of the different formulations of Glucophage® (type 2 diabetes). The product has been marketed by Bristol- Myers Squibb-SASS in China since 1999. The two companies will utilize their existing resources and complementary strengths, with Bristol-Myers Squibb-SASS continuing to manufacture Glucophage’s IR® (immediate release) formulation.
- to expand the geographic distribution of Glucophage®.
- to provide diabetes-related health and medical information including education for health professionals.
- to increase outreach to hospitals.
Glucophage® (metformin hydrochloride) is a prescription-only medicine indicated for the treatment of type 2 diabetes mellitus particularly in overweight patients when diet and exercise alone have failed.
- China now has the most people with diabetes of any country in the world. It has become a major public health problem in China with >90 million people suffering from the disease (International Diabetes Federation. press-statement-china-study).
- Current estimates are that >60% of patients with type 2 diabetes are undiagnosed (Yang W, et al. N Engl J Med. 2010; 362(12): 1090-101), possibly due to a combination of poor public awareness and limited opportunities for diagnosis.
Source: Merck Serono PR

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Positive Results of Biocancell's Targeted Therapy for Bladder Cancer
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The Israeli company reported positive results from the Ph2b of BC-819 in the treatment of patients with itermediate-risk superficial bladder cancer who did not respond to chemotherapy or BCG. Management indicated it was in discussion with several large drugmakers for further development and commercialisation of the therapy.
- Design: Please see NCT00595088
- Results:
  • 24 of 31 patients who completed 12-month of BC-819 treatment and 12 of 25 who completed 24-months of BC-819 treament did not develop new tumours.
  • >80% of patients in the BC-819 arm displayed no functional impairment acc to the Karnofsky Performance Scale during the study period.
BioCancell's patented, personalized cancer therapy approach is based on the identification of target oncogenes, such as H19.
H19 is significantly expressed in over thirty-three different forms of cancer, including superficial bladder carcinoma and pancreatic, ovarian and metastatic liver cancer, while laying dormant and non-expressed in non-cancerous cells.
Source: Clinicaltrials.gov; company website; ThomsonOne.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: BIND Biosciences' Accurins Lead Drug to Enter POC for mCRPC
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Phase 2 has been designed to determine the safety and efficacy of BIND-014 (docetaxel nanoparticles for injectable suspension), administered to approx. 40 men with mCRPC. PE will determine the eficacy of the drug by rPFS.
Start date: April 2013 - Completion dates: Aug. 2014 / Dec. 2015.
PI: Howard Scher, MD (Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center).
Location: USA (1 site).
Accurins Platform

item.title: Progenics Increases Its Focus On Prostate Cancer - Both Imaging & Therapy
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Progenics elaborated on its recent purchase of Molecular Insight during its fourth quarter earnings call last week, suggesting that it supports the group's progress towards becoming a preeminent oncology-focused company with prostate cancer developments providing a core orientation.
Prostate Cancer Imaging
Earlier this month, Progenics reported positive clinical data from a study of imaging agents that were part of the Molecular Insight acquisition. The paper summarizing these data were selected as the cover feature for the March issue of the Journal of Nuclear Medicine.

Progenics noted that Imaging options that currently exist are limited in their ability to diagnose and stage prostate cancer. Data from studies of the compounds discussed in that journal paper and from MIP-1404, all of which we acquired from Molecular Insight indicate that PSMA is a robust target for prostate cancer molecular imaging.

Progenics believes that a radiolabeled small molecule, which binds PSMA with high affinity has the potential to detect prostate cancer throughout the body offering an improved way to visualize prostate cancer with a high degree of specificity and sensitivity.

CRPC Therapy

Elsewhere in its pipeline, the PSMA ADC Phase II study of up to 75 patients with metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer is ongoing. This is an open label trial to assess any tumor activity as measured by responses in PSA, circulating tumor cells, pain and change in tumor size as measured under RECIST criteria. Tolerability and safety are also being assessed. There are currently 25 sites open and which expect to complete enrollment by the end of this year.

Phase I data on this product was presented at ASCO GU this year, the poster presentation for which is attached

Commenting on the company's first 30 day impression/decisions regarding Molecular Insight Mark Baker CEO noted:-

"The bottom line of that is that we will be closing the Cambridge facility of Molecular Insight, just a few people from Molecular Insight will be joining us and I don't see any overall increase in our head count as a result of that acquisition. And, I think we're following the path that we said that we would, when we announced the acquisition we're moving forward with the Phase II trial of the MIP-1404 imaging agent. As I've come to deepen my knowledge around the potential for an imaging agent In prostate cancer, I have to say, my excitement about that program has been building. And the Azedra program, the Ultra-Orphan program for this rare adrenal gland tumor continues to be of great interest and our first effort there is to meet with the Agency, as I've said and get a path forward, given that there is an SPA in place and there is data that satisfies that SPA, although the trial was stopped prematurely because of Molecular Insight's financial troubles."

There are early-stage programs there focusing on small molecule, targeting the PSMA, and we're continuing to evaluate those. But the priority are the Phase II program for the imaging agent and the Azedra program. And when you add that to our PSMA program, we have now with this acquisition moved into a position of having three late-stage oncology programs whereas previously we had one.

Source: www.progenics.com

item.title: The Growth Imperative for AstraZeneca
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: In comments made public at recent events, new CEO Pascal Soriot stressed future strategy being 1/short-term priority: optimise growth drivers; 2/medium-term: return AZ to growth overall; 3/ long-term: to rebuild R&D by exploiting leading science better, and remain focussed on innovation. Of note this CEO's comment: "... we are going to be rebuilding oncology. ... oncology is also close to my heart". On March 18, management announced plans to invest in strategic R&D in the UK, the US and Sweden to improve pipeline productivity. Over the 2013-2016 period, the proposed investment and associated changes will lead to the relocation of nearly 2,500 roles and an overall estimated reduction in headcount in the region of 1,600 roles. Key points are highlighted below.
Under the plans, AstraZeneca’s small molecule and biologics R&D activities will be concentrated in 3 strategic centres:
  • Cambridge, UK;
  • Gaithersburg, US; and
  • Mölndal, Sweden.
The proposals are expected to be fully implemented by 2016. The main changes are as follows:
  • Alderley Park, Cheshire, UK: Under the proposals, research and development work will no longer be carried out at Alderley Park. Approximately 1,600 roles will relocate from Alderley Park, with the significant majority going to the new centre in Cambridge and the remainder to the company’s nearby Macclesfield manufacturing facility or other AstraZeneca sites overseas. At least 700 non-R&D roles are expected to remain at Alderley Park. AstraZeneca is committed to exploring all options to ensure that Alderley Park has a successful future.
  • Wilmington, Delaware, US: With the exit of the Global Medicines Development group and the relocation of global marketing and US specialty care commercial roles, about 1,200 roles will leave Wilmington. There will be a net increase of approximately 300 roles in Gaithersburg. The changes announced today will lead to an estimated overall reduction of about 650 positions in the US; while around 170 will relocate to other AstraZeneca sites in the US or overseas. Wilmington will remain the North America commercial headquarters, with a population of about 2,000 at the AstraZeneca site.
  • London, UK: The majority of corporate and global commercial roles based in London are expected to move to the new centre in Cambridge with some going to other AstraZeneca sites. Following the transfer of the company’s headquarters to Cambridge, AstraZeneca’s Paddington office will close by 2016. Currently, around 350 roles are based in London.
The programme is expected to incur $1.4 billion in one-time restructuring charges, of which $800 million are likely to be cash costs. In addition, the company will invest approximately $500 million in establishing the new centre in Cambridge. Annualised benefits of approximately $190 million are expected by 2016 for the programme.
Rationale
AstraZeneca faces $6 bln revenue falls as generics bite.
Loss of Exclusivity by Brand
Sustainable revenues from:
  • Casodex: fast decline in US/WE, but stable in emerging markets
  • Zoladex: device technology and difficult to manufacture
  • cardiovascular drug Brilinta
  • the diabetes franchise
  • emerging markets, notably China.
  • the respiratory franchise (currently largely based around Symbicort).
  • the relatively young pharma business in Japan.
More news to come on March 21 at Analysts/Investors Day will outline the ambitions for the company.
See PharmaWorld10020: AstraZeneca Appoints New CEO.

item.title: Interest In The DMD Market Gathers Pace
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment PTC Therapeutics concluded a very successful private fund raising last week raising $60m to fund phase III development of its Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy Drug ataluren. The latter demonstrated a statistically significant improvement in walking distance in a phIIb trial.
Regulatory Status & Requirements
A phase III DMD study is set to begin this half and should complete by 2H2015. the EAM is already reviewing an MAA seeking conditional approval of ataluren though approval appears to be viewed as a long shot. The FDA has recommende that an additional study beyond the group's PhIIb trial be undertaken before seeking approval in the US
Details of New Financing
The financing was led by new investor Brookside Capital the public equity afficiliate of Bain Capital. Additional new invesotrs included Adage Capital, Jennison Assocaites, Longwood Fund and its existing set of 7 venture capital groups. Two new borad seats were allocated to Brookside and the Longwood fund.
Meanwhile, Sarepta Therapeutics has seen its market cap spike by 910% since reporting its phIIb data last July giving it a current market cap of $1.03bn.
PTC has raised at least $271.6 million since it was founded in 1998 and currently has no immenent plans to IPO.
Source: www.ptctherapeutics.com

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: re: Daewoong's European Ambition
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Daewoong's European Ambition 
Comment: Korean Daewoong Pharmaceuticals is gaining a foothold in the European market through a distrubtion partnership with Turkey's leading pharmaceutical company Abdi Ibrahim for its biosimilar Epogen. Although, we are not aware of Daewoong's specific intent to enter Europe with its new toxin DWP450, this is the first indication of the company's ambition to enter the European markets with its products  ...
Abdi Ibrahim is the former distributor of Allergan in Turkey before they decide to go direct in the country.

item.title: Pfizer's PDE10 Inhibitor to Enter Ph2 for Early Huntington's Disease
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Administration of PDE10 inhibitors has been shown to provide symptomatic and neuropathological improvements in mouse models as well as extending lifespan. The trial will evaluate the safety, tolerability and brain function of 2 doses of PF-0254920 in subjects with early Huntington's Disease. PE will assess change from baseline to D28 of unified HD rating scale.
Start date: April 2013 / Completion date: March 2015
Recruitment: approx. 65
Site: US

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Daewoong's European Ambition
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Korean Daewoong Pharmaceuticals is gaining a foothold in the European market through a distrubtion partnership with Turkey's leading pharmaceutical company Abdi Ibrahim for its biosimilar Epogen. Although, we are not aware of Daewoong's specific intent to enter Europe with its new toxin DWP450, this is the first indication of the company's ambition to enter the European markets with its products
Daewoong regards this development as an important milestone for the company because of the requirement for "high quality products conforming to rigorous EU guidelines"
Having signed a contract with Turkey-based Abdi Ibrahim, the latter will have the right to distribute EPOSIS a pre-filled liquid syringe verson of erythropoietin and Easyef dermal solution in Turkey. Both products are expected to complete the approval process by 2015. Expectations are that these products will generate more than $13m and $25m in sales five years post launch.
Source: www.daewoong.co.kr

Comments
Abdi Ibrahim is the former distributor of Allergan in Turkey before they decide to go direct in the country.

item.title: re: The Toxin Therapeutic Therapy Area Landscape
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
The Toxin Therapeutic Therapy Area Landscape 
Comment: As part of our ongoing commitment to the recently launched CI/SIS Therapy Area Landscape Service, you will find attached an overview of the competitive landscape in the botulinum toxin therapeutic area.  ...
Dear Jackie, there is one company I recently came across of relevance to this - Theracoat (theracoat.com/). I briefly met their VP Business Development at the Drug Delivery Partnerships conference. They have a novel hydrogel polymer that gels when it reaches body temperature. They are using it to increase retention time and control release of drugs in cavities - focussing on the bladder.
The polymer is not absorbed and eventually passes out in the urine. I can't comment on the strengths and weaknesses of their technology is as only had a brief chat with him. They are about to enter Phase 2 for overactive bladder using botulinum toxin (apparently the "protocol is currently being finalised"). The hope is that the delivery system will enhance efficacy, and provide longer duration of action. The trial will be done under a grant received by the University of Ostrava Medical Center, Czech Republic, and plan to buy Allergan's Botox from pharmacies prior to formulating it in their system (which as you will appreciated doesn't sound ideal from a CMC perspective). They do not currently have a relationship with Allergan (so could use Dysport instead), although you should note that Allergan had a heavy presence at the conference (CEO, VP Pharm Dev, and bus. dev. were present), so I expect they made contact with them.
Best regards,
Andy

item.title: re: Shire Buys Swedish Neonatal Specialist Premacure To Access IGF-1 For ROP
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Shire Buys Swedish Neonatal Specialist Premacure To Access IGF-1 For ROP 
Comment: Shire has purchased Swedish biotech company Premacure for an indisclosed sum with the intention of continuing to develop its insulin-like growth factor to treat retinopathy or prematurity currently in phII development.  ...
In response to yesterday's article Sandra Blethen (US Medical Affairs) has noted that Tercica supported studies by Dr Lois Smith (of Harvard) for this indication. the data were promising, but there were some issues. The perception that IGF-1 was part of the process that led to diabetic retinopathy including the worsening of preexisting retinopathy in subjects with retinopathy enrolled in Genetech's studies of IGF-1 in diabetes. Interpretation of these data was complicated by the fact that retinopathy can worsen when a person with poorly controlled diabetes gets into good control. All of this leads to some questions: Did Premacure licence this indication from Dr Smith? How far along was their clinical development plan? Where do they plan to get the IGF-1?

item.title: Medivation Guidance on PREVAIL & New Registrational Trials In Earlier Treatment Settings
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: During the Barclay's Capital investor conference yesterday, Medivation gave a little more guidance on its expectations regarding the unblinding of the PREVAIL pre-chemotherapy trial with XTANDI (enzalutamide) and emphatically stated its support for registration trials in the MO and hormone naive treatment settings.
In response to a question on PREVAIL Clarence Machado Chief Busines Officer made the following comments:-
"I think it's obviously a hugely important strategic decision when to conduct your interim analysis and you want to be able to do so on the basis of the most wholesome set of data that you have. So our approach with respect to PREVAIL is really the same as it was with respect to AFFIRM. We were able to see all of the data from Zytiga's post chemo study and use that in order to calculate the timing of our own interim analysis and show quite signficiant results."
"We plan to do the same thing for PREVAIL. We've seen the results of the 302 study. We've seen aspects in their data which were a little bit different than what one might have expected for example that the surivavl curves did not change until about 18 months into the study. This was a little bit odd and different to what was seen in in 301. So we've taken those factors on board and we;ve made our best guess as to the appropriate metrics to use."
"That being said, while we're not commenting on the likely timing, I think the kind of triangulation strategy that you are following is probably a helpful way to look at things. As you pointed out the Zytiga 302 study finished accuring patients in May 2010. They conducted their interim in December 2011, so 19,19 months after last paitent in."
"They had about 1,100 patients in the study versus 1700 in ours. So they had quite a bit less power, which would all else equal suggeste that we could look sooner than they did and still achieve comparable results. Remember we completed accrual in May 2012 so 18, 19 months for us would be December of this year."
"On the other hand, we would also expect to see longer survival in the treatment arm in our study than was the case with Zytiga 302, exactly as seen in AFFIRM versus the 301 study."
"How much longer? Obviously that's a question we'd all like to know the answer to. We won't until we get the results from the study. But all else equal that would push than 18-month timing a little bit further out. So it's a bit of a balacing act as you correctly pointed out."
With regard to strategy regarding earlier patient segments Machado also made some interesting comments:-
"Yes so obviously these are two huge growth drivers for the business moving forward. If you divide prostate into four large buckets , we've covered two of those with registrational studies (AFFIRM and PREVAIL). The two that we have not covered are the two that you mentioned, the non-metastatic CRPC and hormone-naive. We consider both of those to be very large, very significant commercial opportunities because there really is a multiplier effect."
"As you go earlier into the treatment algorithm, not only do the number of patients increase, but the time you would expect each patient to remain on treatment also increases... So M0 would be the next earliest and hormone naive would be the earliest of all. As we discussed in our earnings call a couple of weeks ago, we have approved a collaboration budget with Astellas in 2013 which includes funding for upstream development including registrational development. We consider it to be an absolutely vital corporate objective to extend the use of XTANDI as early in the treatment algorithm as we possibly can and with patents expiring in 2027 in the US and 2026 in Europe and Japan, it makes this a pretty compelling investment from a business perspective."
"The strategy about how to do this, I think is one that's going to be complex. As we mentioned, these are long, expensive studies, five to seven years duration about £150-$200m each. So they're decisions that have to be made carefully."
Source: www.medivation.com

item.title: Next Step of Galderma's Growth in the Aesthetic Area
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Nuvo Research Inc has announced the US launch of Pliagllis, an analgesic peelable cream, partnered with Galderma. The product's efficacy, safety, rapid onset of action and ease of use promise to greatly improve the experience of patients by providing analgesia while they are undergoing superficial dermatologic and cosmetic procedures.
Indication: local analgesia for superficial aesthetic procedures including dermal filler injection, pulsed dye laser therapy, facial laser resurfacing and laser-assisted tattoo removal.
MOA: Pliaglis uses Nuvo’s proprietary phase-changing technology to form a pliable peel on the skin when exposed to air.

item.title: Shire Buys Swedish Neonatal Specialist Premacure To Access IGF-1 For ROP
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Shire has purchased Swedish biotech company Premacure for an indisclosed sum with the intention of continuing to develop its insulin-like growth factor to treat retinopathy or prematurity currently in phII development.
Deal Terms
Although undisclosed terms are known to include an upfront followed by milestones contingent on clinical development and commercialisation.
Acquisition rational
The purchase of Premacure fits Shire's strategy of purchasing products for the treatment of rare diseases where it can potentially charge a high price.
Premacure owns exclusive worldwide rights to develop and commercialize Insulin-Like Growth Factor 1 (IGF-I) together with or without its natural binding protein, IGFBP-3, as a product for the “prevention of complications of preterm birth”.
Source: www.premacure.com - www.shire.com

Comments
In response to yesterday's article Sandra Blethen (US Medical Affairs) has noted that Tercica supported studies by Dr Lois Smith (of Harvard) for this indication. the data were promising, but there were some issues. The perception that IGF-1 was part of the process that led to diabetic retinopathy including the worsening of preexisting retinopathy in subjects with retinopathy enrolled in Genetech's studies of IGF-1 in diabetes. Interpretation of these data was complicated by the fact that retinopathy can worsen when a person with poorly controlled diabetes gets into good control. All of this leads to some questions: Did Premacure licence this indication from Dr Smith? How far along was their clinical development plan? Where do they plan to get the IGF-1?

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Eisai's New Strategic Plans for R&D and Marketing In and Outside Japan
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Eisai has announced a number of strategic organisational changes as it struggles to cope with loss of patent protection against its two top earners Aricept (donepezil) and Pariet/Aciphex (rabeprazole). A press conference on 7 March led by company president Haruo Naito was accompanied by a release on the firm's website, with a number of changes outlined. Eisai is targeting at least JPY100 billion in revenues growth from emerging markets within the next five years, with China set to be the biggest contributor with JPY65 billion. Key slides are provided below.
In terms of its domestic operations in Japan, the firm is to be divided into two units, an Integrated Community Unit focused on marketing Aricept, while the Oncology HHC unit will focus on developing Eisai's breast cancer drug Halaven (eribulin mesylate).
Intensive strategy, with 220 new medical representatives to be recruited across the Oncology and Integrated Community units.
The stated goal is to transform into a low-margin, high-volume model through a "new pricing policy, regional best partnership, and category mix model".
The plan is to use tiered pricing to maximise access to drugs in emerging markets.

item.title: Mini Review Involving the PI3K/Akt/mTOR Pathway in the Treatment of pNETs
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Financial support for medical edtorial assistance was provided by Novartis. The conclusion shows that recent studies support the rationale for combination treatment and dual/multi-targeted agents with the aim of targeting different components of the PI3K/Akt/mTOR pathway. The use of biomarkers for predicting disease outcome or defining patient subgroups that may benefit from new treatment options will facilitate improved disease management in patients with pNETs.
Link: http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0304383513001286

TPI3K/Akt/mTOR pathway inhibitors in the therapy of pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors

item.title: New Pasireotide Trial
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: ClinicalTrials.gov is listing a new 100 patient Novartis study which will allow access to pasireotide for patients benefiting from treatment in other Novartis sponsored trials. Patients will be followed-up for a period of 10 years and recruitment will start in May.
Interestingly, many of the eligible indication are not licensed at the current time apart from Cushing's Disease but are being evaluted in terms of pasireotide use e.g. neuroendocrine tumours, Dumping syndrome. Ectopic ACTH tumours, prostate cancer, melanoma negative for bRAF and melanoma negative for nRAS. Hence the study will enable those completing these trial to continue with the study drug if they have benefited from treatment and enable the collection of long-term safety data.
Secondly for the approved or potentially soon to be approved indication it may provide access to drug where reimbursement is an issue and finally there is probab ly an element of patient capture behind the studies strategic intent.
ClinicalTrials.gov Identifier:
NCT01794793

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Takeda Seeks Regulatory Approval For New Ulcerative Colitis Therapy
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Takeda has submitted an MAA to the EMA for vedolizumab to treat moderately to severely active ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease.
Takeda is currently planning to submit a BLA to the FDA for the compound for both indications this year.
Vedolizumab is a humanized mAb against integrin alpha (4) beta (7).
Source: takeda.com

Comments
FDA has accepted and granted Priority Review to a BLA from Takeda for vedolizumab to treat moderately to severely active ulcerative colitis (UC). The pharma expects a decision in 1Q14.
The agency also is reviewing vedolizumab to treat Crohn's disease under a standard review time frame. Takeda, which submitted a single BLA to FDA in June, said the agency chose to review the indications under different timelines.
Source: Biocentury

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Impax/GSK's Rytary Approval Still On Hold As FDA Continues To Scrutinise cGMP Violations
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The FDA has completed its re-inspection of Impax's Hayward manufacturing facility and still apprears to have some issues concerning cGMP violations. Impax is now stating that it plans for a 2014 launch of its extended release carbidopa/levadopa formulation Rytary.
At the end of its recent review the FDA issued a Form 483 with 12 observations, 3 of which were repear observation included in a 2011 warning letter about cGMP violations.
In January the FDA issued a complete response letter for an NDA for Rytary to treat idiopathic PD. According ot the company the agency is requiring a "satisfactory re-inspection" of the Hayward Facility something that may still be in question.
Impax has said it will respond to the FDA's recent observations within 15 days of the Form 482 receipt and has " has every intention of meeting the very high standards set by the FDA"
Source: impax.com

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: One Step Forward Another Step Back
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Dendreon's pathway forward is far from clear as on Friday its CEO indicated that Q1 consensus sales estimates were too high. The company had previously indicated that 1Q sales would be sequentially below Q4 sales but now the indication is that the decline is more significant.
Whilst the company is remaining positive about a return to growth after Q1 as a DTC campaign gets underway, the investment community appears to remain more sceptical with competitive forces from the new oral therapies Zytiga and Xtandi believed to be hampering growth.
FirstWord is indicating in its new report on the prostate cancer market that KOL sentiment to the drug is not positive and that many European KOLs are sceptical about whether European marketing authorisation will be forthcoming and if is whether the drug will actually be prescribed or reimbursed.
http://www.firstwordplus.com/therapy_trends_kol_insights_prostate_cancer_more_info_form.do;jsessionid=B3F6DF30F599CE523F2B113AF0E68B58

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Telormedix' TMX-101 to Enter in the Clinic for CIS in the Bladder
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The company has recruited the 1st patient in a Ph2 of TMX-101, a TLR-7 agonist. Full details of the trial design is provided below.
According to Neal D. Shore, M.D., the Medical Director of the Carolina Urologic Research Center and principal investigator in this trial ... “TMX-101 has already demonstrated a strong disease-modifying cytokine response in a clinical trial involving patients with non-muscle invasive bladder cancer (NMIBC). CIS is obviously a more aggressive cancer, but we do know that it responds well to immunotherapeutic interventions. We are therefore extremely hopeful that targeting TLR-7 with TMX-101 will prove to be a successful and efficacious treatment option in these patients.”
- Drug Description: TMX-101 is a new formulation of Imiquimod optimized for intravesical delivery.
- Indication: TMX-101 is being developed as a potential treatment for patients with non-invasive bladder cancer, including patients with CIS bladder cancer.
- Recruitment: 6 CIS patients recruited from private urology clinics in the USA to examine the efficacy of the drug over six doses.
Oncology8710: Telormedix granted IND for Phase II Bladder Cancer Study.

item.title: Cancer Drugs to be Included on China's Revised EDL
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: While no specific date was given for the release of the EDL, China's minister of health, Chen Zhu confirmed that the list will be expanded to around 500 drugs, and contain oncology drugs, drugs for severe cardiovascular disease, nervous system conditions, psychotropic drugs, as well as blood plasma.
The Ministry of health has promised that the expanded EDL will be accompanied by reforms to the provincial tendering system that will place greater emphasis on quality of drugs rather than price alone, but it remains to be seen exactly how this will be effected.
Health officials have stated that the expanded EDL will play a more prominent role in China's grassroots healthcare institutions in the future, and they estimate that up to 40–50% of hospitals' total prescriptions will be for EDL drugs. This has led to further concerns particularly for local pharma firms that there could be an imbalance created in the market due to the growing importance of the EDL. On the positive side, local media speculate that the addition of oncology and other therapeutic areas to the EDL will probably be a catalyst for greater investment in research by Chinese firms hoping to develop drugs suitable for listing.
Source: Global Insight

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Key Messages from Merck Serono FY12 Results
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: During 2012, the Group realized around €115 million in net savings as a result of the restructuring initiative “Fit for 2018.” The majority of savings (~€ 100 million) were achieved in Merck Serono. The company reported first results of efficiency program now clearly visible in P&L.
Sales generated outside of Europe climbed to 58% in 2012 (2011: 54%), driven by the strong performance in North America, which reported an organic sales increase of 17% to € 1,335 million, and represented 22% of the division’s sales.
Sales in the Rest of World regions grew 12% organically to € 422 million while organic growth in the Emerging Markets grew by 6.8% and represented € 1,737 million of total sales for the division.
Challenging business conditions in Europe, impacted by lower pricing as well as healthcare budget cuts, resulted in a 2.1% organic decline in sales to € 2,502 million.

item.title: Key Messages from Acino's FY12 Results
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Alongside the presentation of the financial results, J-D Bonny (Head of R&D) reported further strengthening of the "implant platform". He highlighted a US-FDA agreement regarding harmonized clinical study design for US and EU. Of note, the progression to Ph1 of Goserelin implant in Japan (prostate and mamma carcinoma), and the estimated approval dates of of Leuprorelin 1M/3M in the US (Q4 16 and Q1 17 respectively). While Gosacin(R) (Goserelin) has been listed in Acino's BTC (direct marketing under the own brand "Acino Switzerland"), Leuprorelin is intended to be out-licensed.
Number of Acino's own projects increased to28 from 20 (in 2011).
Group revenue increased by 91% to €257.1M (vs €134.9M in 2011).
CEO strongly focused on Acino providing high quality products, hence more expensive "to merit the Swiss made brand/label".
Acino intends to grow its BtC business (products for international markets) through additional product launches (from own development and in-licensing) and by expanding the geographic reach.

In numerous markets in the MENA region and in Asia, local registration of new Acino products and preparations for market entry are progressing. The geographic expansion went one step further with the new cooperation between Acino and Medial D&P Ltd. (DKPHybrids203: Acino Expands its Business in the CIS Region).

In the attempt to fuel future growth and to escape price pressure in the European markets, the out-licensing activities have been stepped up to cover all regions worldwide.

A cooperation agreement with a Japanese company and licensing deals with partners in China and India are in negotiation.

Further territorial expansion in 2013 is anticipated in Asia and Latin America (BtC).

Discussions ongoing in China, 'long, but promising outcomes by 2015".
CEO highlighted that Acino is "resistant" and "preemptive". He confirmed the antibiotics business, "loss making business" is now out. Pipeline for the BtB business is "very solid and promising".

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Prana To Highlight Positive Impact of PBT434 On Key Protein Linked To Parkinson's Disease
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Prana has announced that key data on PBT434 will be presented at an upcoming meeting showing that PBT434 reduces the aggregation and accumulation of alpha synuclein, a protein that aggregates in the substantia nigra in Parkinson's disease.
In three different Parkinson Disease animal models, Prana has demonstrated that PBT434 significantly prevents the death of substantia nigra cells. Moreover, marked improvements in motor function and co-ordination were also seen.
The data is to be presented at the upcoming conference on Alzheimer's and Parkinson Disease in Florence 6th-10th March in a talk entitled " The role of nitrated TAU in PD"
Source: www.pranabiotech.com

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: EC Backing For $187m Funding For Rare Diseases
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: A few days ago the European Commission mapped out a plan to help spur development of 200 new treatments for rare diseases by the year 2020. It plans to commit $187 million for 26 research projects.

The research initiative aims to bring together some 300 investigators--academics, biotech and pharma investigators--from 29 countries to work on new treatments related to cardiovascular disease, acute liver failure, rare kidney disease and more. And it adds to a series of initiatives that now account for 100 projects and about $650 million in EC financing.

"Most rare diseases affect children and most of them are devastating genetic disorders resulting in greatly reduced quality of life and premature death," said Máire Geoghegan-Quinn, the EU Commissioner for Research, Innovation and Science, in a statement. "We hope that these new research projects will bring patients, their families and health professionals closer to a cure and support them in their daily battle with disease."


The new projects will bring the number of EU-funded collaborative research projects related to rare diseases to close to 100 over the last six years, representing a total investment of almost 500 million euros.

- In late January, the EU announced new funding of 38 million euros, under the IRDiRC, for research towards new treatments and the development of a central global rare-disease hub involving 70 institutions that will allow scientists to share data from their genomics research projects.

The four projects, which will receive the funding over the next six years, are for the following international collaborations:
- EURenOMICS, led by Heidelberg University Medical Centre, Germany, to identify the genetic and epigenetic causes of rare kidney disorders;
- Neuromics, led by the University of Tubingen, Germany, to address rare neurodegenerative and neuromuscular disorders using next-generation whole-exome sequencing;
- RD-Connect, led by Newcastle University, UK, to develop a global infrastructure to share the research or rare disease projects; and
- SUPPORT-IRDiRC, led by INSERM, France, to support international rare-disease collaboration through IRDiRC.

Source: http://europa.eu/rapid/press-release_MEMO-13-148_en.htm?locale=en

item.title: PROLOR Reinforces hGH Patent Portfolio
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The company has received a notice of allowance from the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office for a new patent application covering the company's long-acting CTP-enhanced human growth hormone (hGH-CTP). Upon issuance, the new patent will provide PROLOR with additional intellectual property protection that covers methods for decreasing body fat in humans through the use of hGH-CTP therapy.
Ph3 trials in AGHD is expected to debute later 2013.
Ph2 trials in PGHD is currently ongoing.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Silence's ATU027 to be Tested in Pancreatic Cancer
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Silence Therapeutics has received formal approval from the German authorities (BfArM) for its phase 1b/2a combination trial into pancreatic cancer. The trial will test Silence's Atu027 in combination with Gemcitabine. ATU027 is now the most advanced RNAi Oncology program in the world.
It is expected that the 1b element of the trial will last for 3 months and the 2a element scheduled to begin in July 2013 and ending approximately in July 2014.
BfArM has also encouraged Silence, primarily due to the exceptional safety profile of ATU027 in phase 1, to apply for 1b/2a trials using Atu-027 as a combination therapy across a wide range of cancers. It indicated that these further trials could be run broadly in parallel with pancreatic cancer.
Silence Therapeutics is the only company worldwide who can effectively deliver siRNAs to multiple locations in the human body.
Together with the strong patent position in its' synthetic siRNA, AtuRNAi, Silence Therapeutics is amongst a handful of companies who have the freedom to operate in this space

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Positive PhI Data With New Pump Patch Liquid PD Formulation
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Neuroderm announced yesterday positive results from a phI PK trial with ND0612, a proprietary levodopa/cabidopa liquid formulation administered subcutaneously through a patch pump.
In a double-blind placeob controlled dose-escalation trial in yound healthy volunteers ND-612 was shown to be safe and tolerable in all of the tested doses.
Importantly, clinically meaningful levodopa concentrations were reached and for the first time in man, steady state levodopa concentration were maintained both day and night (the elusive holy grail of PD levodopa therapy).
Traditionally levodopa and carbidopa are administered orally and suffer from an unfavourable PK profile due to low bioavailability.
Source: neuromed.com

item.title: Calypso Biotech to be the Sixth Spin-Off Company of Merck Serono
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The new formed Calypso Biotech will continue R&D of preclinical antibody programs from Merck Serono in the field of gastrointestinal immunological disorders.
- Merck Serono will invest €2.5M as seed funding
- Co-Founders: Drs. Yolande Chvatchko and Alain Vicari, two seasoned immunologists with strong experience in team management and drug discovery expertise.

Inclusion Criteria

  • diagnosis of moderate to severe primary axillary hyperhidrosis
  • ≥50 mg of sweat production/axilla in 5 minutes as measured gravimetrically
  • HDSS score of ≥3
Completion date: Aug. 2013

item.title: Key Messages from Medivation Q4 and FY12 Results
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Net sales of XTANDI reached approx. $71M in the US for the FY 2012 thanks to the expanded access program (EAP), and the accelerated approval of the drug. Management commentary suggested limited use of Xtandi in the pre-chemo setting as "the indication is in post chemo and that's what we're promoting".
Medivation gave metrics on the launch for the first time, noting that 9,300 prescriptions were written by 1,600 individual prescribers from 300 accounts in 2012.
The 9,300 Rx in 17 weeks compares favorably to Zytiga's 10,200 prescriptions in its first 17 weeks on the market.
Oncologists wrote 98% of Xtandi scripts, with the remaining 2% written by urologists
Management reported that " ... we currently have 60 sales representatives throughout the United States. 150 total including the effort with Astellas and we are calling on urologists and oncologists. We're currently right now targeting close to 9,000 physicians. A majority of them, of course, are oncologists, and 2,000 of them are urologists".
(*Reminder: TERRAIN is enrolling metastatic patients and is being conducted primarily in Europe STRIVE will enroll both metastatic and non-metastatic patients and be conducted primarily in the United States. Both TERRAIN and STRIVE are randomized, double-blind trials of enzalutamide head-to-head against bicalutamide, with a primary endpoint of progression-free survival).
Management oulined that " ... Astellas is operationalizing the TERRAIN trial, and we'll be giving guidance on that. Our trial, which is the STRIVE trial in the US, has only recently begun enrollment. We haven't given guidance on either trial as about when the data will be available".
Questionned on if data are expected this year, P Machado answered " ... We've not guided on PREVAIL. I think we've consistently explained that at this point we're very focused on competition, and we want to keep those cards very close to our vest because we think those data are going to put us in a very strong position competitively. And that it's best for the business to keep that to -- keep that to ourselves".
It was indicated that the company is "continuing to enroll patients in our Phase 1 study evaluating the safety and tolerability of enzalutamide in breast cancer. The study includes a dose escalation stage followed by an expansion where women with estrogen receptive positive breast cancer will be enrolled. If the safety data are acceptable, our next step would be to advance into Phase 2 development".

item.title: Key Messages from Bayer Investor Conference Call
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Bayer increased sales organically by 5% to almost €40 billion for 2012. Sales growth at pharma was driven by business expansion in North America and China(+23%). Management expects its healthcare unit, with prescription, OTC and animal health drugs to see sales grow by 6% per year to €22 billion by 2015 (ex currency swings and portfolio changes). Regarding Alpharadin new trials, management reported they will 'go into patients in earlier stages of disease, do combination trials, and look at additional tumours such as breast and osteosarcoma around year end".
- Q4:12
- FY2012

item.title: re: Roche Acquires Rights To Octreolin in $595m Deal
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Roche Acquires Rights To Octreolin in $595m Deal 
Comment: Roche has entered into an agreement with Chiasma to develop and commercialise its proprietary oral octreotide formulation Octreolin for the treatment of acromegaly and NET. The product is currently in phIII development for the treatment of acromegaly only.  ...
You will find the full list of participating centers (as well as their recruitment status and names of PI) of the phase III study, following the link: http://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/study/NCT01412424?term=Chiasma&rank=1&show_locs=Y#locn
You can see that out of the 14 countries involved, 12 are active (i.e. all except the US and Slovenia): Germany, Hungary, Israel, Italy, Lithuania, Mexico, Netherlands, Poland, Romania, Serbia, Slovakia, United Kingdom.
The phase III trial “Efficacy and Safety of Oral Octreolin in Patients With Acromegaly Who Are Currently Receiving Parenteral Somatostatin Analogs” is enrolling 150 patients. We can’t have access to the split per country / center.
Treatment duration is 7 months, and estimated completion date is October 2013.
Inclusion criteria are: Subjects with acromegaly defined as documented evidence of GH-secreting pituitary tumor that is abnormally responsive to glucose who is currently receiving a somatostatin analog.
Do not hesitate to post comments on Traction related to this trial, e.g. recruitment status, investigators’ or nurses’ feed-back, communication plan, …
Each and every information gathered will be very useful to feed the Octreolin war game planned this year.

item.title: Trophos's Pivotal SMA Study Gets Positive DMC Review
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Trophos SA, a French clinical stage pharmaceutical company developing therapeutics for under-served medical needs in neurology, has announced the completion of the interim analysis of the pivotal efficacy study of olesoxime in Spinal Muscular Atrophy (SMA).
DMC Recommends Pivotal Study Should Continue

The independent Data Monitoring Committee has reviewed the treatment effect at one year on the primary outcome measure of efficacy, change in motor function using the MFM scale, together with the latest safety report including electrocardiogram traces, periodic laboratory findings, haemostatic parameters and serious adverse events listings for all participants. Based on the trial stopping criteria as defined in the protocol as well as no safety concerns related to olesoxime treatment, their recommendation is to continue the study as planned.
An interim analysis of efficacy, as included in the study protocol, has been conducted after all participants have been treated for one year. Over 160 patients have been recruited into the trial between October 2010 and September 2011.
Next Steps & Timeline
Following the recommendations of the DMC, the study will continue until all participants have been treated for two years with the last patient out scheduled for September 2013. Top line results are expected by the end of 2013.
The trial is substantially funded by Trophos' partnership with the Association Francaise contre les Myopathies (AFM-Telethon) The trial protocol has benefited from the EMA protocol advice procedure.
Source: www.trophos.com

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Key Takeaways from Valeant Q4 and FY12 Results
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The company reported that it is continuing to see synergies emerging from the Medicis acquisition and that it is currently pursuing legal and R&D cost synergies. In terms of Dysport and what management is seeing with Merz having reentered the market, it was reported that 'Merz is obviously a very good company and is out marketing their product and our gang continues to be aggressive. What's interesting, in terms of toxins, it competes more directly with Botox than our product. Our product has some different attributes. So it's more of a competition between Allergan and Merz in terms of the toxin'.
This year, Valeant is expecting two key product candidate approvals - efinaconazole in May 2013 and luliconazole in December 2013.
Valeant indicated that it is now the fastest-growing pharmaceutical company in Poland, achieving 3% growth in 2012 while the overall Polish market shrank 6%.
In Asia, the firm delivered 20% growth as measured in local currencies.
The neurology division delivered positive growth in 4Q 2012, after six consecutive quarters of declines.
Valeant's Mexican division and the firm's main dermatology brands all achieved double-digit percentage growth in 2012.
Valeant did not update 2013E guidance in the press release. Management expects to do so on its Q1 2013 conference call (likely early March).

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Mylan To Acquire Stride's Injectable Business Agila For $1.6bn In Cash
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: After a tightly fought battle, Mylan has eclipsed Pfizer and others as the buyer of Agila an Indian Specialty Injectable business propelling Mylan to one of the top 3 players in the hospital injectable market and strenthening its capabilities in terms of injectable microspheres and gel forming implants.
Commenting on the acquisition Rajiv Malik President of Mylan noted:-

"Leading up to this acquisition, Mylan has made significant progress building our injectables platform to various activities, including the acquisition of Merck KGaA's generics business, our Bioniche acquisition and our recent manufacturing expansion through the facility acquisition from SMS, in addition to our biologics and recently announced insulin analog collaborations, both with Biocon."

"We believe that the acquisition of Agila helps to fill significant gaps in our injectables business in terms of contracting capacity and technical capabilities. With the injectables market expected to grow at a compound annual growth rate of 13% from 2011 to 2017, outpacing most other dosage forms, addressing these gaps was strategically important.... with this acquisition, we will meaningfully accelerate achievement of our target to create $1 billion institutional franchise."

"Agila has an impressive global portfolio and a track record of successfully developing, filing and receiving approval for injectable products, driven by their best-in-class R&D platform. In fact, Agila is far and away the market leader in terms of ANDA approval over the last five years and its approval times that FDA have run well ahead of injectables industry average. Agila has a strong pipeline of 349 applications pending approval in addition to 307 global regulatory approvals already received."

"We expect to even further bolster this R&D output as we integrate Agila. Agila will bring us approximately an additional 350 scientists focused on injectables complementing the strong team we already have in place. Together, we'll have comprehensive capabilities across vials, pre-filled syringes, ampoules, lyophilization, mini bags, cytotoxics and antibiotics. This transaction also will make Mylan a significant player in advanced new technologies of the future, such as microspheres, liposome, nano-suspensions and gel-forming implants. "

item.title: The Toxin Therapeutic Therapy Area Landscape
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: As part of our ongoing commitment to the recently launched CI/SIS Therapy Area Landscape Service, you will find attached an overview of the competitive landscape in the botulinum toxin therapeutic area.
This document has been created with collaborative input from the Franchise and we hope that you will find it a useful tool. We encourage you to contribute to our internal knowledge of this therapy area by evaluating some of the Key Intelligence Topics included in the slide kit. However, no matter what competitive information you have, please do keep us informed of any key developments in your countries. In this manner we can look to build on our internal knowledge base and together leverage the utility of the tool for everybody's benefit.

Comments
Dear Jackie,
Thanks for this. I will examine closer and add comments if possible. At first glance It is very useful. Gavin Assauw
Dear Jackie, there is one company I recently came across of relevance to this - Theracoat (theracoat.com/). I briefly met their VP Business Development at the Drug Delivery Partnerships conference. They have a novel hydrogel polymer that gels when it reaches body temperature. They are using it to increase retention time and control release of drugs in cavities - focussing on the bladder.
The polymer is not absorbed and eventually passes out in the urine. I can't comment on the strengths and weaknesses of their technology is as only had a brief chat with him. They are about to enter Phase 2 for overactive bladder using botulinum toxin (apparently the "protocol is currently being finalised"). The hope is that the delivery system will enhance efficacy, and provide longer duration of action. The trial will be done under a grant received by the University of Ostrava Medical Center, Czech Republic, and plan to buy Allergan's Botox from pharmacies prior to formulating it in their system (which as you will appreciated doesn't sound ideal from a CMC perspective). They do not currently have a relationship with Allergan (so could use Dysport instead), although you should note that Allergan had a heavy presence at the conference (CEO, VP Pharm Dev, and bus. dev. were present), so I expect they made contact with them.
Best regards,
Andy

item.title: BETMIGA (mirabegron) Available in the UK for OAB
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Mirabegron is now available via prescription in the UK. It will become available throughout Europe as part of a phased launch plan.
Mirabegron is a once daily oral β3-adrenoceptor agonist discovered and developed by Astellas. It is the first compound licensed in this new class of treatment for OAB, using a distinct mechanism of action compared to antimuscarinics.
Oncology8718: Astellas Strengthens its UroOnco Position with EU Approval of Mirabegron for OAB

item.title: Dendreon Q4 Figures Beat Street Estimates With Q4 PROVENGE Revenues of $85.5m
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The good news was accompanied by not such good news in that Dendreon is pointing to a decline in Q113 sales relative to Q412. Drivers of this fall appear mutli-faceted and include a seasonal slowdown in enrollment, Superstorm Sandy, sales vacancies, new competition and traditional Q1 seasonality for high-price infusion products.
Progress continues to be made on the expense side, with the expectation that COGS will be <50% revenue by Q313 but breakeven increases to $105m due to planned incremental spend on DTC advertising, scheduled to begin in Q213.
Patient Flow
Analysts are still wiating to see an inflection in the number of patients per account before recommending the shares. 61 new accounts were added in Q412 which represents a sequential 8% increase. However, the number of patients per account continues to decline (see chart below) albeit at a slower rate that in the previous two quarters.
Key Account Growth
Management noted that the community setting oncology accounts now represent 43% of the total buisiness whilst urology accounted for 28%. Whilst adding new accounts is important it emphasised that the focus remains on penetrating existing accounts. It claims that it has seen many accounts ramp up and, in fact, has one account that is now treating more than 30 patients per quarter for the last six months.
New Sequencing Data
Management also highlighted data at ASCO (Zytiga sequencing data) and claimed that feedback on the sequencing data was very positive as it begins to remove some concerns around how quickly patients can move to Zytiga post PROVENGE therapy. The impact on Provenge sales has yet to be seen. Xtandi sequencing (simiilar design to the Zytiga sequencing trial) and pre-metastatic screening trials are in planning.
Source: www.dendreon.com

item.title: re: Confirmatory Ph3 of Hugel's BoTXA for Essential Blepharospasm (EB) Has Completed in Korea
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
re: Confirmatory Ph3 of Hugel's BoTXA for Essential Blepharospasm (EB) Has Completed in Korea 
Botulax seems to already have blepharospasm as the registered indication. This Phase 3 would reinforce the dossier? 
I found a study in clintrialtrials.gov run in EB NCT01791881 which is a confirmatory Phase 3. Endpoints and duration of the trial would likely not support registration in the USA when compared to the recent approval of Xeomin in this country.
Their strategy is maybe to gain registration in Latin America?

An an SEC filing, Allergan said that the executive made $2.1M, including the stock award, $1.3M in salary, an almost $1.7M cash bonus and $7M in options awards.

item.title: Two Ph3 of Botox® Have Started in Japan for Aesthetic Indications
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Clinicaltrials.gov is listing two new Ph3 trials assessing Botox® in aesthetic indications in Japan. The trials will test the efficacy/safety of different dosages (12U/24U and 32U/44U). PE will assess the severity of CFLs at maximum smile using the facial wrinkle scale. Both trials will recruit a total of approx. 400 participants. Additional details are provided below.

The objective of the 4-arm randomized-controlled trial is to evaluate the safety and efficacy of Botox® (12U / 24U) compared to placebo in approx 300 men and women with moderate to severe Crow's Feet Lines (CFLs).
Start date: Jan 2013
Completion dates: Feb 2014 - March 2015
The objective of the 2-arm randomized-controlled trial is to evaluate the safety and efficacy of Botox® (32U / 44U) in approx 100 men and women with upper facial lines (Crow's Feet Lines and Frown Lines).
Start date: Feb 2013
Completion dates: Feb 2014 - March 2015

item.content:encoded:
Roche Acquires Rights To Octreolin in $595m Deal 
Comment: Roche has entered into an agreement with Chiasma to develop and commercialise its proprietary oral octreotide formulation Octreolin for the treatment of acromegaly and NET. The product is currently in phIII development for the treatment of acromegaly only.  ...
Thanks to Kate Higgs (UK Medical Advisor) and a conversation she had with a UK endocrinologist participating in the Octreolin trial, we have learnt that Chiasma has been suggesting that the price of Octreolin should be higher than injectable therapy because of the "benefits" of oral administration. This comment was not well received by the endocrinologist who perceived that such a price would cause funding and reimbursement issues.
The cost of goods associated with an oral therapy has always raised the possibility that the price of Octreolin would not be that low since the quantity of API required to achieve an acceptable level of bioavailability is 200x the dose needed for injectable therapy.
In addition to comments on price, the need for gastric acidity for the drug to be absorbed (i.e. it has to be taken on an empty stomach) and difficulties with co-administration with PPIs was also acknowledged but patients that have been treated with the drug have been positive about it.

item.title: Exelixis Expects Top-Line Post Chemt CRPC Data In 2014
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Alongside yesterday's earnings figures, Exelixis announced that it has entered into a 3-year agreement with Swedish Orphan Biovitrum to commercialise Cabozantanib for medullary thyroid cancer in Europe.
No other indication is covered by the agreement, andExelixismaintains full commercial rights for COMETRIQ in MTC outside the covered territory and for all other indications on a global basis.
On November 29, 2012, Exelixisannounced that the EMA had accepted for review the MAA for COMETRIQ for the proposed indication of treatment of progressive, unresectable, locally advanced, or metastatic MTC.
Deal Terms
Exelixis will continue to be responsible for regulatory approvals in the covered territory whilst Sobi will serve as the exclusive distributor of COMETRIQ in the covered territory
Exelixis’ payments to Sobi include certain pre-determined fixed fees as well as potential performance based milestones related to the commercialization of the product in the covered territory.
Exelixis will book revenues based on product sold to Sobi.Exelixishas the ability to terminate the agreement at will at any time upon payment of certain pre-determined fees.
Group Fourth Quarter & F/Y Financial Results
Revenue for the quarter was $7.8m and $47.5m for the full year (lower than 2011 as a result of the wind-down of several collaborations). Fourth quarter figures did not include any revenue for COMETRIQ as shipments only started in late January 2013.
R&D expenses were $32.5 million for the quarter and $128.9m for the full year (down 18% for the full year reflecting the completion of the EXAM study in medullary thyroid).
The group ended the year with $634m in cash.
Progress With Clinical Development of Cabozantinib
The two COMET trials in CRPC patients are progressing well with patient receruitment and enrollment in line with expectations. Top-line data from both trials is expected in 2014. COMET-1 end point is focused on overall survival whilst COMET-2 is on pain reduction.
Plans are also advanceing to evaluate cabozantinib in an earlier line of therapy of CRPC patients prior to chemotherapy. It is working on the design of two phI/II studies; one evaluating the combination of cabozantinib with enzalutamide and one evaluating the combination of cabozantinib with abiraterone. These trials should start in 2H2013.
Beyond prostate the key priorities are the initiation of two planned phIII trials in RCC and HCC. Both trials are expected to commence in Q32013.
The phIII RCC trial is being initiated based on the very promising data presented at ASCO in 2012 which demonstrated at PFS in heavily pretreated patients of 14.7 months a figure which vastly exceeds that previously reported. The study will compare cabozantinib against everolimus in patients who have received and progressed on one VEGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitor. PE will be PFS.
The trial will include 664 patients has been powered based on the assumption of seeing a 5 month median PFS with everolimmus versus 7.5 months with cabozantinib (i.e. a HR of 0.67). For the secondary endpoint of OS it is assumed that a 15 month OS will be seen with the everolimus arm and 20 months with cabozantinib.
The phIII HCC trial, by contrast, will be against placebo and conucted in 760 patients with advanced HCC across 200 sites. Patients may have up to two prior systemic therapies and one of them must have been sorafenib. The PE of the trial will be overall survival.
In addition to the above Exelixis has 20 ongoing or planned investigator sponsored studies and 13 studie under the IND associated with the CTEP programme.
Source: www.exelixis.com

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Key Takeaways From Lexicon's Q4 and F12 Results
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Lexicon has 5 clinical candidates in Ph2 and Ph3 development and all have shown initial human proofof- concept efficacy in Ph2. Management started by reporting that 2012 was dominated by the positive results of its Ph2b trial of LX4211 (type 2 diabetes), and the initiation of the first Ph3 with LX1032 (telotristat etiprate) in carcinoid syndrome (data unlikely before H2:14 at the earliest). Lexicon is exploring alternative indications for LX-2931 given the evolving RA competitive landscape, and is reformulating LX-7101 (glaucoma).
Management reported it is on track 'to initiate Ph3 with a corporate partner in 2013.' ' ... we are looking for a partnership where we think we can fund the program out of the partnership, and so that is something that we -- that is one of the objectives that we're seeking. And we do want to have a significant level of involvement in the program as well, but those are some of the objectives that we have for that partnership process'.
- study ongoing in 20 patients with type 2 diabetes and moderate renal impairment with results planned for H1:13.
- combination with insulin for type 1 diabetes: 33 patients planned for recruitment. 28-day study. Results expected Q4:13.
Ulcerative Colitis
Ongoing Ph2: recruitment of approx 60 patients with mild to moderate UC to be complete in Q2:13.
Carcinoid Syndrome
Design of the Ph3: single pivotal study with 12 wks of placebo control and then after have patients in open label extension. Dosage: placebo 250mg 3 times daily of telotristat, and 500mg 3 times daily of telotristat - Recruitment: approx 150 Sites: in process of getting sites (EU; US; Australia).
Management indicated they have planned to 'complete enrollment by Q2 of 2014, and if we're able to achieve that, then we should have results towards Q3 or Q4 of 2014. That's an aggressive goal, we think we can do it. That's why we're pushing hard on site initiations and enrollment."
Analysts Views
Morgan Stanley 'see the commercial opportunity as relatively limited given a small carcinoid syndrome population, relatively well treated with generic octreotide'.
Wedbush Securities 'estimate LX1032 for carcinoid syndrome may be launched in 2015 with gross sales reaching over $400 million in 2020'.
A 360 patient Ph2 study - Fast-track status from the FDA. Trial completion anticipated in Q3:13. PE to assess stool consistency, and combined endpoint with abdominal pain.
The target of LX7101 is a kinase regulating IOP--LIM domain kinase 2 (LIMK2). The goal for LX7101 is to become a once daily eye drop with a novel mechanism complementary to many marketed treatments for glaucoma. The target of LX7101 is a kinase that is responsible for regulating intraocular pressure. LX7101 is intended to lower IOP by enhancing the fluid outflow facility of the eye. The goal of the LX7101 program is to develop a once-daily eye drop that lowers IOP by increasing the fluid outflow facility in the eye, a novel mechanism not currently addressed by approved products for glaucoma.
The company filed an IND in Q4:11 and shortly afterwards initiated a Phase 1/2 proof-of-concept, first-in-man study to test safety, tolerability, and efficacy.
In Q4/FY:12, Lexicon reported $0.2/$1.1 million in revenues and GAAP EPS (loss) of $(0.05)/$(0.23), respectively.
The company ended 2012 with about $223.2 million in cash.

item.title: re: Confirmatory Ph3 of Hugel's BoTXA for Essential Blepharospasm (EB) Has Completed in Korea
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
re: Confirmatory Ph3 of Hugel's BoTXA for Essential Blepharospasm (EB) Has Completed in Korea 
Botulax seems to already have blepharospasm as the registered indication. This Phase 3 would reinforce the dossier? 
Anne-Gaelle is right. As I check it out through KFDA, Hugel's botulinum Toxin A " Botulax " got BE approval as a registered indication from KFDA as of March 17, 2010.
There is no recent clinical study for EB completed these days.
However, Hugel has been doing phase III study for CP in Korea to add new indication since mid of 2012 and will finish within 2013.
