item.title: Companion Biomarker Partnership to Advance Therapeutic Development for Huntington's Disease
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: KineMed, Isis and CHDI will develop novel biomarkers for pre-clinical and clinical use in drug development and therapeutic monitoring. I
The collaboration will use KineMed's translational biomarker platform with Isis' antisense therapeutic program for Huntington's disease (HD). This collaboration, which builds on an earlier alliance between CHDI and KineMed to develop companion biomarkers of therapeutic response in HD, will provide Isis access to novel biomarkers for use in the development of an antisense drug to treat HD.
KineMed's neurodegeneration biomarker of axonal transport deficit has been recently published in the Journal of Clinical Investigation and validated in patients with other neurological disorders: (http://www.jci.org/articles/view/64575).

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Dana-Farber to Conduct Trial of Ziv-aflibercept + Octreotide LAR for Carcinoid Tumours
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Ziv-aflibercept (a VEGF Trap) has recently been approved for patients with treatment-resistant colorectal cancer. This Ph2 study will assess the combination to see if it slows the growth or spread of the disease. PE will assess PFS.
Recruitment: approx 43

Inclusion Criteria:

  • Histologically confirmed well differentiated or moderately differentiated neuroendocrine tumor from either a primary or metastatic site
  • Must have disease that is not amenable to curative resection
  • Must have evidence of disease progression within 12 months prior to study entry
  • Must have measurable disease (RECIST 1.1)
  • Prior chemoembolization of local ablative therapies are allowed, provided there is measurable disease outside of the area treated, or documented evidence of progression at the site of prior treatment
  • No limit to number of prior treatments. Prior bevacizumab allowed unless discontinued due to unacceptable toxicity. Prior TKI targeting VEGF receptors allowed
  • Treatment with a somatostatin analog required for all subjects
  • Subjects with history of hypertension must be adequately controlled
  • Therapeutic anticoagulation is allowed. Must be on a stable dose of anticoagulant medication
  • Must agree to use adequate contraception prior to study entry, for the duration of study participation and for 3 months after last administration of study drug.
Start date: March 2013 - Completion date: March 2015
Location: USA (3 sites)

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Novel Peptide Based Therapeutic Vaccine Has Entered Ph1/Ph2a for Prostate Cancer
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Ultimovacs' vaccine consists of a mix of peptides which are fragments of the enzyme telomerase expressed by cancer cells allowing them to divide endlessly. In this study, >21 patients with metastatic prostate cancer will receive UV1 at different dose levels. PE will assess safety and tolerability.

Inclusion Criteria:

  • Patients with advanced oligometastatic prostate cancer (PCa) without lung and/or liver metastases who are eligible to CAB (GnRH-agonist combined with anti-androgen)
  • Patients already on GnRH-agonist must have a history sPSA < 200 ng/mL prior to start of GnRH-agonist treatment. GnRH-agonist with or without bicalutamide can have been initiated up to 6 months prior inclusion.
  • Must be ambulatory with an ECOG performance status of 0 or 1 and not have contraindications for MRI (pacemaker, claustrophobia, metal splints).
  • Must be at least 18 years of age.
  • Must have lab values as follows:
    • White Blood Cells ≥ 1.5 x 109/L
    • Platelets ≥ 100 x 109/L
    • Hemoglobin ≥ 9g/dL (≥ 5.6 mmol/L)
    • Creatinine ≤ 140 µmol/L; if creatinine is borderline, the creatinine clearance ≥ 40 mL/min;
    • Bilirubin < 20% above the upper limit of normal
    • ASAT and ALAT ≤ 1.5 the upper limit of normal
    • Albumin ≥ 2.5 g/L
    • Normal NSE
    • sPSA < 200 ng/mL.
Start date Feb 2013 - Completion date: Jan 2015
Location: Oslo, Norway
PI: Wolfgang Lilleby, MD PhD Oslo U. Hospital

item.title: New Indications Approved for Botox in Italy
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Thanks to Patrizia Caglioni (PM), we have learnt that Botox has been approved for NDO and migraine. Allergan may increase the FTEs to 12/14 from 7 effective at the beginning of next month. Of note, Merz is recruiting Italian center(s) to conduct an international pivotal study on CP.
Marketing authorization for the medicinal product for human use "Botox." (13A01015) (OJ n. 35 of 11.02.2013 - Ordinary Suppl. 10) Retrieved determination no. 68/2013 of 23 January 2013
Reimbursement scheme and price as a result of new therapeutic indications for BOTOX (Botulinum Toxin Type A).
- Urinary incontinence in adults with neurogenic detrusor overactivity resulting from neurogenic bladder due to stable sub cervical spinal injury or to multiple sclerosis.
- Symptoms relief in adults fulfilling the diagnostic criteria for chronic migraine (headaches on ≥ 15 days per month of which at least 8 days with migraine) in patients who have responded inadequately response or are intolerant to prophylactic migraine medications.
Classification for reimbursement
Packaging: 100 units Allergan powder for solution injection »1 vial - M.A.H. n. 034883013 / M (in base 10) 118KG5 (Under 32) - Class of eligibility H.
Ex-factory price (excluding VAT) € 142.99.
Retail price (including VAT) € 235.99.

item.title: re: Confirmatory Ph3 of Hugel's BoTXA for Essential Blepharospasm (EB) Has Completed in Korea
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Confirmatory Ph3 of Hugel's BoTXA for Essential Blepharospasm (EB) Has Completed in Korea 
Comment: The objective of this trial was to compare the efficacy and safety of Hugel's botulinum toxin A against Botox in the treatment of EB, and to get a regulatory approval from KFDA.  ...
Its a relatively small study - I would'nt have thought they'd be enough patients to statistically show non-inferiority, therefore not sure if it has a regulatory purpose. A quick look at clintrial.gov showed anther Korean toxin did a similar thing with an even smaller study (60 patients - NCT00682760 KbtxA, Pacific Pharmaceuticals, Korea) - will check to see if LRA are aware of any sort of local requirement ?

item.content:encoded:
Confirmatory Ph3 of Hugel's BoTXA for Essential Blepharospasm (EB) Has Completed in Korea 
Comment: The objective of this trial was to compare the efficacy and safety of Hugel's botulinum toxin A against Botox in the treatment of EB, and to get a regulatory approval from KFDA.  ...
Botulax seems to already have blepharospasm as the registered indication. This Phase 3 would reinforce the dossier?


Comments
Anne-Gaelle is right. As I check it out through KFDA, Hugel's botulinum Toxin A " Botulax " got BE approval as a registered indication from KFDA as of March 17, 2010.
There is no recent clinical study for EB completed these days.
However, Hugel has been doing phase III study for CP in Korea to add new indication since mid of 2012 and will finish within 2013.
I found a study in clintrialtrials.gov run in EB NCT01791881 which is a confirmatory Phase 3. Endpoints and duration of the trial would likely not support registration in the USA when compared to the recent approval of Xeomin in this country.
Their strategy is maybe to gain registration in Latin America?

item.title: Confirmatory Ph3 of Hugel's BoTXA for Essential Blepharospasm (EB) Has Completed in Korea
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The objective of this trial was to compare the efficacy and safety of Hugel's botulinum toxin A against Botox in the treatment of EB, and to get a regulatory approval from KFDA.
Recruitment: approx 172
  • Adult between ages 18 and 75 years
  • All patients, diagnosed of essential blepharospasm, with Grade 2~4 of Severity of Spmasm (by Scott's Method).

Comments
Botulax seems to already have blepharospasm as the registered indication. This Phase 3 would reinforce the dossier?

Anne-Gaelle is right. As I check it out through KFDA, Hugel's botulinum Toxin A " Botulax " got BE approval as a registered indication from KFDA as of March 17, 2010.
There is no recent clinical study for EB completed these days.
However, Hugel has been doing phase III study for CP in Korea to add new indication since mid of 2012 and will finish within 2013.
I found a study in clintrialtrials.gov run in EB NCT01791881 which is a confirmatory Phase 3. Endpoints and duration of the trial would likely not support registration in the USA when compared to the recent approval of Xeomin in this country.
Their strategy is maybe to gain registration in Latin America?
Its a relatively small study - I would'nt have thought they'd be enough patients to statistically show non-inferiority, therefore not sure if it has a regulatory purpose. A quick look at clintrial.gov showed anther Korean toxin did a similar thing with an even smaller study (60 patients - NCT00682760 KbtxA, Pacific Pharmaceuticals, Korea) - will check to see if LRA are aware of any sort of local requirement ?

item.title: ASCO GU - Key Intelligence On Enzalutamide
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Enzalutimide
Impact of on-study corticosteroid use on efficacy and safety in the phase III AFFIRM study of enzalutamide
A growing body of evidence suggests that corticosteroids may stimulate prostate cancer growth. A variety of mechanisms have been proposed:
§ Activating promiscuous ARs
§ Stimulating human SGK1 gene expression
§ Promoting expression of IL-6
§ Activating GR signaling
As such, the investigators of the AFFIRM (post-chemo) study hypothesized that corticosteroid use may adversely affect survival.
An unplanned, post-hoc analysis exploring the relationship of corticosteroid use to survival and if potentially associated, whether patients still benefit from enzalutimde is detailed in the following slides.
In the P3 AFFIRM study, corticosteroids were permitted at entry but not required. Results showed a prolonged survival median of 4.8 months, translating into a 37% reduction in risk of death.
In the P3 AFFIRM trial, baseline corticosteroid use was associated with an inferior OS independent of study treatment
Corticosteroid use varied widely in AFFIRM from some pts receiving none at all, some pts came on at baseline and some added corticosteroids while on study.
In total, 30% of pts were on corticosteroids at study start and all patients had received corticosteroid along side first line docetaxel

The following slides detail the output from baseline use at study entry.

Statistical methods for the post-hoc analysis were applied
A number of factors were pre-specified to develop a multivariate model for the question
The multivariate analysis suggests that baseline corticosteroid use is an independent predictor of OS.
A summary of the post-hoc analysis of baseline corticosteroid use in AFFIRM is addressed below:
Next, the speaker reviewed the relation of baseline use as well as on study use of corticosteroids in relations to survival. These patients had corticosteroids added at some point during the study. 47% were on for 6+ months, 59% for 3+ months. Overall, this represents an increase of 16% of the patient population.
The frequency and type of corticosteroid used was similar between the two groups of which prednisone and dexamethasone were the most common. Pts who received corticosteroids were generally sicker and had more advanced disease.

Patients receiving corticosteroids had worse survival times and progressed more rapidly

Survival times, rPFS and time to PSA progression with enzalutimide were superior to placebo in both the no corticosteroid and corticosteroid treated groups
Use of corticosteroids on study was associated with more pts reporting grade 3-4 adverse events relative to the no corticosteroid group
To conclude:-

item.title: New Therapeutic Target in Prostate Cancer
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Dr Ramesh Narayanan (Director, Drug Discovery for GTx Inc) presented preclinical data indicating that AKR1C3, a steroidogenic enzyme, is an androgen receptor-selective coactivator and promoter of growth in prostate cancer cells and CRPC, and may present the 1st nuclear hormone receptor coactivator that can be pharmacologocally targeted in the treatment of advanced prostate cancer.
ASCO GU Presentation (Feb 14 2013) Abstract ID 100
CRPC may occur by several mechanisms, including up-regulation of the androgen receptor, coactivators and steroidogenic enzymes, including AKR1C3.
In vitro cellular and molecular biological techniques and novel AKR1C3-selective inhibitors developed by GTx facilitated the identification of AKR1C3 as a unique androgen receptor-selective coactivator that promotes prostate cancer growth.
Over expression of AKR1C3 promotes both androgen-dependent prostate cancer and CRPC growth with concomitant reactivation of androgen signaling in xenograft models.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Key Messages from GTx' Analyst Event
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The company reviewed data from previous and current Ph2 of Capesaris, and the next steps. Some questions arising in patients with CRPC and hormone sensitive prostate cancer were treated by Ph Kantoff, as well as where could GTx-758 fit in.
- Presented by Philip Kantoff, MD (Dana-Farber Cancer Institute Harvard Medical School).
Presented by Evan Yu, MD (Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research).
Details of the 710 and 705 studies
Focus on the 705
Capesaris data from earlier trials (at higher doses) showed statistically significant lower rates of hot flashes than Lupron, improved markers of bone turnover and lowered levels of IGF-1. At 1000 mg, the rate of hot flashes was 18.6%; at 2000 mg, it was 5.6%, compared to 80.9% of men receiving Lupron.
Similarly, men receiving the 1000 mg and 2000 mg doses of GTx-758 had C-terminal telopeptide declines of -56.9% and -54.8%, respectively, as compared with an increase of 46.0% in the men receiving Lupron.
Bone specific alkaline phosphatase levels were also lower in men treated with GTx-758, with mean percentage changes of-28.5% and -19.8%, in the treated arms, compared with an increase of 8.1% in the Luprontreated group.
Serum IGF-1 levels dropped by a mean of >50% in Capesaris-treated patients, while Lupron-treated patients saw IGF-1 levels stay the same or increase. All these indicators favor an improvement quality of life for patients receiving Capesaris compared to Lupron.
Presented by Thomas Flaig, MD U. of Colorado School of Medicine)

item.title: re: New Sequential Design Study In pNET
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
New Sequential Design Study In pNET 
Comment: Thanks to Eva Pineda, we were recently able to access a presentation given by Marianne Pavel to the VIII International GETNE Symposium. The slides interestingly refer to a new upcoming Novartis GETNE co-sponsored study looking at sequential chemo/mTOR therapy in a study callled SEQTOR.  ...
Combinability of drugs for the management of NET is indeed an open question and has also been considered at Ipsen with the SUNLAND study.
This european ESS is coordinated by GERCORupported by ENETS . It is fully granted by Ipsen and Pfizer through a global / european partnership between both companies aiming at joining both expertises in this dynamic field and trying to address to enroll more than 100 patients. The first 2 patients have been enrolled in January 2013.

item.title: New Trials with Aragon's ARN-509 for Prostate Cancer
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Aragon started two new combination trials this month. A Ph2 RCT to study the effects of 12 months of treatment with ARN-509 alone or in combination with an LHRH agonist in men with a rapidly rising serum PSA after prior definitive local therapy for prostate cancer. PE will assess mean change in QoL. A Ph1b open label trial to assess ARN-509 in combination with abiraterone + prednisone for mCRPC. PE will measure MTD.

Start date: Feb 2013 - Completion dates: Feb 2015 / Feb 2018

Recruitment: approx 90 men

Inclusion Criteria:

  • Histologically proven adenocarcinoma of the prostate
  • Rising PSA after prior definitive local therapy (radical prostatectomy, external beam radiation, or brachytherapy) or combination of radical prostatectomy and radiotherapy with curative intent
  • PSA doubling time less than or equal to 12 months
  • No evidence of metastatic disease by CT/MRI abdomen/pelvis and whole body bone scan
  • Minimum PSA 1.0 ng/mL if prior radical prostatectomy +/- adjuvant or salvage radiation; nadir + 2.0 ng/mL if prior RT without prior radical prostatectomy
  • No androgen deprivation therapy or anti-androgen (i.e. bicalutamide) within 12 months of study entry
  • No prior androgen deprivation therapy (ADT) or anti-androgen for biochemical relapse
  • Serum testosterone > 150 ng/dL at study entry
  • No history of seizures or medical conditions which may lower seizure threshold
Start date: Feb 2013 - Completion dates: Feb 2014
Recruitment: approx 21 men

Inclusion Criteria:

  • Participants must have histologically confirmed prostate cancer.
  • Radiographic evidence of metastatic disease, detectable by bone scan, CT scan, or MRI. At least one site of metastatic disease must be amenable to needle biopsy.
  • Castrate levels of testosterone (testosterone < 50 ng/dL) on androgen deprivation therapy (ADT). Patients who have not undergone orchiectomy will continue gonadotropin releasing hormone (GnRH) agonist or antagonist therapy.
  • Age > 18 years
  • ECOG performance status < 2
  • Evidence of disease progression on ADT. Patients must have two serial rises in PSA from nadir, with at least 1 week between PSA measurements, with a minimum PSA of 2 ng/mL, OR patients must have radiographic evidence of progression. Nadir is defined as the lowest PSA value after beginning the most recent therapy for metastatic CRPC.


Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Ghrelin Peptide Agonist to Enter POC Study for Constipation
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Clinicaltrials.gov is listing a new Ph2 RCT, sponsored by Rythm Pharm, to assess RM-31 for chronic constipation. PE will assess the effect of the drug on colonic transit.
Regimen/Dosage : RM-131 (100 ug) will be delivered subcutaneously once daily for 14 days.
Recruitment: approx 48
Location: USA
RM-131 was derived from the natural ghrelin sequence and optimized for the properties of stimulating GI motility, weight gain, and anti-inflammatory activity—with enhanced stability and pharmacokinetics.
Development Stage : RM-131 is in Ph2 clinical development for the treatment of diabetic gastroparesis.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Sanofi to Refocus R&D Strategy on the Biology of Diseases
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: As Novartis and Roche, Sanofi is shifting the company's focus toward disease biology to increase the quantity and quality of new drug discoveries.
Since becoming Sanofi's Head of R&D in 2011, Elias Zerhouni has reduced the company's late-stage portfolio of experimental drugs to ensure that only the most promising candidates are studied in clinical trials.
Sanofi plans to hire about 20 new R&D leaders.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Spain to Prepare New Drugs Reference Pricing Regulation
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The prospective decree is aimed at enhancing the stability of the national pharmaceutical system, encouraging fairer bidding practices for those companies wishing to sell drugs to the public healthcare system, and setting up fairer standards in relation to timeframes of payment from the government to companies involved in tendering in order to avoid the payment delays that occurred in 2011.
Spanish health minister Pilar Farjas has announced that the Ministry of Health (MoH) is working on implementing a new Royal Decree aimed at the regulation of the country's drug reference pricing system. According to Farjas, cited by Europa Press, the measure is expected to be "a key instrument for fairer market access to Spain and a necessary element to foster pharmaceutical cost containment".
At the XVI Farmaindustria Forum that took place this week in Zaragoza, Farjas asked the pharmaceutical sector to maintain its loyalty to the public healthcare system. According to the source, Farjas also stated that pharmaceutical companies doing business with Spain can trust the government in terms of repayment of debts contracted during the last two years as a "suppliers repayment plan" has been implemented under which the government has started paying off some debts in a bid to regain the trust of the industry. Farjas also pointed out that the government is working towards clearer pharmacovigilance and pharmaco-surveillance regulations to avoid counterfeiting and other illegal activity. This measure, together with the centralised drug purchase that was recently approved at the beginning of January, is expected to help the government save EUR1.5 billion (USD2 billion). No further details of when the regulation will come into force were disclosed.

Outlook and implications

The regulation, when implemented, would mark an essential step towards regulating the price of drugs in the country as well as creating stronger guarantees for wholesaler enterprises operating in Spain. The decree is aimed at enhancing the stability of the national pharmaceutical system, encouraging fairer bidding practices for those companies wishing to sell drugs to the public healthcare system, setting up fairer standards in relation to timeframes for payments from the government to companies involved in the tendering process, and avoiding the kinds of payment delays that occurred in 2011.
This new regulation is part of a wider wave of austerity measures that began in 2011 aimed at decreasing pharmaceutical expenditure in the country. Specifically, this regulation is aimed at avoiding unnecessary spending while tendering for drugs entering the public healthcare system, as reference pricing regulations in Spain have been historically unreliable, depending on a host of different variables. Therefore, the creation of a decree will benefit the pharmaceutical industry operating in the country as well as the government.
This measure, together with the recently approved centralised drug purchasing system, is expected to help the government with consistent savings. The centralisation of drug purchases is also part of a wider emergency financial plan aimed at cutting healthcare expenditure.
The laws on drug purchases approved at the end of December fulfill the aims of Royal Decree 16/2012 to guarantee the sustainability of the national health system, as well as improving drug supplies. The centralised purchase is expected to also benefit pharmaceutical companies tendering for drugs as the MoH has recently established a new payment system for those firms providing drugs for the public healthcare system, offering payment to the companies within a set time period and a contract of up to three years.
Source: GlobalInsight

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Roche Acquires Rights To Octreolin in $595m Deal
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Roche has entered into an agreement with Chiasma to develop and commercialise its proprietary oral octreotide formulation Octreolin for the treatment of acromegaly and NET. The product is currently in phIII development for the treatment of acromegaly only.
Deal Terms
Under the terms of the agreement, Roche receives a W/W exclusive license to Octreolin, and will assume responsibility for the commercialization of Octreolin.The arrangement includes an upfront payment to Chiasma of $65 million, future considerations of up to $530 million in development and commercial milestones, as well as tiered, double-digit royalties on Octreolin net sales.
  • Genentech will market the product in the United States after US FDA approval.
  • Chiasma will continue development through completion of the pivotal phase 3 clinical trial for acromegaly.
  • The arrangement includes an upfront payment to Chiasma of $65 million, future considerations of up to $530 million in development and commercial milestones, as well as tiered, double-digit royalties on Octreolin net sales.
Deal Rational
Roche is a large oncology player and probably views the NET therapy area as an attractive market in which to participate, however, hitherto it has no existing presence of previous experience of within this field.
It does have an existing presence within the Endocrinology market but only in the US through its growth hormone franchise (e.g. Nutropin).
There is currently ongoing a phIII study being undertaken by SWOG that is evaluating Avastin as a potential treatment for NET. If the results are positive (due mid 2013), it may provide a basis for Roche to file for approval and an entry point to the NET market.
Octreolin's Profile
Chiasma is a Biotech company without any commercial capabilities so it was always going to be in need of contact/partnership with a pharma company for commercialisation purposes.
Regarding Octreolin, we see this product as a twice daily oral treatment potentially for well controlled Acromegalics (see comments below).
The first phase I/II results on the drug were presented at the ENDO congresses 2011/2012. Highlighted was
Octreolin's low bio-availability due to the oral route of administration. Potentially this could create some issues for the product in the presence of food or drugs such as PPIs, and it raises some concerns regarding long term safety profile because of the large quantities of active drug substance that have to be administered to achieve a therapeutic concentration and therefore reach the portal circulation in the liver.
A phase III study is currently in place for Acromegaly with 40 participating sites in EU countries and Mexico. Chiasma claim that they will be able to use this unique study for registration in US despite the lack of participating centres in this country.
There is a possibilitiey that there may be a requirement for a futher study to address higher dose octreotide LAR patients and this could delay the registration process.
.
The target population for such drug appears as though it would be good responders to SSAs ( may be low dose patients 10-20 mg octreotide LAR). There is some preliminary indication that needs to be confirmed that higher dose octreotide LAR patients may not be adequately controlled by twice daily Octreolin dosing.
From a regulatory stand point, Octreolin has FDA Orphan drug status, and Chiasma will file utilising the 5O52B regulatory route (an abreviated filing process for follow-on products). In term of timelines, we assume that for Acromegaly , Octreolin could reach the EU market in Q1 2015, assuming that 1 study is sufficient for approval. Regarding the US timelines could be similar.
Chiasma claim that they want to develop Octreolin within NET area but no study has been initiated yet, pushing potential approval timelines out towards 2020.

Comments
Thanks to Kate Higgs (UK Medical Advisor) and a conversation she had with a UK endocrinologist participating in the Octreolin trial, we have learnt that Chiasma has been suggesting that the price of Octreolin should be higher than injectable therapy because of the "benefits" of oral administration. This comment was not well received by the endocrinologist who perceived that such a price would cause funding and reimbursement issues.
The cost of goods associated with an oral therapy has always raised the possibility that the price of Octreolin would not be that low since the quantity of API required to achieve an acceptable level of bioavailability is 200x the dose needed for injectable therapy.
In addition to comments on price, the need for gastric acidity for the drug to be absorbed (i.e. it has to be taken on an empty stomach) and difficulties with co-administration with PPIs was also acknowledged but patients that have been treated with the drug have been positive about it.
Very interesting info indeed.
The Octreolin trial involves a lot of patients with Acromegaly condition, leading to a significant loss of patients in our market places. Can we have the details of countries / centers per country / number of patients per country involved ? Can we estimate the duration for investigating these patients under octreoloin ?
You will find the full list of participating centers (as well as their recruitment status and names of PI) of the phase III study, following the link: http://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/study/NCT01412424?term=Chiasma&rank=1&show_locs=Y#locn
You can see that out of the 14 countries involved, 12 are active (i.e. all except the US and Slovenia): Germany, Hungary, Israel, Italy, Lithuania, Mexico, Netherlands, Poland, Romania, Serbia, Slovakia, United Kingdom.
The phase III trial “Efficacy and Safety of Oral Octreolin in Patients With Acromegaly Who Are Currently Receiving Parenteral Somatostatin Analogs” is enrolling 150 patients. We can’t have access to the split per country / center.
Treatment duration is 7 months, and estimated completion date is October 2013.
Inclusion criteria are: Subjects with acromegaly defined as documented evidence of GH-secreting pituitary tumor that is abnormally responsive to glucose who is currently receiving a somatostatin analog.
Do not hesitate to post comments on Traction related to this trial, e.g. recruitment status, investigators’ or nurses’ feed-back, communication plan, …
Each and every information gathered will be very useful to feed the Octreolin war game planned this year.

item.title: Interest in Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy Hots Up
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Daiichi Sankyo has announced that it will establish a new company, Orphan Disease Treatment Institute Co., Ltd. with Innovation Network Corporation of Japan and Mitsubishi UFJ Capital Co., Ltd. to collaborate on the development of a new treatment for Duchenne muscular dystrophy with the active ingredient ENA® oligonucleotide*.
The Partnership Terms

INCJ will underwrite third party allocation of new shares for the new company with a maximum investment of 1.65 billion yen. The new company will also issue new shares by third party allocation for a fund managed by MUC. Daiichi Sankyo will invest in the new company and mainly conduct development with the goal of achieving POC for clinical drug development.

*ENA® oligonucleotides

ENA® is an ethylene-bridged nucleic acid in which ethylene is bridged at the furanose sugar ring at 2'-O and 4'-C ends. Short-chain nucleic acids and ENA® oligonucleotides found in ENA® demonstrate high binding force with complementary DNA and RNA as well as superior thermal stability and nuclease resistance.

item.title: Tokai's Galeterone Appears To Have A Differentiated Profile
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Thanks to Phil Kaspryzk, we note that Tokai has published in poster form some interesting data at ASCO GU, demonstrating its differentiated CYP-17 profile compared to Zytiga (abiraterone) and Orteronel (TAK-700). The implications are that it may be have an improved safety profile versus these drugs and will not require concomitant prednisone administration.
A copy of the poster is attached for review but the important data is highlighted below:
Tokai's galererone is the most postent Cyp17 inhibitor selective for CYP17 Lyase, whereas its negligble effect on CYP17A1 hydroxylase means that it has little effect on cortisol levels. The latter it suggest could explain phI clinical experience with the drug where no mineralocorticoid excess was observed or prednisone required.

item.title: How To Interpret The Value Of An Oncology Asset
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Phase III cancer drugs owned by micro-cap companies are almost assured of failure and thus will see a collapse in their share prices, according to an analysis (http://jnci.oxfordjournals.org/content/early/2011/09/26/jnci.djr375.full) published in the Journal of the National Cancer Institute. The article suggests that cocmpanies with a market cap of less than $300m four months before data readout will ultimately fail to produce positive results.
This is likely not a reflection on the scientific expertise or the capabilities of the company, but rather a sign of how rare and sought-after good oncology assets are, leaving only the probable failures in the hands of small drug developers.
Waiting for validation

At the time their article was published in JNCI, 21 micro-cap companies had failed the test; by comparison, 21 of 27 trials reported by companies of greater than $1bn market cap had been successful.
The explanation is rather simple: based on earlier-stage data, investors have simply not had the belief in the company to drive prices any higher. Furthermore, big pharma companies have not had the confidence to either in-license the drug or buy the company outright; either move would help validate the drug’s promise.
Source: Evaluate Pharma

item.title: New Sequential Design Study In pNET
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Thanks to Eva Pineda, we were recently able to access a presentation given by Marianne Pavel to the VIII International GETNE Symposium. The slides interestingly refer to a new upcoming Novartis GETNE co-sponsored study looking at sequential chemo/mTOR therapy in a study callled SEQTOR.
Below you will find a link to the presentation but it is worth highlighting a slide showing the current range of combination studies ongoing and some of Marianne Pavel's key conclusions about where we stand with the different types of therapies/combinations available for the treatment of NET, both in terms of efficacy and safety.
source: http://www.getne.org/LinkClick.aspx?fileticket=qTqmicDIrFw%3D&tabid=174

Comments
Combinability of drugs for the management of NET is indeed an open question and has also been considered at Ipsen with the SUNLAND study.
This european ESS is coordinated by GERCORupported by ENETS . It is fully granted by Ipsen and Pfizer through a global / european partnership between both companies aiming at joining both expertises in this dynamic field and trying to address to enroll more than 100 patients. The first 2 patients have been enrolled in January 2013.

item.title: Medivation Signals Its Itent To Potentially Compete Head On With The GNRH-agonists
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Medivation has reported phII data from its study of enzalutamide in hormone niave prostate cancer patients, demonstrating a significant PSA response. These results are likely to pave the way for a phIII trial as Medivations's CFO alluded to during yesterday's Leerink Swann H/C Conference.
Study Design
A 25-wk, open-label, single-arm study of patients with hormone-naïve, histologically confirmed prostate cancer (all stages) requiring hormonal treatment, an ECOG PS score of 0, and a life expectancy >1 y. All patients received ENZA 160 mg/d without concomitment castration.
Key Findings
Among 67 men enrolled, the median age was 73y; 39% had metastases; 36% and 24% had undergone prostatectomy or radiotherapy before study entry.
The PSA response rate (>80% PSA decline at wk 25) was 93%, with a median decrease of −99% at wk 25. Serum T and estrogen levels increased by a median 113% and 58% at wk 25, respectively, compared with baseline.
82% of men reported drug-related AEs (mostly Grade 1 or 2). Most frequent treatment-emergent AEs included gynaecomastia (36%), fatigue (34%), and hot flush (18%). 7% of men experienced SAEs; none were drug-related.
Commenting on these results Pat Mochado Chief Financial & Business Officer stated
"This data is very very robust and definitely in the same ballpark as one would expect to see with Lupron, which really is significat for us because from a clinical rational point of view Lupron is currently the first agent that physicians reach for. And Lupron has good news and bad news. The good news is it's pretty effective at controlling tumour growth for a certain period of time. The bad news is that it reduces your testosterone to castrate levels to the equivalent of being physically castrated. So if we could offer an option to patients of that stage of the disease that offered comparable tumour control without castratoin and the side-effects and libodo and muscle wasting and the various associated issues that follow with castration, we think that would be a fairly compelling proposition. So the fact that the initial foray into this patient population generated PSA response data which are the same zip code as Lurpon's that to us is a very encouraging first sign."
Pat Mochado also noted that he expects the R&D budget to inflect upwards in 2013 as one or potentially more phIII studies are intitiated. He noted:-
So the details of that are still being worked out, but I think if you just look at the spectrum of disease states , there are two substantial population... We have done preliminary work in both of them but they certainly remain interesting targets for registration. The first would be the M0 population, so non-metastatic CRPC, patients who have fialed Lupron but do not yet have metastatic disease. That's a population that we think would be quite interesting and based on the data that we,ve seen so far, especially if PREVAIL reads out positively, as we expect, very strong clinical rational for going into that poplation.
The second would be the even earlier stage population, which is the hormone-naive patients who have had their prostatectomy or their radiation and are experiencing biochemical recurrence.
We are looking to expand our opportunity by pushing earlier into the disease state but an equally interesting way to expand the opportunity is to follow the Lupron template from initiation of biochemical recurrence until death. Once the patient progresses you don't stop the Lupron you add a new agent onto it.
That is exactly the model we want to follow with XTANDI. So one of the studies that we are actually in fairly late stages of finalizing would be a study that would look at exactly that. If you take patients who've begun to progress on XTANDI, is there incremental benefit to keeping them on XTANDI and adding on Zytiga or whatever subseqeunt treatment the physician might think is appropriate and I think if we can show that answer to that as yes, that will be a further enhancement of the opportunity.
Source: www.medivation.com

item.title: Orphan Drug Designation Granted in EU to PROLOR's Longer-Acting hGH
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The EU Commission and the EMA have granted orphan drug designation (ODD) to hGH-CTP, a once-weekly version of human GH, in development for the treatment of GH deficiency. This is the 1st time a GH drug has received ODD in Europe.
- Market exclusivity: the ODD will prevent any other long-acting recombinant growth hormone from being marketed in Europe for 10 years after the launch of hGH-CTP.
Ph3 trial in growth hormone-deficient adults is scheduled to begin later this year.
In Oct 2010 the drug received ODD in the US which provides 7 years of market exclusivity, reductions in regulatory fees, certain credits and additional regulatory support.
Source: PROLOR

item.title: re: Bayer/Algeta's Alpharadin Submitted to the EMA for CRPC Patients with Bone Metastases
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Bayer/Algeta's Alpharadin Submitted to the EMA for CRPC Patients with Bone Metastases 
Comment: On August 20th, at last Bayer's Q2 financial results, management highlighted EU launch to occur in Q2/Q3:13. In Russia, the drug is expected to reach the market in the course of the next five years.  ...
Bayer has received notification from the FDA granting priority review of the NDA (filed in December 2012). The application is under review for the treatment of CRPC patients with bone metastases.
FDA now has 8 months to complete its review (This suggests an estimated PDUFA action date of 13 August 2013).
Analysts with Deutsche Bank "believe Alpharadin has blockbuster potential in prostate cancer alone, supported by use as an alternative to Taxotere and potential for use in combination with new oral anti-hormonals.
Benefits on bone palliation are particularly important given additional potential for repeat use in patients with bone pain at the end of life. In addition, our discussions with physicians suggest Taxotere is often used more for its palliative benefits than for its improvement in survival. The data suggests Alpharadin could be competitive in this regard and further adds to its benefits which include an improvement in overall survival (14.9 vs 11.3 mo; HR=0.695) and delay in time to skeletalrelated events (15.6 vs 9.8 mo;P< 0.001; HR = 0.66; 95% CI: 0.52-0.83)."

Maintain: 1.6g daily

item.title: Nasal Growth Hormone to Progress Phase 2/3 Studies
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Latest Ph1 results with Critical Pharm.'s CP024 showed that the drug was well tolerated, pharmacokinetics were highly reproducible, and IGF-1 was strongly induced. The company is searching for a development and commercialization partner.
Dosage: 6 dose levels of CP024 (between 2-6 mg growth hormone) were administered to healthy subjects along with an infusion of octreotide to suppress the production of endogenous growth hormone.
Objectives: The objectives of the study were to measure the pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics and dose response relationship of CP024 compared to a subcutaneous dose of 0.75 mg Omnitrope®.
Critical Pharmaceuticals’ proprietary CriticalSorb technology enhances the absorption of somatropin and thereby makes it possible to deliver the drug by nasal spray.
Pipeline

item.title: OncoGenex Expands OGX-427 Development Program for Bladder Cancer
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The Ph2 trial (Borealis-2) will investigate OGX-427¨+/- docetaxel for the treatment of 2nde-line metastatic bladder cancer.
Currently, first-line platinum-based chemotherapy regimens result in a median overall survival of approximately 12-15 months. Docetaxel is commonly used in second-line treatment, with a reported median overall survival of approximately six months.
Rationale for 2nd/3rd-line Treatment
Given acquired treatment resistance and these short survival times, there continues to be a high unmet need for additional therapeutic options for this patient population.
Borealis-2 will be the second randomized, controlled clinical trial of OGX-427 in advanced bladder cancer.

o Recruitment: approximately 200 patients

o Protocol: OGX-427 plus docetaxel treatment or docetaxel treatment alone. Patients may also continue weekly OGX-427 infusions as maintenance treatment until disease progression or unacceptable toxicity if they complete all 10 planned cycles of docetaxel or are discontinued from docetaxel due to docetaxel toxicity.

o The primary objective: overall survival

o Location: 30 sites in the U.S.

o Sponsors/Investigators: Hoosier Oncology Group. Dr. Noah Hahn from the Indiana University Simon Cancer Center, Dr. Toni Choueiri from the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute and Dr. Jonathan Rosenberg from Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center will serve as the primary investigators on the study.

Borealis-1 clinical trial is the OncoGenex-sponsored, randomized, placebo-controlled Phase 2 study designed to evaluate a potential survival benefit, safety and tolerability of combining OGX-427 with gemcitabine and cisplatin in the first-line treatment of patients with advanced bladder cancer.
If either Borealis trial shows a survival advantage, OncoGenex plans to initiate conversations with the Food and Drug Administration about the possibility of a Phase 3 study of OGX-427 in bladder cancer as part of the ORCA program.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Survey Data Highlights Recent Trends In The CRPC Market
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: A recent report from Baird equity research, highlights the results of two new surveys evaluating usage of new drugs in the CRPC market. The surveys were undertaken in the US in October/November 2012 by BioTrends and ICI community-oncology and included 191 participants. Zytiga is more favourably perceived than Provenge but there are also indications that Xtandi is likely to be very well received.
BioTrends surveyed urologists and oncologists and included 52 urologists, whilst ICI's survey included 92 oncologists.
Key Findings
  • Both surveys show Zytiga increasing its footprint in the chemo-naive patients segment.
  • Feedback from urologists (n=52) indicated that Provenge's share of the asymptomatic /minimally symtpomatic CRPC segment has increased steadily over the last year, now 24%.
  • However, amongst oncologists (which account for 60% of community-based sales)Provenge sales are flat
  • The view on sequencing Provenge and Zytiga remains split with about half indicating that they will prescribe Zytiga only.
  • Oncologists also indicate a high degree of enthusiasm for Xtandi with 46% citing it as a promising new treatment strategy for prostate cancer vs 5% for Provenge and 30% for Zytiga
For a full copy of the report please contact the CI Department.
Source: Baird Analyst Report January 31st 2013

item.title: re: Key Takeaways from IMCAS (Jan. 31 - Feb. 3)
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Key Takeaways from IMCAS (Jan. 31 - Feb. 3) 
Comment: General perspectives for the years to come will be guided by more sessions on Evidence Based Medicine (EBM), the importance of anatomy and muscle mass-based approaches. Prolonged action (> 6 months) was cited as a missing important characteristic for an ‘ideal toxin’. If portfolios include products from prevention to enhancement, a question mark arised on whether to consider ‘diagnosis’ in the future. Of note, Medy-Tox exhibited for the 1st time, and Merz did not hold a symposium, whereas Allergan’s one celebrated the 10th anniversary of Botox, and the launch of a new filler. Highlights from the ‘New approaches for hyperhidrosis’ and 'The power of nanotechnology" sessions are provided below.  ...
  • It is important to mention that BoNT-A is the best choice for the treatment of hyperhidrosis - (Dr Marc Heckman at the session "New approaches for Hyperhidrosis").
  • According to Juergen Frevert (Merz at Botulinum Toxins products : from characteristics to recommendations) and Philippe Bouchard (CEO - Merz at the Industry Tribune), the goal of Merz is to develop new indications for Xeomin.

item.title: Key Takeaways from IMCAS (Jan. 31 - Feb. 3)
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: General perspectives for the years to come will be guided by more sessions on Evidence Based Medicine (EBM), the importance of anatomy and muscle mass-based approaches. Prolonged action (> 6 months) was cited as a missing important characteristic for an ‘ideal toxin’. If portfolios include products from prevention to enhancement, a question mark arised on whether to consider ‘diagnosis’ in the future. Of note, Medy-Tox exhibited for the 1st time, and Merz did not hold a symposium, whereas Allergan’s one celebrated the 10th anniversary of Botox, and the launch of a new filler. Highlights from the ‘New approaches for hyperhidrosis’ and 'The power of nanotechnology" sessions are provided below.
For this exceptional edition, IMCAS welcomed more than 4000 participants from 85 countries, 160 exhibitors, 350 international speakers, and about 900 oral presentations.
The Ideal Toxin
G. Monheit (dermatologist, US) and C-H Huh () had a go on trying to describe the 'ideal toxin'.
C-H Huh concluded his presentation entitled 'Focus on Chinese and Korean Toxins' by highlighting that Botulax/Regenox/Zentox from Hugel still lack clinical references. He also warned the audience on the 'allergic reactions' (skin rash) and possibly bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE) linked with BTX-A/Prosigne from Lanzhou Institute of Biological Products.
'NEW APPROACHES FOR HYPERHIDROSIS' (HH)
Although the title of this session was attractive, there was nothing new on the matter. Below are some interesting points to note:
The ‘Sweat’ market represents approx. $10bn (EU: 45% - Americas: 30%).
  • 3% of the population in the world
  • 80% who do not want to sweat
- Cause: neuronal overstimulation (neuregulin overexpressed)
- Background: gene locus have been mapped
- Diagnosis: "clinical signs and patients history are key".
Doris Hexsel (dermatologist, Brazil) outlined that as "sweating is connected to the brain, the placebo effect is important in this pathology". She concluded her presentation outlining that BoNT-A injections is a very good option to optimize the effects of HH in various areas of the face and body. Several recent publications have reinforced the efficacy of BoNT-A in many forms of the condition.
Nano Dermatology: Ethosomes (discovered by Pf E. Touitou)
Schlomit Halachmi (dermatologist, Israel) cited Ethosomes, as novel vesicular carriers for enhanced delivery. The ethosomal system is composed of phospholipid, ethanol and water. This carrier presents interesting features correlated with its ability to permeate intact through the human skin due to its high deformability. Ethosomes are soft, malleable vesicles tailored for enhanced delivery of active agents.
The InParT Transdermal Delivery System
Hyperhidrosis / Mark Nestor presented :
The results from a prospective open label study for axillary and palmer hyperhidrosis in 24 patients (18-59) -
HIGHLIGHTS FROM THE SYMPOSIUM
MYOSCIENCE
For the 1st time, Myoscience organized a symposium to introduce iovera, its Cold Therapy for dynamic wrinkles. Speakers: B. Ascher, J. Sykes and D. Cassuto.
Key Messages
  • World’s first toxin free treatment of dynamic wrinkles
  • Not a competitor to toxins, but an opportunity to increase patient demand (2 to 5 times the number of botulinum toxin treated patients do not want a toxin)
  • Predictable (Treatment effect: Immediate results - Duration: 2 to 4 months; 90 days (minimum)
  • Repeatable (complete restoration of motor functions)
ALLERGAN
Allergan celebrated the 10th anniversary of Botox, and the arrival of a newcomer in the "Juvederm dynasty": JUVEDERM VOLBELLA with lidocaine, which contains low molecular weight HA (< 1 million Da).
First Part of the presentation was dedicated to Botox, listing its following characteristics:
  • The very first
  • The longest follow-up
  • The largest literature
  • The most widely used in the world
Supported by literature references
Precision - Study De AlmeIda et al(2007) P1070228 Key Findings 6 month pilot study using a forehead anhydrotic model
Rapid onset of effect -Study Beers et al(2011) VISTABEL provides rapid onset of response based on physician and subject assessments
Long lasting effect: dynamic lines — Study Kane et al (2011) 84.2% subjects identified as responsers at day 30; Median duration of efficacy was 120 days (95% CI 119-121)
High patient satisfaction - Study Stotland et al(2007) Aesthetic treatment with AGN BoNTA significantly improved self perception of age by approx. 5years
Proven long term safety — Study Brin et al (2009) meata-analysis
Second Part dedicated to Volbella ("Voluma's little brother")
  • Same Vycross technology HA 15 mg/ml
  • Specifically designed for lips and perioral
  • Extremely soft and easy to mold
  • Less swelling
  • Reduced edema potential
  • Significantly increased longevity (12 months)
MERZ Presence
Merz did not organize a symposium this year. In addition to Bocouture, Radiesse and Belotero, the company exhibited Glytone “the dermal filler with a pharmaceutical heritage’ acquired from Pierre Fabre in Q3:12.
Glytone contains mannitol, a well-known radical scavenger.
NCT00777803 - Results from a Ph3 comparison trial with Vistabel for GL (in press) were projected on the booth. They show that:
MEDY-TOX Presence
Medium-size booth presenting Neuramis and Neuronox.
Medy-Tox claims that "Approximately a million Neuronox procedures have been administered globally since 2004" - data on file, Medy-Tox (source: Neuronox flyer)
The company outlined four articles about Neuronox in the recent issue of 'Dermatology Surgery' (vol 39 Number 1 Part II, Jan 13) introducing "a novel Botulinum Toxin Preparation"
(gathered by the Aesthetic Team)
- J& J's Mentor Purified Toxin (ex PurTox) will have a "low pre-marketing profile" (feedback from an ex J&J employee), and its clinical profile may be considered as a "mee too" (feedback from a US dermatologist).
- Because biodisponibility is low, Revance has to increase the dose. Is this going to arise safety concern with the US FDA ?
- Allergan message to increase the doses of Botox Cosmetic in GL in order to avoid underdosing (could be linked with the fact that Allergan recently reported it will focus on the Botox Cosmetic duration of action of 4 months vs. 3 months in the Xeomin label after reintroduction of Xeomin in the US).

Comments
With regard to the InPart Transdermal Delivery System: a more comprehensive presentation on their topical Botulinum toxin trial can be found at the company's website: http://www.transdermalcorp.com/clinical-studies
(Presentation can be downloaded when left-clicking on it).
Slides 114-138 are most relevant to botulinum toxin trial.
  • It is important to mention that BoNT-A is the best choice for the treatment of hyperhidrosis - (Dr Marc Heckman at the session "New approaches for Hyperhidrosis").
  • According to Juergen Frevert (Merz at Botulinum Toxins products : from characteristics to recommendations) and Philippe Bouchard (CEO - Merz at the Industry Tribune), the goal of Merz is to develop new indications for Xeomin.

item.title: microRNAs as Biomarker to Predict the Progression of Bladder Urothelial Carcinoma
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The conclusion of the study, published in the British Journal of Urology, shows that microRNA can be useful biomarkers for prognosis in patients with urothelial carcinoma and that the expression levels of several microRNAs, including miR-29c, identified high- and low-risk groups.
According to Kenneth A. Berlin (CEO of Rosetta Genomics), "... This publication adds to the growing body of clinical data demonstrating the utility of microRNA expression for predicting progression of disease, and for stratification of patients with bladder cancer ...".

item.title: re: Allergan Reports Botox Sales in Q4 were the "Highest Ever"
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Allergan Reports Botox Sales in Q4 were the "Highest Ever" 
Comment: Management reported that FY12 therapeutic sales accounted for about 52% of total Botox®, an increase of 13% compared to 2011. FY12 aesthetic sales accounted for approx. 48% of total Botox® sales (an increased of 8% compared to 2011). At the IMCAS conference in Paris, Allergan launched Volbella (with lidocaine), a new filler based on the VYCROSS technology, indicated for the lips and the perioral area.  ...
Additional information arising from the earnings call highlights the point that due to rapidly increasing sales and workloads in neurology and urology, Allergan over the summer of 2012 created dedicated sales teams for neuro-rehabilitation, covering cervical dsytonia and upper limb spasticity, Hence it now has four focused sales team: chronic migraine, neuro-rehab, urology and a hospital team covering all indications. Additional country approvals were also mentioned,
New Approvals
  1. Russia and Austria for chronic migraine,
  2. Russia, Saudi Arabia, Egypt , Kuwait and Argentina for neurogenic bladder;
  3. Germany, Austria , Finland and Estonia for iOAB in addition to the Irish reference member state approval; and
  4. Hyperhydrosis for GSK in Japan
In terms of Xeomin re-entry to the US market, Allergan does state that it expects to lose some share to Xeomin but in terms of messaging it will focus on the Botox cosmetic label which specifies a duration of action of four months versus three months in the Xeomin label.

item.title: Acorda Highlights New Stroke Data
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Acorda Therapeutics has presented data at a recent stroke conference demonstrating Glial Growth Factor 2 (GGF2) can enhance recovery of sensorimotor function in a preclinical model of stroke.
The data were featured as a late-breaking poster presentation at the American Heart Association/American Stroke Association International Stroke Conference in Honolulu, HI.
Commenting on the data Anthony Caggiano VP of R&D stated “These data confirm earlier preclinical study results showing that GGF2 can improve recovery of function following stroke. They also provide valuable information about varying dosing regimens that will contribute to the further development of GGF2."
He went onto say "Previous studies have shown that GGF2 can be effective in restoring function when initiating therapy as long as seven days following a stroke. Currently approved stroke interventions need to be administered within a few hours of an event, which limits therapy to a small minority of people who experience a stroke. Early data on GGF2 suggest a longer time window to administer treatment, which represents a potentially critical advance.”
Key Study Findings
The poster, entitled “Optimized Dosing of Glial Growth Factor 2 in a Middle Cerebral Artery Occlusion Model Increases GAP43 Expression,” reviewed data from study groups receiving differing doses of GGF2 to determine which dose was most effective in enhancing recovery of sensorimotor function after stroke. This was measured by several sensorimotor function tests, including limb placement. Treatment was initiated 24 hours after the stroke. The study showed significant improvements in sensorimotor recovery with GGF2 that were related to dose and frequency of treatment. As was seen in previous studies, improvements were not associated with reduced lesion volume, but in this study were shown to be associated with increased expression of the growth associated protein, GAP43, within the brain, both close to and distant from the area of injury.
What is GGF2
GGF2 is the leading development candidate from the Company’s neuregulin program. Neuregulins are a class of naturally occurring protein growth factors that have multiple effects on the nervous and cardiovascular systems.
Next Steps
Acorda is currently conducting a clinical program for GGF2 in heart failure and preclinical development in a number of neurological indications, including peripheral nerve injury and stroke. The first clinical trial of GGF2, a Phase 1 study of GGF2 in patients with heart failure, was completed in late 2012.

item.title: A Ph2 of LHRH +/- Zytiga (abiraterone) Has Started in Men with Prostate Cancer
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The goal of the study is to learn if treatment with HT (Zoladex, Lupron, Degarelix) +/- abiraterone and prednisone for 8 months controls the disease better than treatment with HT alone. Primary endpoint will assess PSA Free Survival.
Sponsor: M.D Anderson Cancer Center - Collaborator: Janssen Services LLC
Recruitment: approx 200 men with prostate cancer who have PSA progression after prostatectomy and/or radiotherapy.
Start date: Feb 2013 - Completion date: Feb 2017
PI: Christopher Logothetis, MD

item.dc:creator: spoon

Rhenovia Initiates Drug Research Program in Huntington's Disease (HD) 
Comment: The company has started to develop the use of biostimulation as a novel approach for drug development in HD.  ...
After the 1st round of seed funding of €350,000 in 2009, Rhenovia is preparing a second round of €2.5M to accelerate its development. The company plans to recruit about 20 new employees in France over the next 5 years.
Rhenovi announced yesterday it has had its position confirmed as world leader in the field of biosimulation for research into drugs for the treatment of diseases of the CNS.

item.title: Addex to Focus Resources on Clinical Pipeline for Rare Diseases
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: B. Chowrira (CEO) reported that value drivers for 2013 include the initiation of a POC trial of dipraglurant in rare dystonias, the completion of GABA(B)-RPAM Ph1 testing for Charcot-Marie-Tooth neuropathy. To improve the Company's liquidity and long term outlook, Addex will secure a listing on a US stock exchange.
Addex will advance current clinical and pre-IND programs in certain diseases where orphan drug designation can be reasonably achieved in the major commercial markets - U.S., Europe and Japan.
In executing this strategy and to maximize potential clinical success in at least two programs over the next 12 months, the company will reduce its overall cost structure, particularly around its early-stage discovery efforts, while maintaining its core competency and expertise in allosteric modulation.

item.title: Aduro Biotech to Advance Portfolio of Combination Vaccine Treatments
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Aduro, a clinical-stage immunotherapy company located in Berkeley (California), has acquired all GVAX assets from BioSante Pharm.. End of last month, the company completed an equity financing of $6.5M (€4.8M). Management believes that combinations will become the standard for the next generation immunotherapies. Of note, the sequential administration of GVAX Pancreas and the Listeria-based CRS-207 is currently assessed in a randomized, controlled Phase 2 trial in patients with metastatic pancreatic cancer. (interim analysis planned H1:13).
- synergy between listeria and other vaccine technologies would improve efficacy.
The company previously licensed 2 GVAX vaccines (GVAX Pancreas and GVAX Prostate), for use in combination with its Listeria-based vaccines.
See Oncology7339: Aduro BioTech Licenses GVAX Cancer Vaccines from BioSante.
- covers all uses and includes additional vaccines for multiple myeloma, breast and colon cancers.
- assumes rights to the existing license agreement for GVAX Melanoma.
- based on human cancer cell lines that are genetically modified to secrete granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor (GM-CSF), an immune-stimulatory cytokine.
Platform
Pipeline - Available for partnering

item.title: Novo Nordisk - The 'Experts in Protein Technology'
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Novo Nordisk outlines five key strategic focus areas including Diabetes, Obesity, Haemophilia, Growth Disorders and Inflammation.
Novo Nordisk published their 2012 annual report this week, defining themselves as experts in protein technology, not just a ‘diabetes company’.
There may be a long term goal to diversify but, they are the world's largest insulin producer and had a total sales growth of 18% in 2012 ($14 billion) - due to the strong sales from their diabetes franchise. Sales growth for 2013 is a projected 8-11%.
The report centred around five key strategic focus areas of 2012 which will be continued and further developed in 2013:
  • Expand its leadership in Diabetes Care
  • Establish a presence in Obesity
  • Pursue a leadership position in Haemophilia
    • In October 2012, turoctocog alfa – a recombinant factor VIII therapy – was filed for approval in Europe
    • US. Long-acting versions of recombinant factor VII and factor IX are in Phase III development
    • Novo Nordisk did suffer a setback in 2012 with vatreptacog alfa, a fast-acting recombinant factor VIIa analogue whereby some patients in the trial developed anti-drug antibodies and chose to discontinue development
  • Build its Growth Disorders franchise by providing new convenient products and devices
    • Novo Nordisk is developing a long-acting growth hormone formulation, currently in Phase I trials
  • Establish a presence in inflammation using its expertise in protein design
    • 3 candidates in Phase II development

Primary endpoint will measure composite endpoint based upon the investigator global assessment and patient assessment of severity of lateral canthal lines.
Recruitment: about 240 (both genders - 18 to 65 years)
Started Dec 2012 - completion date Feb 2013 / March 2013
Location: Dermatology Research Institute (Florida)
Product Description
Proprietary 150kD neurotoxin molecule with TransMTS peptide
- reconstituted with poloxamer gel
Liquid at refrigerated temperatures; gels at room temperature
Applied in the physician's office
Gel stays on skin for 30 minutes
- easily wiped clean with water

item.title: Allergan Reports Botox Sales in Q4 were the "Highest Ever"
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Management reported that FY12 therapeutic sales accounted for about 52% of total Botox®, an increase of 13% compared to 2011. FY12 aesthetic sales accounted for approx. 48% of total Botox® sales (an increased of 8% compared to 2011). At the IMCAS conference in Paris, Allergan launched Volbella (with lidocaine), a new filler based on the VYCROSS technology, indicated for the lips and the perioral area.
  • In Q4 12, Allergan sales grew vs. Q4 11 by 8.1% in lc.
  • FY12 sales increased by 9.1% in lc vs. FY11.
Management outlined that " ... Botox® sales in Q4 were the highest ever at $475 million benefiting from the normal high aesthetics and an accelerating trend in therapeutics. Sales grew vs. the Fourth Quarter of 2011 by 14.7% to local currencies and 14.3% in dollars.
For the full year, Botox® sales increased 12.7% in local currencies and 10.7% in dollars. The therapeutic indications grew approximately 13% in dollars and the aesthetics sales grew approximately 8% in dollars with local currency growth for both franchises being greater in local currencies by approximately 200 basis points".
For the FY12, Allergan spent $927 million on R & D, an increase of 8.1% over 2011.
Management indicated that : " ... As we reviewed our urology R & D portfolio we have determine which products to fund for late stage development. Given positive Phase III data SER120, development in cooperation with our partner Serenity, Allergan has decided to fund a confirmatory Phase III trial. With mixed efficacy data Botox® for benign hyper static hyperplasia we have decided to terminate this program".

The company expects to execute a signed agreement in H1:13.
Total product net sales between $5,900 million and $6,200 million, which excludes the obesity intervention business.
  • Botox® product net sales between $1,900 million and $2,000 million.
  • LATISSE® product net sales at approximately $110 million.
  • Facial aesthetics product net sales between $410 million and $440 million.
- Botox® in OAB " ... if we compare and contrast to chronic migraine, it was clear to us from the very beginning that urology would move much quicker. Urologists are really procedure-based physicians. They like doing things like this. Obviously from my remarks once we've trained urologists how to deploy a scope and use the bladder injections to go from 200 units for NDO to a hundred for idiopathic overactive bladder is pretty simple. Coupled with that, the reimbursement codes is relatively complicated but it depends on site of care but I would say not only favorable in our point of view but also the point of view of the urology practices. ... in terms of training, this will continue to pick up in terms of those that still have not yet been trained and certainly, we heard prior to the approval of the latest indication, a lot of doctors were already thinking about the patients if you like they had in their practice just waiting for approval and of course that meant really access to reimbursement, so I think adding all those factors together, the over active bladder launch which by the way still has not formally occurred, this will be right around the corner, should be pretty quick".
- Botox® growth in 2013, " ... the growth will be higher on the therapeutic side than the aesthetic ... If we look at the cosmetic side, we think the market in the US is growing pretty close to 10%. The European market is also very healthy. I gave you some very specific numbers on fillers where it's easier for us to get behind it and the issue we always have with BOTOX Europe is how do we split therapeutic and aesthetic even ourselves because of lots of shipments that go around from one country to another and then of course trying to do that for our competitors becomes like an even greater defining process when we have our own data but stepping back from all of that I think you can see pretty healthy consumer facing market demand and hence why we feel pretty good about BOTOX and its entirety for 2013".

Comments
Additional information arising from the earnings call highlights the point that due to rapidly increasing sales and workloads in neurology and urology, Allergan over the summer of 2012 created dedicated sales teams for neuro-rehabilitation, covering cervical dsytonia and upper limb spasticity, Hence it now has four focused sales team: chronic migraine, neuro-rehab, urology and a hospital team covering all indications. Additional country approvals were also mentioned,
New Approvals
  1. Russia and Austria for chronic migraine,
  2. Russia, Saudi Arabia, Egypt , Kuwait and Argentina for neurogenic bladder;
  3. Germany, Austria , Finland and Estonia for iOAB in addition to the Irish reference member state approval; and
  4. Hyperhydrosis for GSK in Japan
In terms of Xeomin re-entry to the US market, Allergan does state that it expects to lose some share to Xeomin but in terms of messaging it will focus on the Botox cosmetic label which specifies a duration of action of four months versus three months in the Xeomin label.

item.title: New Drug Pricing Regulations Come into Effect in Greece
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: New regulations governing the price of medicines have been published in a Ministerial Decision by Greece's deputy minister of health, Marios Salmas, with the order that the decision be published in the Greek government gazette, thus bringing its regulations into law. The regulations in the Ministerial Decision are numerous and many are technical in nature, but there are a number of important changes that have immediate implications for pharmaceutical companies.

Of note, Management reported that the Ph3 results from TAK-700 / Orteronel in post-docetaxel setting (NCT01193257) will be presented at ASCO and ESMO this year. Approvals are expected next year in the US, and FY15-FY16 (JP/EU). FY2012 forecasts remain unchanged from the latest announcement. Key figures are provided below.
Thanks to the acquisitions of Nycomed and Multilab the sales increased about 2.3 times over year to reach JPY151.1bn (14% of the total ethical drug sales of Takeda).

item.title: re: SPA for Tivantinib in 2nde-Line Ph3 Trial in MET-High HCC Patients
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
SPA for Tivantinib in 2nde-Line Ph3 Trial in MET-High HCC Patients 
Comment: Daiichi and ArQule have announced a SPA agreement with the FDA for the design of the Ph3. Details of the trial as well as ongoing development program with the drug are provided below.  ...
The first patient has been enrolled in the pivotal Phase 3 METIV-HCC (MET-high patients with tivantinib in HCC) trial of tivantinib (ARQ 197). PE will assess Overall survival (OS) in Intent to Treat (ITT) population.
The METIV-HCC trial is a randomized, double-blinded, controlled study of previously treated patients with MET-high inoperable HCC who will receive tivantinib or placebo. The primary endpoint is overall survival (OS), and the secondary endpoint is progression-free survival (PFS). Approximately 300 patients are planned to be enrolled at approximately 120 clinical centers worldwide.
Tivantinib, an investigational selective inhibitor of MET, a receptor tyrosine kinase, is being evaluated for the treatment of patients diagnosed with hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) who have received one or two prior systemic anti-cancer therapies.

item.title: Aesthetics Leadership Change at Merz in the US
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Jim Hartman has been appointed to VP President of the US Aesthetics Business Unit, which includes Xeomin, Radiesse and Belotero.
Hired in June 2012 to lead the US Dermatology Business Unit, which includes Naftin, Mederma and Onmel.
Prior to join Merz, he was the VP, Global Marketing & Business Development at Obagi Medical Products.
Previously, he was Senior VP of US Commercial Operations, and Vice President of US Marketing for Stiefel Laboratories, a leader in global dermatology and skin health.
Mikael Svensson will now report directly to Mr. Hartman.
Svensson will assume responsibility for marketing our aesthetic filler franchise which includes BELOTERO BALANCE® Dermal Filler and RADIESSE® Volumizing Filler in his new role, Director of Marketing Filler Franchise.
Liz Newman will continue in her role as Director of Marketing, maintaining responsibility for marketing our aesthetic toxin / phlebology franchise which includes XEOMIN® (incobotulinumtoxinA) and Asclera® (polidocanol) Injection.
Source: Merz

item.title: re: Theratechnologies' Second Generation GRF Peptide Enters PC Phase
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Theratechnologies' Second Generation GRF Peptide Enters PC Phase 
Comment: According to the company, TH1173 exhibits superior pharmaceutical properties than tesamorelin. It is a shorter peptide with better physical and chemical stability. FIM is planned in Q1 2013. Potential future indication could include growth hormone replacement in growth hormone deficient patient populations.  ...
The US Patent and Trademark Office (USPTO) has granted a patent for the drug, providing for patent protection >2030. Of note, TH1173 is unpartnered.
Drug Clinical Program
The PC phase is completed. Results, including those from 7-day and 28-day toxicology trials, warrent the pursuit of clinical stage.

item.title: Epidemiology of Acromegaly in Denmark
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Aarhus U. Hospital, the sponsor of this observational study, will focus on the comparison between the outcome of surgery alone vs. medical treatment with SSA. Primary outcome measure will assess mortality.
NCT01752621 Incidence and late prognosis of acromegaly in Denmark from 1991 - 2010 Twenty years of medical treatment.
Recruitment: about 500 patients diagnosed with acromegaly in years 1991 - 2010.
Start date: Feb 2013 - Completion date: March 2015.
Status: Active but not yet open for recruitment.
Two cohorts: surgery treatment (acromegaly treated with surgery) and medical treatment (acromegaly treated with somatostatin).
Denmark holds a unique position in terms of epidemiological studies due to the existence of well organized databases which include all its inhabitants. A recognised problem with epidemiological surveys from specialised centres is whether the figures are representative for the general population. A nationwide Danish study will profit from the fact that every Danish citizen holds a unique ID number that makes it easy to retrieve and combine pertinent data regarding health, disease and death from different registries. The investigators have previously used this for a landmark survey of another rare endocrine disease, i.e. Cushing's syndrome. This publication has been cited more than 100 times.

item.title: Intelligence from Spain Brings Additional Details on Lexicon's Ph3 for Carcinoid Syndrome
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Thanks to Eva Pineda (Medical Adviser), we have learnt that the Ph3 study is not only recruiting in the US but in Spain as well. Six Spanish NET specialists/KOLs will participate in the trial.
Recruitment in Spain: expected to start in April 2013.
According to the clinical study protocol, 50 international centers will participate to include 104 patients.
TELESTAR (Telotristat Etiprate for Somatostatin Analogue Refractory Carcinoid Syndrome) - NCT01677910

- Design: randomized, placebo-controlled, parallel group, multicenter, double-blind study

- Recruitment: approx. 105 participants with carcinoid syndrome refractory to SSA therapy.

- Primary outcome measures will assess change from baseline in number of daily bowel movements.

- Timelines: study started in October 2012 and is expected to complete in April 2015.

item.title: Import and Sale of Animal Tested Cosmetic Product to be Banned in EU Soon
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: G. Asta (Public Affairs) commented this recent news. As of March 2013 animal testing will be banned for comsetics, due to the implementation in EU countries of the EU Cosmetic Products Directive (76/768/EEC, as amended). In spite of repeated attempts by Animal Rights Activists each time the legislation is amended, this ban does not apply to BoNTA used in aesthetic medicine.
Products containing substances intended to be injected in the human body do not come under the field of cosmetics, and are therefore not covered by the provision of this directive.
For any question you may get re animal welfare, please contact Ipsen's Animal Welfare WG (law@ipsen.com).
Original news please click here

item.title: The FDA Intesifies Its Efforts To Understand & Address The Issues Facing ALS Patients
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The FDA will hold a public hearing on Feb 25th to obtain stakeholder input on the needs and preferencese of ALS patients, as well input on how to be responsive to those needs.
The agency believes it needs input on ways to regulate the scientific evaluation, marketing authorisation and postmarketing surveillance of potential products to treat and diagnose ALS. Comments are due by March 25th.
The last therapy to be approved for ALS was Riluteck in 1996 based on a survival endpoint thus unmet need remains high. However the disease is poorly understood, heterogenouse in presentation and progression and there are currently no markers of progression or treatment response.
Biogen-Idec recent disappointing phIII data sparked and interesting review of drugs in development for ALS, with a number of companies now claiming they believe they have identified ways to improve the odds of clinical success. Companies taking a more optimistic view include Cytokinetics, Newron Pharmaceuticals and Neuraltus Pharmaceuticals. For those interested in a copy of the full 6-page article please contact the CI Dept.
Source: biocentury.com

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: XTANDI (enzalutamide) Starts To Perform Well In The CRPC Market
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: During its Q3 figures Astellas noted that sales of XTANDI enzalutamide during its first quarter on the US market (launched in September) reached $71m (ahead of company internal expectations). EU approval for postchemotherapy CRPC is awaited, whilst the first data on usage in hormone naive patients will be presented at the upcoming ASCO GU.
Oncology Sales
Tarceva-related revenue grew by 2.7% year-over-year to reach $329 million. Whilst Eligard in Europe, year-over-year it grew by 10.4%, to reach €106 million. Eligard, in October, was approved in Hong Kong.
The group's other oncology drug that continues to make good progress is Tivozanib (see below).
Source: astellas.com
