item.title: Spectrum Reacquires Rights To Bladder Cancer Drug From Allergan
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Spectrum has announced that it is to acquire all rights to Apaziquone in the US, Europe and other territories from Allergan with the expectation that it will soon file an NDA for the the treatment of NIMBC. In return Allergan will receive a royalty on sales.
Spectrum's decision to file is based on a recent meeting it had with the FDA to discuss the results of the phIII trials. Based on the discussion Spectrum understands that the FDA will accept a filing based on current PhIII data and will convene an Advisory meeting to review the data. It also agreed to conduct one additional phIII study following consultation with the FDA on design.
Spectrum views the acquisition of apaziquone rights as essential to advancing the durg's commercialisation throughout the US, Europe and other key territories and especially to expanding its footprint within the US market.

Apaziquone's Profile

Apaziquone is a pro-drug of a cytotoxic alkylating agent. Spectrum has conducted two multi-centre randomised single dose phIII studies with the drug which did not meet their primary endpoint of a statistically significant differennce in the rate of tumour recuurence at 2 years However, analysis of the pooled data did reach statistical significance for this endpoint and key secondary endpoints.

What is NIMBC

It is a form of bladder cancer localized in the surgace layers of the bladder that has not spread to the deeper muscle layer. Appoximately 70% of all newly diagnosed patients have this form of baldder cancer (more than one million in the US and Europe alone) which is primarily treated by urologists.

Source: spectrum.com

item.title: Botox Assessed in Ph2/Ph3 for Non-Relaxing Puborectalis Syndrome (NRPS)
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
omment: American Urogynecologic Society and Allergan collaborate on this study. Approx. 30 women will be recruited. Primary endpoint will measure change in symptoms based on scores using the PAC-SYM and Wexner Constipation questionnaires.
Non-relaxing puborectalis syndrome (NRPS) is an obstructive defecatory disorder that presents with chronic constipation, anismus, or a sensation of incomplete rectal emptying.
The etiology of NRPS is unknown. Previous therapies for this syndrome have included biofeedback, pelvic floor physical therapy, dietary changes, laxatives, enemas, and surgical division of the puborectalis muscle. However, responses to these treatments have been variable at best.
to determine the efficacy of ultrasound and EMG guided Botox injections into the puborectalis muscle in women with NRPS.
Study Details NCT01780636

item.title: Patient Enrollment Completion for Provenge Plus Indoximod Trial
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The Phase II indoximod with Provenge (sipuleucel-T) Prostate cancer study will conclude its patient enrollment in 2014
Cancer therapeutics developer NewLink Genetics aims to raise $42.5m to finance a slew of cancer immunotherapy trials, selling over four million in common stock for its HyperAcute immunotherapy and IDO pathway inhibitor technology.
NewLink's lead product candidate using the HyperAcute immunotherapy is HyperAcute Pancreas cancer immunotherapy (algenpantucel-L), in phase III trials with surgically-resected pancreatic cancer patients.
Other trials utilizing this technology include:
  • Phase IIb/III clinical trial for HyperAcute Lung (tergenpumatucel-L)
  • Phase II HyperAcute Melanoma trial
  • Phase I renal cell cancer HyperAcute study
With regards to their indoleamine-(2,3)-dioxygenase (IDO) pathway technology, the lead programme - indoximod (d-1-methyltryptophan) which is currently in phase II for second-line metastatic solid tumor studies (updates on data expected by mid 2013) and patient enrollment in a phase II prostate cancer study which combines indoximod with Provenge (sipuleucel-T) will conclude in 2014 - ClinicalTrials.gov Identifier:NCT01560923

item.title: SciClone Pharmaceuticals Continues To Promote Sanofi Products in China
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: SciClone Pharmaceuticals will continue with its agreement to promote Sanofi's products in China, including Xatral for the treatment of BPH
SciClone Pharmaceuticals has renewed its agreement with Sanofi to continue to promote four products in China. The agreement has been extended until the 31 December 2013 with a possibility for a longer-term collaboration.
The four products included in the agreement are:
  • Depakine (sodium valproate) for the treatment of epilepsy
  • Stilnox (zolpidem) for the treatment of insomnia and some brain disorders
  • Tritace (ramipril) for the treatment of hypertension
  • Xatral (alfuzosine HCl) for the treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia

item.title: JV Formed to Develop Peptide Injectable Drugs for Cancer
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: ScinoPharm, a Taiwanese API manufacturer, and Foresee, a US drug delivery company, have formed a JV that will initially focus on developing a controlled-release formulation of leuprolide for prostate cancer. Of note, Foresee Pharm's pipeline is listing 2 drugs in PC for prostate cancer (once-6month dosing) and acromegaly.
ScinoPharm will invest $3.6M for a minority stake in the JV
The companies plan to start a Ph3 trial of the injectable leuprolide late 2013.
To submit a NDA under the section 505(b)(2) of the FDA.
Pipeline : http://www.foreseepharma.com/Product-Pipeline.html
Technology: http://www.foreseepharma.com/Technology.html
Partnership: http://www.foreseepharma.com/Technology.html
In collaboration with Nang Kuang Pharm Inc., Foresee are developing FP-001 the treatment of advanced stage prostate Cancer. This long-acting release formulation has the potential to provide important therapeutic benefits in a once-6 months dosing regimen.
  • Foresee is responsible for developing potential long-acting formulations of FP-001, conducts its preclinical toxicology testing and clinical trial, and obtains regulatory approval.
  • NanKuang is responsible for the cGMP compliant manufacturing of injectable FP-001 for supporting development and commercial manufacturing.
Source: Cos websites

Summary of Q4:12
Summary of FY12

item.title: Pfizer May Split Drug Units in Emerging Markets
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Alongside Q4 results presentation, management reported that the company may consider operating its branded medicines and generic products units as seprate businesses, with separate management.
- To do the same way as in developed markets, where Pfizer's operations are already structured into separate units for brand-name and generic products.
- To offer stakeholders the opportunity to invest in 2 separate companies or not.
Analyst with Goldman Sachs forecasts Pfizers new business to have about $369bn sales in 2013, and generic medicines line $17bn.

item.dc:creator: spoon

Comment: Pfizer in its Q4 performance review, has started once again reporting more detailed sales figures for Somavert. Full year global sales were $197m +14% with all geographic territories registering strong growth. The geographic sales breakdown is shown below together with sales of Genotropin.
Somavert (Registering Strong Growth)

item.dc:creator: spoon

Comment: The survey polled 32 U.S based dermatologists and 31 plastic surgeons. Respondents expect Botox to capture >70%+ of the overall market in 2014 despite the return of Merz' Xeomin, and forecast stable Q/Q growth for toxins and fillers in Q1:13. Physicians' most cited interest area is injectable fat reduction technology (for "double-chin"). Key results are provided below.
Please see Neurology6626: Highlights of Leerink Swann's 3Q Cosmetic Survey Results.

If approved, ATX-101 will be the 1st and only drug product for the reduction of submental fat. Bayer has rights outside US and Canada.

During IMCAS (Jan31 - Feb3, Paris), Bayer will be dedicating its symposium to ATX-101.

item.title: Injecting Botox Into The Stomach Does Not Promote Weight Loss
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The February issue of Clinical Gastroenterology & Hepatology highlights a study which indicates that Botox injections are not helpful when it comes to treating obesity.
Study Methodology
Botox was evaluated by Mark Topazian and team at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester Minessota. as a means of possibly slowing gastric emptying. They compared the effects of injecting different doses of BTA into the stomachs of 60 individuals with mild-to-moderate obesity.
Study participants were each given 1 injection of BTA (100, 300, or 500 U), or placebo, in the gastric antral muscularis propria, guided by endoscopic ultrasound.
Gastric emptying of solids was measured by scintigraphy and participants' body weight was recorded every 2 weeks, as well as satiation, calorie intake, gastrointestinal symptoms, and psychological aspects of eating.
Key Findings
Two weeks after the injections, the mean half-time for gastric emptying of solids increased by 0.8, 14, 24, and 14 minutes among subjects given placebo, 100, 300, or 500 U BTA, respectively.
Sixteen weeks after the injections, mean body weights were reduced by 2.2, 0.2, 2.3, and 3.0 kg in these groups, respectively -- not a statistically significant difference.
Nor were there significant differences among groups in satiation volume, caloric intake, gastrointestinal symptoms, or psychological aspects of eating among groups.
So, although stomach injection of BTA slows gastric emptying, it does not increase the feeling of fullness or lead to loss of body weight.

item.title: Addex' Dipraglurant As a Novel Treatment for Dystonia
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The company has reported positive PC data for its mGlu5 NAM in a validated rodent model of dystonia. These data are consistent with earlier findings in a Ph2a trial assessing LID in Parkinson's patients as well as a non-human primate model of Parkinson's-related dystonia.
On track for Ph2 clinical testing in H2:13.
May be a valuable new strategy for treating PD, LID in PD, anxiety, depression, pain, tardive dyskinesia, dystonia, addiction, autism and Fragile X syndrome.
Addex continues to seek a partner to advance dipraglurant in Parkinson's LID.

item.title: Aileron's Stappled Peptide Technology Has Entered Ph1 for GHD
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The FIM study started this month, and is evalutating approx. 48 adult participants for growth hormone deficiency (GHD). Primary outcome will assess incidence of AEs.
Completion date: June 2013
PI: Bradley D. Vince
Study Director: Hubert C. Chen
Location: US (1 site)
Aileron's Stapled Peptide therapeutics provide the opportunity to greatly expand the number of "druggable" targets by targeting the thousands of intracellular and extracellular protein-protein interactions that cannot be functionally modulated by current therapeutics.
Leveraging these attributes, Aileron is creating a new paradigm in drug discovery and development.
Reference in Traction CI Please see PharmaWorld9557: Permeon Biologics Technology Platform Focuses On Intracellular Delivery of Biologic Macromolecules.

item.title: re: Lilly Announces Positive Results For Ramucirumab in Phase III Gastric Cancer Trial
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Lilly Announces Positive Results For Ramucirumab in Phase III Gastric Cancer Trial 
Comment: Eli Lilly has announced today positive top-line results from the REGARD trial, a Phase III study of ramucirumab (IMC-1121B) in patients with metastatic gastric cancer. The study met its primary endpoint of improved overall survival and also showed prolonged progression-free survival.  ...

Ramucirumab a drug according to Goldman Sachs analysts with "game changing commercial potential not widely recognised in brokers forecasts " and highlighted as one of 10 in a recent report in Scrip, has reported additional data from the phIII REGARD study in gastric cancer at the recent ASCO Gastrointestinal Cancer Symposium in San Franscisco.

The double-blind, international Phase III REGARD trial in 355 patients with metastatic gastric or gastroesophageal junction adenocarcinoma following disease progression on first-line platinum or fluoropyrimidine-containing combination therapy showed that 8 mg/kg IV ramucirumab every 2 weeks plus best supportive care (BSC) led to a median OS, the primary endpoint, of 5.2 months vs. 3.8 months for placebo plus BSC (p=0.0473). On secondary endpoints, ramucirumab plus BSC led to a median PFS of 2.1 months vs. 1.3 months for placebo plus BSC (p<0.0001). Additionally, ramucirumab led to a 12-week PFS rate of 40% vs. 16% for placebo and an ORR of 3.4% vs. 2.6% for placebo. Furthermore, ramucirumab led to a disease control rate (DCR) of 49% vs. 23% for placebo (p<0.0001). BSC included anti-emetic agents, opiate and non-opiate analgesic agents, appetite stimulants, and granulocyte and erythroid growth factors. Data were presented at the American Society of Clinical Oncology Gastrointestinal Cancers Symposium in San Francisco.

item.title: re: Recordati Enters Into Asset Purchase Agreement To Strengthen US Business
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Recordati Enters Into Asset Purchase Agreement To Strengthen US Business 
Comment: Recordati has acquired a portfolio of non-core products from Lundbeck, aimed at strengthen its US operations and its rare disease portfolio. Lundbeck, meanwhile, wishes to exit these areas to focus on its core CNS business.  ...
Recordati has completed its acquisition of a portfolio of H. Lundbeck’s non-core products. Recordati paid Lundbeck $80 million at closing. Recordati said it expects 2013 revenues for the acquired portfolio to be about $40 million.

item.title: Venom Peptide Therapeutic In-licensed By Kineta For Treatment Of Chronic Pain
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Kineta has secured exclusive, worldwide development rights from the University of Utah Research Foundation to a portfolio of drug candidates based on the Conotoxin Rg1a for the non-narcotic treatment of chronic pain.
Peptide Scource
Derived from the Rg1a peptide found in the venom of cone snails, these molecules were discovered in the laboratory of Baldomero Olivera, Ph.D. and are featured in an article in the February issue of National Geographic magazine.
Leveraging Its Core Competency
“This is a tremendous opportunity for Kineta to leverage its expertise in venom peptide therapeutics to provide a medical solution to an emergent need. We have in our hands the potential to replace some of the most dangerous and abused prescription drugs on the market - opioid analgesics including morphine and oxycontin. It is imperative that our industry develop treatments for chronic pain that are potent and effective without producing the destructive, sometimes deadly side-effects of opioid drugs,” said Shawn P. Iadonato, Ph.D., Kineta's Chief Scientific Officer and Executive Vice President. Dr. Olivera has an established record of discovering successful conotoxin-derived molecules; the FDA approved non-narcotic pain medicine Prialt® (Zicoconotide) is based on his laboratory's seminal work.
Press Coverage
The National Geographic story is a scientific overview of the therapeutic potential of venom that also features a second Kineta drug candidate, ShK-186. Derived from a venom peptide of the Caribbean Sea anemone, ShK-186 is Kineta's lead clinical stage autoimmune drug candidate. The National Geographic article highlights its ability to suppress self-reactive inflammatory processes in autoimmune diseases such as multiple sclerosis and lupus without shutting down the entire immune system. ShK-186 was originally developed in the lab of K. George Chandy, M.D., Ph.D. at the University of California, Irvine who is quoted in the article as saying “¦ anecdotal reports from patients in the field have been inspiring to my team, and encourage us to fully explore venom as a wellspring of potential new therapies.” Kineta obtained development rights and has advanced ShK-186 into Phase 1 human clinical trials.
Source:www.kineta.com

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: The Success Of Yervoy - Next Indications For Which Potentially Include CRPC
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: During its Q4 earnings call BMS focused on the success of Yervoy (ipilumumab), sales of which topped $700m in 2012, making the drug one of the best oncology launches over the last decade behind that of Zytiga (abiraterone).
Yervoy Sales
Yervoy is commercialised both in the US and Europe for the treatment of metastatic melanoma. Quarterly sales are now running at $211m +18% sequentially vs. Q3 with $141m generated from sales in the US. Geographic roll-out within Europe is ongoing. The product is selling well in the UK and Germany whilst formulary access in other countries continues to expand.
Next Indications
With regard to follow-on indications the following comments were made:-
"We do have Phase III trials in multiple indications including adjuvant melanoma, two trials in prostate cancer and you mentioned yes, one of them should have data internally at BMS in H1 and hopefully we’ll find a way to present that this year at a conference. And the one the will be coming due first is a Phase III trial in castrate-resistant post-docetaxel prostate cancer. And these are patients who have progressed on that taxane. It was initiated in 2009, we project to have the number of events to analyze and present this year.

"The other trial (chemonaive CRPC) will take longer. We have two trials also in lung cancer, one in non-small cell lung cancer, one in small cell lung cancer. We are doing combination therapy with other chemotherapy agents and we are actively exploring studies in other tumor types with the National Cancer Institute."

Source: www.bms.com


Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Threshold and Merck KGaA Progress with Their Pancreatic Cancer Program
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Merck initiated the global Ph3 MAESTRO trial assessing TH-302 + gemcitabine in patients with previously untreated, locally advanced unresectable or metastatic pancreatic adenocarcinoma. The study is conducted under a SPA with the US FDA. The primary endpoint is OS.
Title: MetastAtic or unrESectable pancreaTic adenocaRcinOma
Design: randomized, placebo-controlled, international multi-center, double-blind
Recruitment: approx. 660
Secondary endpoints include efficacy measured by PFS, ORR and disease controlrate, as well as assessments of safety and tolerability, PK and biomarkers.
See Oncology8475: OS Advantage Remains Elusive In Pancreatic Cancer Study But Threshold Blames Trial Design.
Feb. 2012 - Merck KGaA signed a global license and co-development agreement for TH-302 with Threshold, which includes an option for Threshold to co-commercialize in the US.

item.title: US Defence Funding For Acorda's New Spinal Cordy Injury Drug
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Acorda Therapeutics, has been awareded a $2.67m research grant by the U.S. Army Medical Research and Material Command (USAMRMC) to support development of AC105, a propriety magnesium formulation being studied as a treatment for acute spinal cord injury.
The contract will help support a Phase 2 clinical trial designed primarily to assess the safety and tolerability of AC105 in people with acute SCI. The Company plans to open enrollment for this study in the first half of 2013.
Basis For Funding
In preclinical studies, AC105 demonstrated neuroprotective properties and improvement of locomotor function in SCI when therapy was initiated within several hours of injury.
Next Steps
The US FDA has granted the drug Fast Track designation to improve functional recovery of acute SCI patients. Acorda expects to apply for FDA orphan drug designation for the acute treatment of SCI and will explore orphan drug designations in Europe and in other parts of the world.
About Spinal Cord Injury (SCI)
Spinal cord injury (SCI) refers to any injury to the spinal cord that is caused by trauma, such as a motor vehicle accident, fall or sports injury. According to the National Spinal Cord Injury Statistical Center (NSCISC), there are approximately 270,000 people in the United States living with a spinal cord injury. Each year, there are approximately 12,000 new injuries reported in the United States, the majority of which are males. Spinal cord injuries primarily affect young people, with 50-70% occurring in those aged 15-35.
The costs of living with SCI can be considerable and can vary greatly with the severity of injury. Long-term complications from SCI can include neurologic impairments in any body system controlled by the affected nerves. Average annual medical cost for an SCI patient ranges from $40,000-$178,000 depending on the extent of the injury.
There are currently no FDA-approved therapies indicated to treat, mitigate, or reverse SCI.
Source: www.acorda.com

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: re: Watson on Track to Buy European-Based Actavis for Around $6bn
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Watson on Track to Buy European-Based Actavis for Around $6bn 
Comment: The deal would further diversify Watson's generic footprint in the EU, and help the company to compete more effectively against Teva and Sandoz.  ...
Watson Pharmaceuticals has announced that the company has adopted Actavis, Inc. as its new global name and will today begin trading under the symbol — ACT — on the New York Stock Exchange. The combination created the world's 3rd largest generic pharmaceutical company, with anticipated pro forma combined 2012 revenues in excess of $8 billion.
On Jan 23rd, Watson completed the acquisition of Belgium-based Uteron Pharma SA for $150M in cash up front, and up to $155 million in potential future milestone payments.
Rationale
The acquisition of Uteron expands Watson's Global Brands pipeline of Women's Health products including two potential near term global commercial opportunities in contraception and infertility, and one novel oral contraceptive, projected to launch globally in 2018. Several additional products in earlier stages of development are also included in the acquisition.
Source: Actavis; Watson

item.title: Key Takeaways from Amgen Q4:12 and FY:12 Results
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Product sales grew 9% for the full year and 11% for the fourth quarter, driven by the solid contributions of Enbrel (the clear outperformer). On the plus side, XGEVA/Prolia re-accelerated with 19% QoQ growth to $369MM. R&D strategy will be disclosed on Feb 7 at the company's upcoming business review.
When it comes to XGEVA, management reported that "... as we approach the patent expirey for zoledronic acid, we expect there'll be some temporary disruption in the marketplace, both as a result of competitive activities and some reimbursement considerations. But we continue to be very confident on XGEVA's superior clinical profile and the benefit that it actually delivers to patients".
In the EU, the launch is continuing strongly with 23% QoQ growth to $37MM bolstered by recent reimbursement approvals in France, Italy and Spain.
Generic Zometa (in H:2 13) remains a near term risk although preference for XGEVA’s subQ administration over IV may offer a near-term buffer to erosion.

item.title: Novartis Q4 Figures - Key Takeaways
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Demonstrating resilience in the face of its patent cliff, Novartis has reported a solid set of year-end figures with sales flat in constant currencies and operating income and net income down 2% and up 7% respectively. The resignation of Chariman Danielle Vasella from the board is also noteworthy as is yet further confirmation that the group expects FDA action on Signfor for acromegaly in 2H13.
2012 Business Profile
Pharmaceutical Business Highlights
Sandostatin sales for the full year increased by 8% ar CC to$1.512bn with sales up 13% in the US to $649m and up 5% outside the US to $863m.
Novartis claims that there are now 29 countries that have an amended label for Sandostatin LAR including delay of disease progression in patients with advanced NET of mid-gut or unknown origin and that its new formulation of the drug is approved in 26 countries

item.title: NICE is Still not Backing Pierre Fabre's Javlor
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: NICE made the same decision in November 2012, but Pierre Fabre won a partial appeal against this decision. However NICE still did not find in favour of Javlor (for advanced/metastatic transitional cell carcinoma of the urothelial tract).
Javlor, compared with best supportive care (BSC), would have a QALY in excess of £120,000 (far higher than the normal threshold of £20,000-£30,000 per QALY gained).

item.title: Progenics To Buy Radiopharmaceutical Company Molecular Insight
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: In an all-stock transaction, Progenics Pharma has acquired Molecular Insight Pharmaceuticals, Inc. a private company specialising in radiopharmaceutical products for the treatment/diagnosis of prostate and adrenal cancer (phaeochromocytoma).
Deal Rational
The acquisition broadens Progenics oncology pipeline adding later-stage assets and deepening the company's strategic focus on the PSMA antigen, which it believes shows great promise as an oncology target.
Company Profiles
Progenics is a US biopharmaceutical company that in 2011 had revenues of $84m. It has one commercialised product Relistor which was outlicenced for commercialisation purposes to Salix Pharmaceuticals.
Molecular Insight is a US clinical stage biopharmaceuticalo company that exited Chapter 11 in May 2011 as a private company with a new board. Strategically it realligned its business to focus on the discovery development and commercialisation of radiopharmaceutical for molecular imaging and targeted radiotherapy of prostate cancer.
Azedra™ radiotherapy for pheochromocytoma and potential other neuroendocrine indications
  • "Compelling data" obtained from a phase 2 registrational trial for pheochromocytoma, an ultra-orphan adrenal tumor indication
  • Is in development under a Special Protocol Assessment with the U.S. Food and Drug Administration using a surrogate marker registrational endpoint
  • Potential for use in neuroblastoma and other neuroendicrine diseases
Trofex™ imaging agent with potential to alter clinical practice in treating prostate cancer
  • Phase 2 study ongoing in metastatic prostate cancer
  • Highly sensitive and selective radioisotope small molecule targeting PSMA uses technetium-99m for metastatic and localized prostate cancer imaging and detection
  • Designed as an improved imaging agent that identifies cancer cells in soft tissue and bone, where current agents are insufficient
Commenting on this Product Robert Israel Senior VP-Medical Affairs & Clinical Research stated: "Results thus far suggest that this agent may have sensitivity and specificity substantially beyond currently available options. We expect this imaging product to complement our PSMA ADC program by facilitating its path to market and enhancing its value once marketed."
MIP-1466 small molecule therapeutic for metastatic prostate cancer and other PSMA-expressing cancers
  • Targets the PSMA antigen with a radioactive payload
  • In preclinical development with evidence of dose-dependent enhanced tumor kill and prolonged survival in animal models of human prostate cancer
  • Investigator-initiated study in Germany of men with late-stage metastatic prostate cancer demonstrated tumor reduction for more than 14 days and a greater than 50% decrease in PSA levels in eight of 14 evaluable patients.
Deal Terms
Under the terms of the all-stock transaction, Progenics exchanged 4,566,210 shares of its common stock (8.9% of the total outstanding post-transaction shares) for all of the outstanding shares of Molecular Insight, which will become a wholly-owned subsidiary of Progenics. Molecular Insight has no debt. Progenics may make additional milestone payments to the former owners of Molecular Insight based on future commercial sales of the company's compounds. No royalties are due to the former owners of Molecular Insight.
Source:www.progenics.com

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Allergan Enhances Position in Migraine with MAP Pharma Buy
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: MAP Pharma is developing LEVADEX, an orally inhaled drug for migraine in adults. The drug is currently under review with the FDA (decision around April 15th). Allergan expects to fund the deal (about $598M) with a combination of cash on hand, cash equivalents and short-term borrowing.
The per share cash offer price ($25.00) represents:
  • 60% premium over MAP's closing stock price on the NASDAQ of $15.5 (on Jan. 22, 2013).
  • total equity value of approx. $958M
Close date of the acquisition: Q2:13.
  • To capitalize on specialty business (neurology and pain specialists)
  • To complement BOTOX® migraine franchise (Allergan has received regulatory approvals in 56 countries for BOTOX® for chronic migraine)
  • To use MAP's proprietary drug particles and inhalation technologies to generate new pipeline opportunities (D2/D3 agonist for PD and for epilepsy)
Assuming this transaction closes as planned, and approval of LEVADEX® occurs on or before the PDUFA date of April 15th, 2013, Allergan anticipates that this transaction will be dilutive to 2013 earnings per share by approximately $0.07 and accretive to earnings per share by the second half of 2014.
Management indicated launch of LEVADEX 'would be quicker than Botox. The reason being on the Botox side being an injectable, we actually to have train the physicians how to administer the product, where as in the case of this product it is prescribed, and, of course, really the only education piece is making sure then the patients know how to fire the Tempo inhaler, which isn't that complicated, but still is something we would pay attention to'.
When questionned on the launch of LEVADEX in interational markets, management reported that 'Canada is the largest market for Allergan outside the United States. And also we're in full launch phase of Botox, private pay space, which is actually for myself, even larger than I had initially assumed. And then, of course, will you all know from any drug launch in Canada it takes awhile to he get through all the different provincial formularies. If we look further afield, particularly to Europe, the real issue is will public payers be willing to pay for such a technology, and there we've started doing some work. I would say, however, I put a note of caution on that, given what's going on with reimbursement in Europe, and I won't refer to all the various I am ped did Iments. So we'll look at it carefully but I would say this will be relative to other programs or products launched by Allergan much more skewed to North America than is normal'.
When it comes to intellectual property, D. Pyott highlighted that 'the patents go out to 2028. This is the case where this whole inhalation technology is quite unique, quite complex, and therefore we feel really good about its protectability'.
Recent article in TRACTION CI, please See Neurology6660: MAP Resubmission Accepted By The FDA.
Jan. 2011 Allergan and MAP were to co-promote LEVADEX to neurologists and pain specialists in U.S. and share profits 50-50 from U.S neurologist and pain specialist sales (MAP would retain U.S. primary care and all ex-U.S. rights). Allergan was to record its share of net profits in “other revenues.
Source: Allergan; MAP Pharm.; ThomsonOne

item.title: JNJ - Q4 Results Key Takeaways
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Full year sales advanced 3.4% to $65bn (+6.1% CER) with growth driven by Pharmaceuticals +6.8% and Medical Devices ~& Diagnostics (+8.7%) whilst consumer sales remained flat. Zytiga (abiraterone) was a strong contributer to Pharmaceutical growth with sales in the full year reaching $961m. With both post and pre-chemotherapy usage now approved, the next indication JNJ is looking to tackly is hormone niave metastatic patients in combination with androgen deprivation therapy.
Business Profile
Primary contributors to operational sales growth were REMICADE® (infliximab), a biologic approved for the treatment of a number of immune-mediated, inflammatory diseases; VELCADE® (bortezomib), a treatment for multiple myeloma; PREZISTA® (darunavir), a treatment for HIV; and a number of recently launched products including Zytiga (abirarterone).
Zytiga achieved operation sales growth or over 75%, with US sales growing 34.1% and sales outside the US more than doubling.
Key Pipeline Developments
Focusing on innovation JNJ also highlighted its late stage pipeline (see below) which as you will note includes a development plan for Zytiga in hormone naive patients with metasatic disease.

The purpose of this study NCT01715285 is to determine if newly diagnosed (within previous 3 months) patients with metastatic hormone-naive prostate cancer (mHNPC) who have high-risk prognostic factors will benefit from the addition of abiraterone acetate and low-dose prednisone to androgen deprivation therapy. The study will recruit 1270 patients starting this year and scheduled to complete in terms of primary endpoint (overall survival) in July 2018. The study will be an international study run outside of the US.

With regard to its R&D spend, Alex Gorsky Vice Chairman Executive Committee
"The R&D spending is at the higher end of the industry norm although there are other innovators in pharma that also spend at that high level. So we view ourselves as an innovator in pharma and for that, you should expect us to be spending at the higher level and quite frankly, with the productivity that our R&D organization in pharma has been able to deliver, that’s a fantastic investment from my point of view. Overall, for the enterprise, we tend to average an R&D spend as a percent of sales higher than our competitive set blended. Again, that’s a much more capital-efficient way of growing our business. As long as that’s productive, we’re happy to invest at higher levels than our competitors. We’ve got to find ways to fund that and you saw that that’s what we did by a significant reduction in the SG&A costs. So as long as our R&D is productive and we can bring innovation to the marketplace, we’re happy to spend more than the industry in that regard and then obviously then to hopefully grow at a rate faster than our competitors as well."
Interestingly, the group plans to host a Pharmaceutical Business Review in the spring on May 23rd.
Source: www.jnj.com

item.title: Takeda Reinforces Business Structure in China
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Takeda has launched a new trading company, which began operations this month. Takeda China Internation Trading Co., Ltd (TCIT) will serve as a central hub for importing Takeda products from the company's global manufacturing sites.
Local integration of Nycomed.
To complete liquidation of Nycomed Shanghai (end of March 2015).
China is Takeda's seventh largest market by revenue, and a cornerstone of the company's strategy to grow in emerging markets. It is expected to be second largest globally by 2016.
Takeda is outpacing the market growth in China, with the highest market share among Japanese pharmaceutical companies in the country. The Company aims to achieve top line growth of 29% CAGR between 2012-2016.
Will import finished products from Takeda global manufacturing sites and transfer them to TCIT.
  • Establishment: September 2012 (capital paid in October 2012)
  • Start of operation: January 2013
  • Location: Shanghai Waigaoqiao Free Trade Zone
  • Capital Stock: 8.4 million USD
Source: Takeda

item.title: Health Canada to Request Revision of Product Labels for Botulinum Toxin Products
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: To help prevent medication errors, all manufacturer of botulinum products are to revise their product labels to reflect that each product has its own individual potency and as such is not interchangeable with other botulinum products. Manufacturers will have one year to comply with the labelling change requests.
  • Botox is indicated for the treatment of severe muscle spasm in the neck, eye and foot, for chronic migraines, incontinence, and for excessive sweating.
  • Botox Cosmetic is indicated for cosmetic purposes, to treat facial wrinkling.
  • Dysport is indicated for the temporary improvement in the appearance of moderate to severe wrinkles in adult patients less than 65 years of age.
  • Xeomin is indicated for severe muscle spasm in the neck, eye and arm.
  • Xeomin Cosmetic is indicated for the temporary improvement of moderate to severe frown lines in adult patients.
  • Myobloc is indicated for the treatment of adult patients with severe muscle spasm in the neck.

The Gablofen prefilled syringe was created to reduce preparation steps, helping to simplify the pump refill process for patients receiving ITB TherapySM (Intrathecal Baclofen Therapy) to treat severe spasticity of cerebral and spinal origin.

item.title: re: Impax Pharmaceuticals Announces Extension of RytaryTM FDA Review Date
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Impax Pharmaceuticals Announces Extension of RytaryTM FDA Review Date 
Comment: Impax Pharmaceuticals has announced that the U.S FDA has extended the PDUFA date for its review of the RytaryTM (IPX066) NDA from October 21, 2012, to January 21, 2013 due to the submission by Impax of information on an excipient in the RytaryTM formulation.  ...
Impax failed to win U.S. approval for a new version of an extended-release drug used to relieve spasms in patients with Parkinson’s disease. The US Agency requires a re-inspection of a plant involved in the development of Rytary, which combines standard Parkinson’s medications in a new sustained release formulation.
Piper Jaffray Forecasts
The medication would likely be used most among patients for whom the standard medicines, levodopa and carbidopa, have stopped working as reliably
Analyst with Piper Jaffray & Co. predicts Rytary could generate peak sales of $200 million to $300 million.

item.title: FDA Approves New Ulcerative Colitis Drug
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The FDA has approved an NDA from Santarus for Uceris budesonide to induce remission of mild to moderate active ulcerative colitis.
Santarus said it plans to launch Uceris in the U.S. in March.
The company has not yet determined the price but estimates Uceris will cost
around $40 a day. Santarus has U.S. rights from Italian company Cosmo to the product which is budesonide delivered using Cosmo’s MMX multi-matrix system
technology.
In August, the Netherlands Medicines Evaluation Board decided not to approve an MAA for the product. The MAA was submitted under the EU’s decentralized procedure, with the Netherlands acting as the reference member state. Ferring has rights to the product from Cosmo outside of the U.S. and Japan.
Source: santarus.com

item.title: Biscayne Pharm. Closes $1.5M Financing to Develop GHRH Drugs
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Biscayne Pharmaceuticals, a privately biopharm. company discoverig and developing novel therapies based on GHRH analogs, is developing novel GHRH drugs based on recent discoveries by Dr. Andrew Schally. The company has exclusively licensed IP from the U. of Miami that includes WW rights to the Schally GHRH technology, including GHRH antagonists and GHRH agonists.
Biscayne's lead GHRH antagonist is in PC development, initially for CRPC.
The company's GHRH agonists have demonstrated capacity to repair the heart following ischemic injury.
The Reich Group, based in Miami Beach (Floria), led the financing.
HQ: Miami, FL.
CEO: Samuel Reich, managing partner of the Reich Group.
The company's technology stems from the discoveries of Dr. A. V. Schally

item.title: FDA Approves Botox For iOAB as Allergan Launches New PhIII trial
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: On Friday Allergan received FDA approval to expand Botox's label to include patients with idiopathic overactive bladder who do not repond to existing medications. The timing is in line with expectations and follows European approval in December.
to be more specific the agency has said that Botox can be used to treat symptoms of overactive bladder including urinary incontinence, feeling a sudden and urgent need to urinate and frequent urination in patients who can't use or don't respond adequately to anticholinergic medications.
Launch of New Study
Coinciding with this approval, Allergan has launched a new phIII study to evaluate the efficacy and safety of Botox in combination with solifenacin in patients with overactive bladder and urinary incontinence. See Neurology6751: Botox and Solifenacin in Patients With OAB and Urinary Incontinence.
The randomised 345 patient study will evaluate the number of episodes of urinary incontinence and percentage of patients who are 100% dry over a 12 week period. The study is scheduled to complete in December 2014.
Including this indicatrion Botox is now approved for 26 different indications in more than 85 countries
Source: www.allergan.com

item.title: Merz's Extended Version 2011/12 Annual Report
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: In its extended 2011/12 annual report which has just been released, Merz suggests that it is likely to face more litigation in the US market in the coming year (2012/13) relating to botulinum toxins and aesthetics particularly with regard to trade secrets.
Management assumes that the injunction improsed by the ruling about alleged abuse of business secrets by Merz US companiesIt "should not last beyond 2013 and that its products should be able to be marketed without further restriction from thereon." We believe its comments relate to fiscal 12/13 which extends to June 2013.
With regard to Xeomin it notes that Merz Pharma will further build on its position as a specialist provider in the field of Neurology with Xeomin for the indication dystonia and spasticity. In the US it claims that it will continue to invest heavily in successfully positioning Xeomin on the market after its market launch. For further growth it notes that it willl be particuarly important to obtain expanded approvals in the US, Canada and Brazil as planned.
It suggests that the full potential of botulinum toxin has yet to be captured in manneurology. Its stated objective is to broaden the range of indicationy aresa of specials It notes that it also improved its market share during the year particularly in Germany where its share of the market rose from 25% to 29%. due to the size of the global market it claims to expect substantial growth in future years
The company notes that one of the most important growth driver for the company is its aesthetic business and that building up this business has been one of its prime goals during the last reporting year.
Source: Merz 2011/12 Annual Report

The company’s rock-bottom valuation had risesn by 15% ahead of the approval and yesterday soared by another 40%.
Given NuPathe’s limited cash and no immediate plans actually to launch Zecuity, its top priority now must be to sign a licensing deal.

item.title: The European Medicines Agency (EMA) is seeking views on proposed changes to the way it assesses cancer drugs
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment : The European Medicines Agency released early January a new guideline aiming to provide guidance on the development of medicinal products for use in anti-cancer indications. It underlines the importance of exploratory studies to properly define the most appropriate target population and puts further emphasis on the role of biomarkers. The draft guideline also covers companion diagnostics, and says their development should be considered early in clinical development, maximising the clinical application of the technology.
The guideline, adopted by the EMA during the 15 December 2011 meeting of the Committee for Medicinal Products for Human Use (CHMP), aims to provide guidance on the development of medicinal products for use in anti-cancer indications. More specifically, the guideline provides clarity on:
  • proper dosing of anticancer products
  • proper scheduling of anticancer products
  • optimizing the benefit of a product to patients by identifying the optimal target population
  • conducting studies on combination therapies
It provides condition specific guidance for non-small cell lung cancer, prostate cancer, chronic myeloid leukemia, myelodysplastic syndromes, and hematopoietic stem cell transplantation.
The guideline was released with an accompanying appendix, titled, Methodological consideration for using progression-free survival (PFS) or disease-free survival (DFS) in confirmatory trials, which provides guidance on endpoint definitions, frequency and methods of assessment, ascertainment bias, handling of deviations and missing data, and radiology review.
From both a clinical and a methodological perspective, the most persuasive outcome of a clinical trial is the demonstration of favorable effects on overall survival. Prolonged progression-free survival and disease-free survival are also considered to be of benefit to the patient.
Consultations are due by 31 May, 2012. The guideline will come into effect on 1 July.
Sources : Scrip 16 January and Regulatory Focus 5 January
See :
  • EMA - Guideline on the evaluation of anticancer medicinal products in man
  • EMA - Appendix 1 to the guideline on the evaluation of anticancer medicinal products in man

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: re: Kinex' Src kinase inhibitor Enter Ph2 in Patients with Prostate Cancer
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Kinex' Src kinase inhibitor Enter Ph2 in Patients with Prostate Cancer 
Comment: The Ph2 trial will assess the safety and efficacy of KX2-391 in patients with bone-metastatic, castrate-resistant prostate cancer (CRPC).  ...
KX2-391 dosed at 40 mg twice-daily lacks antitumor activity in men with CRPC, but has modest effects on bone turnover markers. Because a C (max) of ≥142 ng/mL is required for tubulin polymerization inhibition (defined from preclinical studies), higher once-daily dosing will be used in future trials.

METHODS: We treated 31 patients with oral KX2-391 (40 mg twice-daily) until disease progression or unacceptable toxicity. The primary endpoint was 24-week progression-free survival (PFS); a 50 % success rate was pre-defined as clinically significant. Secondary endpoints included PSA progression-free survival (PPFS) and PSA response rates. Exploratory outcomes included pharmacokinetic studies, circulating tumor cell (CTC) enumeration, and analysis of markers of bone resorption [urinary N-telopeptide (uNTx); C-telopeptide (CTx)] and formation [bone alkaline phosphatase (BAP); osteocalcin].

RESULTS: The trial closed early after accrual of 31 patients, due to a pre-specified futility rule. PFS at 24 weeks was 8 %, and median PFS was 18.6 weeks. The PSA response rate (≥30 % decline) was 10 %, and median PPFS was 5.0 weeks. Additionally, 18 % of men with unfavorable (≥5) CTCs at baseline converted to favorable (<5) CTCs with treatment. The proportion of men with declines in bone turnover markers was 32 % for uNTx, 21 % for CTx, 10 % for BAP, and 25 % for osteocalcin. In pharmacokinetic studies, median C (max) was 61 (range 16-129) ng/mL, and median AUC was 156 (35-348) ng h/mL. Common toxicities included hepatic derangements, myelosuppression, fatigue, nausea, and constipation.

Cancer Chemother Pharmacol. 2013 Jan 13. [Epub ahead of print]

A phase 2 study of KX2-391, an oral inhibitor of Src kinase and tubulin polymerization, in men with bone-metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer.

Antonarakis ES, Heath EI, Posadas EM, Yu EY, Harrison MR, Bruce JY, Cho SY, Wilding GE, Fetterly GJ, Hangauer DG, Kwan MF, Dyster LM, Carducci MA.

Source : Prostate Cancer Research Program, Sidney Kimmel Comprehensive Cancer Center at Johns Hopkins, 1650 Orleans Street, CRB1-1M45, Baltimore, MD, 21231-1000, USA, eantona1@jhmi.edu.

item.title: Versartis Closed $25M Series C Financing
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The primary use of the proceeds will be to fund clinical trials of VRS-317 (monthly form of rhGH), currently in Ph1b/Ph2a for growth hormone deficiency in paediatric patients.
See Endocrinology7142: First Pediatric Trial with Versartis' Once-Monthly rhGH.
In October 2012 the company started its first pediatric clinical trial of VRS-317 in pre-pubertal children with Growth Hormone Deficiency (GHD).
The Versartis Trial In Children to Assess Long-Acting Growth Hormone (VERTICAL) study is being conducted in approx. 30 sites in the US, and was initiated following the successful completion of a Ph1 study in adults with GHD.
The VERTICAL study is designed in 2 stages:
  • the first stage (Ph1b) utilizes an ascending-dose design to evaluate the safety and tolerability of up-to-four dosing levels of a single subcutaneous (SC) dose of VRS-317.
  • the second stage (Ph2a) will further study these patients to determine the efficacy of VRS-317 as defined by an increase in height velocity over six months of treatment.

item.title: Astellas' ASP-1707 (GnRH Antagonist) Now in Ph2 for Endometriosis Associated Pain
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The Ph2 trial will recruit approx. 600 pre-menopausal women, with confirmed length and regular menstrual cycle, surgically diagnosed endometriosis and moderate-to-severe endometriosis related pain. Primary endpoint will assess change from baseline to the end of 12 weeks treatment of pain score.
Abbott's Elagolix is the most advanced (NDA filing/Launch planned in 2016).
Title: A Randomized, Double-blind, Placebo-controlled, Phase 2 Study to Assess the Efficacy, Safety, and Dose-Response Relationship of ASP1707 in Subjects With Endometriosis Associated Pelvic Pain for 12 Weeks, Followed by a 12-Week Double-blind Extension Without Placebo Control, Including a 24-Week Open-Label Leuprorelin Acetate Treatment Group for Bone Mineral Density Assessment.
Completion dates: June 2014
Location: Japan

item.title: Botox and Solifenacin in Patients With OAB and Urinary Incontinence
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Clinicaltrials.gov is listing a new Ph3, which will be starting next month and assessing number of episodes of urinary incontinence and percentage of participants who are 100% incontinence-free/dry as primary endpoints. Locations of the trial include US, Belgium, Canada, Czech Rep., France, Germany, Poland and the UK.
Recruitment: approx. 345 participants, with:
  • Symptoms of Overactive Bladder (OAB) (frequency/urgency) with urinary incontinence for at least 6 months
  • Inadequate response or limiting side effects with anticholinergics for the treatment of OAB
Completion dates: Dec 2014 / June 2015
Protocol : 3-arms (Botox; solifenacin, placebo).

item.title: New Senior Executive Team Structure at AstraZeneca
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The new, expanded membership of AstraZeneca’s Senior Executive Team, includes increased representation of the company’s scientific expertise, key products and key markets.
• Three senior R&D roles responsible for discovery and early stage development in small molecules; discovery and early stage development in biologics; and late stage development.
• Three roles representing the commercial regions: North America, Europe and International.
• A role responsible for global portfolio and product strategy, bridging between the R&D and sales organisation.
As a result of the changes, two senior roles – President of Research and Development, held by Martin Mackay, and Executive Vice President, Global Commercial, held by Tony Zook – have been eliminated. Martin Mackay and Tony Zook will leave the company at the end of January.
The full Senior Executive Team is as follows:
•Pascal Soriot Chief Executive Officer and Executive Director
•Simon Lowth Chief Financial Officer and Executive Director
•Mene Pangalos Executive Vice President, Innovative Medicines
•Bahija Jallal Executive Vice President, MedImmune
•Briggs Morrison Executive Vice President, Global Medicines Development
•Paul Hudson Executive Vice President, North America
•Ruud Dobber Executive Vice President, Europe
•Mark Mallon Executive Vice President, International
•David Smith Executive Vice President, Operations & IS
•Lynn Tetrault Executive Vice President, Human Resources & Corporate Affairs
•Katarina Ageborg Chief Compliance Officer
•Jeff Pott General Counsel
Source: PharmaLive

item.title: Expanded Chemonaive Label For Zytiga In The EU
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: J&J has announced that last Friday the European Commission granted expanded approval to Zytiga for use in combination with prednisone for the treatment of metastatic CRPC who are asymptomatic or mildly symptomatic after failure of ADT in whom chemotherapy is not indicated.
This approval has been expected within this timeframe. Previously the product has only been approved in Europe to treat men with CRPC whose disease has progressed on or after docetaxexl-based therapy. This indication was approved in the US late last year.
The basis for approval was the results from the phIII COU-AA-302 study which showed a statistically signficant improvement in PFS, a trend towards improved overall suvival and significant improvements in a number of secondary endpoints.
source: jnj.com

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Roche Hires Leading U.S Academic to Head pRED
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: John C. Reed, Chief Executive at Stanford-Burnham Research Intitute in California will take over as Head of Roche's Pharma Research and Early Development (pRED).
John C. Reed (54), who is an American citizen, earned his M.D. and Ph.D. at the School of Medicine of the University of Pennsylvania.
Prior to joining Roche he has been CEO at Sanford-Burnham Medical Research Institute in La Jolla, California. He is one of the world’s leading biomedical researchers with a focus on cancer, neuroprotection, autoimmunity, and other diseases. John Reed has authored several hundred medical research publications and is among the world’s most highly cited scientists for his research contributions.
He is an inventor of more than one hundred patents, a member of multiple scientific journal editorial boards, and the founder or co-founder of a number of biotechnology companies. He has also served on the Boards of Directors of several public biopharmaceutical and biotechnology companies.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: re: The Toxin Aesthetic Landscape
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
The Toxin Aesthetic Landscape 
Comment: You will find attached an overview of the competitive landscape compiled by the CI department in close collaboration with the Neurology Aesthetic Franchise. We hope you will find this a useful tool and feel more inclined to contribute to our internal knowledge of the toxin aesthetic area. By keeping us informed of developments in your countries, we can build our internal knowledge base, and together leverage the utility of the tool for everybody's benefit. Highlighted below is a small selection of some of the slides from the attached presentation.  ...
To respond one of the KIQs, PhII study demonstrated that Purtox has > 30-60 days longer duration than Botox with the optimal dose of Purtox 30U vs. Botox 20U (source Dr MAAS lecture at Toxins 2012).

item.title: Abiraterone + BEZ235 in mCRPC
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Recently listed in clinicaltrials.gov, this Ph1/Ph2 study designed in collaboration with Novartis and Stand Up to Cancer is to start this month. Primary endpoints will assess number of reported DLT of the combination, anti-tumour responses and response proportion as defined by a decline in PSA of >50%.
Recruitment: approx. 74
Design
  • Phase 1: This part of the study will determine what dose of BEZ235 is safe to give with a standard dose of abiraterone acetate and prednisone by administering different doses of BEZ235. This will help to find out what effects, good and/or bad, this combination has on CRPC.
  • Phase 2: This part of the study will measure the treatment effect of the combination of BEZ235 and abiraterone acetate/prednisone on CRPC.
Completion dates: Jan 2015 / Jan 2016.
BEZ235 is a potent pan-class I PI3K and mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR) inhibitor belonging to the class of imidazoquinoline derivatives.
Location: USA

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Dendreon Shares Jump As Bernstein Upgrades Stock To Outperform
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Bernstein analysts have signalled that they believe Dendreon's shares could be one of the best performing stocks in 2013 as they believe the prostate cancer vaccine PROVENGE will return to modest but steady growth.
Dendreon's shares lost 60% of their value last year due to disappointing sales of PROVENGE launched in April 2010. However, the analysts suggest the competitive environment is stabilizin, citing feedback from a survey with urologists who prescrive PROVENGE.
It is reported:-
"Our interviews all suggested steady increases in expected uses among busy community urology practices: none of the physicians expected to reduce their usage and most expected to use PROVENGE in combination with Xtandi in the future and saw little threat from Zytiga".
The brokers forecast growth for 2013 peak revenue of $799m for PROVENGE by 2017 and 13% sales.
See Oncology8707: Key Takeaways from Dendreon Preliminary Q4:12.
Source; www.reuters.com

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: 1st In Class SGLT2 Inhibitor Recommended For US Approval
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment:J&J announced last week that the Endocrinology & Metabolic Advisory Comittee of the FDA recommended 10-5 in favour of approval of its SGLT2 inhibitor canagliflozin for the treatment of type 2 diabetes. This represents a key development for other companies, most notably for Lexicon Pharmaceuticals.
Novel MOA
The SGLT2 class of agents is unique in that they block the reabsorption of glucose by the kidney, increasing its excretion and lowering blood glucose levels.
Scope of PhIII Programme & Key Findings
Data supporting the approval came from a comprehensice phIII programme which enrolled 10,285 patients in nine study, the largest late-stage development programme every undertaken for a diabetes product. The results of the studies shown that in addition to lowering blood glucose canagliflozin was also associated with reductions in weight loss and reductions in blood pressure.
Safety Issues
The drug has some specific safety issues such as genital mycotic infections and urinary tract infections which reportedly can be well managed by physicians.
Implications For Other Companies
At one time there was some scepticism about whether this class of agents would ever be approved. Possible hurdles now seem to have been overcome which is good news for other companies developing such agents such as GSK and Lexicon Pharmaceuticals and for the potential outlicensing of Lexicon's drug which appears as though it could be best-in-class.
Source: www.jnj.com

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Disappointment For Eisai in Ovarian Cancer
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Eisai announced on Friday the preliminary results of its global phIII study with its folate antagonists farletuzumab which regretably failed to meet its pre-specified endpoint of improvement in PFS in patieents with platinum sensitive epithelial ovarian cancer in first relapse. The company appears committed to further development in possible disease sub-sets.
Study Design
The study was a multicentre randomised double-blind placebo controlled parallel group study undertaken in 1,100 patients. The patients received standard of care therapy (carboplatin and a taxane) in combination with doses of either 1.25mg/kg or 2.5mg/kg or farletuzumab or placebo.
Key Findings
Whilst the primary endpoint was not met the post hoc exploratory analysis has showed a trend towards improved PFS in some patient sub-sets and further analysis of this data is ongoing. Once this is available the company will determine a new development strategy based on discussions with external experts and the relevant health authorities.
Source: www.eisai.com

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: re: Gattex for Short Bowel Syndrome at the Center of NPS' Presentation
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Gattex for Short Bowel Syndrome at the Center of NPS' Presentation 
Comment: At the J.P Morgan Conference, François Nader (President and CEO) highlighted high unmet medical need, burden of illness, clincial value and ultra-orphan status as key value framework for Gattex (the first and only analog of GLP-2 proven to increase absorption of remaining bowel and decrease or eliminate the need for parenteral support).  ...

SBS is perceived by physicians as one of the highest unmet needs in the field of GI conditions. This NPS assessment could directly benefit to SSAs including Somatuline.

If less than 1 meter of ileum is remaining after surgery, chronic intestinal failure is installed, making the patient dependent on parenteral nutrition for life.

Several clinical aspects must attract our interest:

- Despite they are malabsorptive, SBS patients are not “nil per os”. They could even ingest very large amounts of energy and liquids;

- Depending of patients GI functional capacities and for answering to nutritional needs, parenteral nutrition could be administered either to fulfill daily needs or just a part of these needs. Because of these different situations and related to respecting a “physiological” slow rate of infusion, patients could be fed all day long and every day , or “only” some days per week and/or some hours per days (in a cycling way, at night).

- So improving SBS is not only reducing the number of parenterally fed patients, but this could be also preserving for each patient, number of days or hours of freedom with no “line-attachment” or no infusion (meaning improving Quality of Life).

- Because SBS is a chronic condition, PN is given at home ( “HPN”) and today , there are registries for HPN patients in almost all EU countries. However it is important to take into consideration that the major part of HPN patients are not recorded in registries and this “hidden” part of SBS / HPN patients are postoperative patients suffering of digestive cancer. So the real number of SBS patients is in practice significantly larger than registered patients (but this actual number is unknown).

Taking as a whole, reducing fluid secretion, means improving SBS patient quality of life: patients can receive oral food, their transit and enterostomy fluid outputs can be reduced and parenteral nutrition and rehydration regimen as well as their potential risks (infection and metabolic) can be diminished. The main medical field is cancer.



Add a Comment on this Article

View thread Endocrinology7230: Gattex for Short Bowel Syndrome at the Center of NPS' Presentation

item.title: re: Aspireo Starts Ph2a Study with Somatoprim for Acromegaly
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Aspireo Starts Ph2a Study with Somatoprim for Acromegaly 
Comment: The Israeli biopharm company has enrolled its first patient in a Ph2a study designed to assess the safety, tolerability and efficacy of its drug in untreated acromegaly patients. Initial data from this study is expected to be available in the first quarter of 2013. Aspireo has been looking to partner this product for some while but has so far been unsuccessful, most probably because of the short patent life that remains.  ...
Besides Novartis SSAs ( Octreotide and Pasireotide) do we have a new competitor to Somatuline to consider ?
Somatoprim (DG3173) is a SSA developed by the Israeli biopharm company Aspireo (Project Focused Company ; www.aspireopharma.com).
As mentioned by Brigitte, Aspireo is looking for partnership, their only one current investor is TVM Capital.
Looking at Pubmed, there are currently only 3 referenced publications with a main one reporting a recent German in vitro study. ( Plöckinger et al, 2012 Charité Hosp, Berlin).
Regarding the results of this preclinical study and also a clinical Phase I single ascending dose study in HV, Somatoprim is described as follows
From International Journal of Endocrinology, 2012 : A recently developed somatostatin multireceptor ligand, Somatoprim, may be at least as potent, as Octreotide, but without a negative effect on glucose metabolism. This molecule has a GH suppressing effect but a very low insulin-suppressing action in vitro. If these in vitro data are confirmed in vivo in acromegalic patients, Somatoprim will be a valuable alternative to other SRL.
From Nature Review Endocrinology : Somatoprim causes greater GH suppression than octreotide when applied to primary cell cultures of somatotroph adenomas according to a German Study. In contrast to octreotide, somatoprim has a high affinity for SSTR3, in addition to SSTR2 and SSTR5. All analyzed adenomas highly exptessed SSTR3, the activation of which might have been responsible for the higher number of tumors responsive to somatoprim compared to octreotide. Previous studies have shown a very low insulin-suppressing effect of somatoprim (NB: leading to less risk of hyperglycemia), which is an advantage vs Pasireotide and Octrotide.
Prof Ursula Plöckinger : “If clinical trials confirm the in vitro data, we feel that the drug may well become the treatment of choice for medical therapy in acromegaly owing its high efficacy, potential for tumor shrinkage and its negligible effect on insulin secretion”.
Concerning the results of the clinical Phase I study: it is indicated that Somatoprim had an excellent tolerability profile at all doses administered. An exploratory analysis of plasma growth hormone levels was consistent with a suppression of growth hormone release thus indicating that Somatoprim is able to suppress growth hormone release in humans.
Finally, Somatoprim is also expected to enter in phase II for its development in GEP-NET.
Main Bibliographic References
U. Ploeckinger, U. Hoffmann, M. Geese et al., “DG3173 (Somatoprim), a unique Somatostatin receptor subtype 2-, 4- and 5-selective analogue, effectively reduces GH-secretion in human growth hormone secreting pituitary adenomas even in Octreotide non-responsive tumours,” European Journal of Endocrinology, vol. 166, no. 2, pp. 223–234, 2012.
Shimon I, Rubinek T, Hadani M, and Alhadef N, “PTR- 3173 (Somatoprim), a novel somatostatin analog with affinity for somatostatin receptors 2, 4 and 5 is a potent inhibitor of human GH secretion,” Journal of Endocrinological Investigation, vol. 27, no. 8, pp. 721–727, 2004.

item.title: Xiaflex's Uptake For Dupuytren's Contracture & Extended LifreCycle Management Opportunities In Urology & Aesthetics
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: At the JP Morgan H/C Conference this week Auxillium gave a detailed account of its commercialisation activities with Xiaflex for Dupuytren's Contracture and development prospects for other indications such as peyrone's disease, frozen shoulder and cellulitis. Some key comments about the termination of its relationship with Pfizer in Europe were also made particularly in relationship to the strategic flexibility this now gives ahead of the submission for peyrone's disease in Europe by the end of the year.
Highlighted below are some of the key slides that were presented.and some of theCEO's key comments made during the breakout session with regard to pricing in Europe and the mutual termination of its partnership with Pfizer in Europe covering Xiaflex.
During the breakout session an interesting question was posed about Xiaflex's pricing in Europe which prompted both a response about European pricing and Auxilium's relationship with Pfizer.

Q: Why are you selling XIAFLEX in Europe at about half the price of the U.S. and then still, you have to give a discount to Pfizer? That's one question. And the other question is German government has rejected your application for XIAFLEX under the grounds that it is not the newest technology. What do you do to still try to get into this basically most important market in Europe?

Adiran Adams CEO responded:-

"Yes, I think, I mean, there's a lot of, kind of, points to note in there. As it relates to price, I think – I don't think it would be wrong of me to say that it is not uncommon in a lot of different disease areas for the pricing, kind of broad structure in Europe to be quite different from the pricing structure within the United States."

"So, I think, obviously, decision making in relation to pricing, et cetera, was done obviously in concert with our partner , Pfizer n Europe for XIAFLEX. As you well know, I think we announced the mutual termination of the agreement wit h Pfizer in Europe. And we're having discussions with them in terms of a transition perspective ahead of the termination which is at the – towards the end of April of this year."

"Now, you are absolutely correct that everyone looks broadly across Europe, and particularly in the Scandinavian countries, a number of other countries, we've actually seen some good progress with XIAFLEX. But in some of the key markets of Germany and France, there have been some challenges in relation to securing the right reimbursement levels. And I think that is not in any way reflective of lack of focus by Pfizer"

"It's just that, as you well know, across a large number of products, not just specific to Auxilium and Pfizer and XIAFLEX, I think changing the goalpost in terms of what's needed to get to reimbursement approvals, et cetera, and putting in place certain challenges in relation to demonstrating difference versus current available treatment options, I think, is very challenging. And clearly, I think where we are right now with the mutual termination of the agreement with Pfizeris we see this as an opportunity, I think."

"We see this as an opportunity. We have the strategic flexibility now to either, one, consider whether there is a cost-effective, shareholder-friendly way of commercializing and distributing ourselves; or to assess whether or not there are other partners that we could work with. And certainly, we had a number of inbound interest calls in that area, which we're assessing at this particular point in time."

"We want to make sure that the decisions we make are the right, appropriate decisions. And I think we certainly see continued opportunity in Dupuytren's. And more certainly, I think, there is nothing impacting the momentum in relation to moving towards submitting the Peyronie's application in Europe towards the end of this year. So, I think from our perspective, particular with the corporate evolution here in the United States, we're happy to have the strategic flexibility in Europe that is now afforded."

item.title: Astellas Strengthens its UroOnco Position with EU Approval of Mirabegron for OAB
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: BETMIGA has received EU approval for the treatment of OAB symptoms in adults (data on file). The drug will offer doctors an alternative to antimuscarinic agents (the only class of approved oral treatment previously available).
Different Mechanism of Action
Mirabegron improves the storage capacity of the bladder without inhibiting bladder voiding, thereby prolonging the time between trips to the toilet for the patient ().
Quality of Life
Patients with OAB who received mirabegron reported significant improvements in treatment satisfaction, symptom bother, disease perception and quality of life, in comparison to placebo ().
Phase III study in China, Korea, Taiwan, and India recently completed.
Source: ASTELLAS

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Allergan to Advance Bimatoprost in Ph3 for Eyebrow Hypotrichosis
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The randomized trial will start in March 2013, and assess the safety and efficacy of the drug compared with placebo. Primary endpoint will measure percentage of participants with at least a 1-grade increase in the 4-point Global Eyebrow Assessment (GEBA) scale.
Completion date: Oct 2014 / Nov 2014
Recruitment: approx 348
Location: USA (1); Canada (1)
Please see Neurology6641: Allergan Progresses with Bimatoprost for Increasing Eyelash Growth.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Norwegian Directorate of Health Recommends Zytiga for National Cancer Treatment Guidelines
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The advisory group of Norway's Directorate of Health recommended yesterday (9 January) to insert Yervoy (ipilimumab; BMS, US) and Zytiga (abiraterone; J&J, US) into the national guidelines for cancer treatment. The advisory group has indicated the drugs for their beneficial effects in the treatment of specific cancer types. The experts have taken into consideration results of clinical trials that have demonstrated that Zytiga was found to prolong patients' life and improves overall patients' QoL in individuals suffering from prostate cancer.
According to the Directorate, the cost estimate of both drugs is between NOK750,000 (USD134,152) and NOK850,000 per quality-adjusted life year (QALY).
A final decision on the willingness of the community to pay for these drugs will be taken by the National Council for quality and prioritisation in health services.
The Directorate of Health requested in September 2012 that the NMA ascertain the cost-effectiveness of Zytiga for patients affected by prostate cancer. The recommendations issued by the advisory group need to now be examined by the Directorate for a final decision on admission of the two drugs on the national guidelines. A final decision of the regulatory body in favour of the insertion of Yervoy and Zytiga on the Norwegian cancer guidelines will clearly represent a major opportunity for BMS and J&J to further penetrate the Norwegian pharmaceutical market.
Source: Global Insight

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Amgen and BIND Biosciences Sign $180M Nanomedicine Deal
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: BIND's lead product candidate contains the chemotherapy docetaxel. Data from the ongoing Ph1, presented at AACR 2012, demonstrated safety and tolerability. The clinical-stage biopharmaceutical company plans to initiate Ph2 clinical trials in multiple solid tumor indications in 2013.
- Terms: W/W collaboration agreement to develop and commercialize a kinase inhibitor nanomedicine for treating a range of solid tumors.
- Financial: BIND could receive upfront and development fees of $46.5M, and > an additional $134M in regulatory and sales milestone payments for the 1st therapeutic indication.
- Accurin Platform
- employs a combination of a targeted biodegradable nanoparticle and docetaxel

item.title: Sarepta Look To Exploit New Regulatory Framework For Rare Debilitating Diseases
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Sarepta's presentation at the JP Morgan H/C Conference highlighted both the new regulatory framework that exists for companies trying to obtain expedited approval for rare diseases beyond HIV/AIDS that could be applicable to Eteplirsen and the commercial potential for its Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy drug, based on its positive phII data.
The results of Sarepta's phII data with Eteplirsen have been summarised previously (see Neurology6656: Sarepta Seeks Ex-US Partner For Its Duchenne Drug) however, in summary the company''s position with the drug is shown below.
What was interesting in terms of Sarepta's presentation was its focus on the new regulatory climate that exists for drugs like eteplirsen which the company is hoping to exploit in order to gain accelerated approval for Eteplirsen based on its strong phII data.
Commercial Potential In Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy Market
Next Steps
Competitive Outlook
Interestingly, Biocentury's reveiw of the approval outlook for 2013 included in its focus drugs for Duchenne Musuclar Dystrophy. It was noted that multiple programmes are maturing including those being undertaken by Sarepta Therapeutics Inc. Therapeutics Inc.

Apparently, Sarepta was one of the leading gainers in 2012, with its share price up more than 450%. In October, the company's market cap peaked at $1 billion after reporting additional data from a Phase IIb trial of its lead program eteplirsen, PTC Therapeutic's ataluren is under review in Europe for nonsense mutation DMD. This quarter, the company expects to start a confirmatory Phase III trial of the small molecule, which facilitates complete translation of proteins containing nonsense mutations for DMD.

Both companies will be competing against drisapersen (GSK2402968,PRO051) from GlaxoSmithKline plc oligonucleotide that induces exon 51 skipping on the dystrophin gene is in Phase III testing.

Source:www.sarepta.com

item.title: Exelixis - Key Takeaways From JP Morgan H/C Conference
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Exelixis's presentation focused on its commercialisation plans for COMETRIQ (cabozantinib) in medullary thyroid cancer and its expanded lifecycle development plan for the drug which is aimed at creating a major oncology franchise with an initial focus on prostate cancer. Top-line phIII data is expected in 2014.
Micahel Morrissey Exelixis's CEO emphasised the company's belief that cabozantinib is a unique compound especially in today’s age of researchers making single molecules targeting driver mutations in oncology for a single subset of a single indication with high-efficacy, but also a very narrow, Commercially. he believes Cabozantinib has the opportunity, of being a broadly active compound based upon existing Phase 2 data such as Taxotere or Avastin. MTC is just the start for the company with the bigger opportunities lying behind.
Commercialisation For MTC
The company has adopted a unique selling process for its first approved indication as shown below. The drug will be sold as a capsule configuration with three different doses that are flat priced at $9900 per 28-day supply. Commercial launch will take place in the very near future.
In terms of the prostate development programme top-line data is expected in 2014. Meanwhile, there is an interest in the company in terms of conducting combination trials with abiraterone and enzalutamide.in post and pre-chemo settings. Exelixis claims to have some early data from an IST and Dana Farber, which highlights the potential there and so it is devising a plan to conduct company sponsored randomized trials in that space.
Source:www.exelixis.com
