Comment: At the J.P Morgan Conference, François Nader (President and CEO) highlighted high unmet medical need, burden of illness, clincial value and ultra-orphan status as key value framework for Gattex (the first and only analog of GLP-2 proven to increase absorption of remaining bowel and decrease or eliminate the need for parenteral support).
See Endocrinology7210: NPS Sets Price for Newly Approved Gattex.

Comments

SBS is perceived by physicians as one of the highest unmet needs in the field of GI conditions. This NPS assessment could directly benefit to SSAs including Somatuline.

If less than 1 meter of ileum is remaining after surgery, chronic intestinal failure is installed, making the patient dependent on parenteral nutrition for life.

Several clinical aspects must attract our interest:

- Despite they are malabsorptive, SBS patients are not “nil per os”. They could even ingest very large amounts of energy and liquids;

- Depending of patients GI functional capacities and for answering to nutritional needs, parenteral nutrition could be administered either to fulfill daily needs or just a part of these needs. Because of these different situations and related to respecting a “physiological” slow rate of infusion, patients could be fed all day long and every day , or “only” some days per week and/or some hours per days (in a cycling way, at night).

- So improving SBS is not only reducing the number of parenterally fed patients, but this could be also preserving for each patient, number of days or hours of freedom with no “line-attachment” or no infusion (meaning improving Quality of Life).

- Because SBS is a chronic condition, PN is given at home ( “HPN”) and today , there are registries for HPN patients in almost all EU countries. However it is important to take into consideration that the major part of HPN patients are not recorded in registries and this “hidden” part of SBS / HPN patients are postoperative patients suffering of digestive cancer. So the real number of SBS patients is in practice significantly larger than registered patients (but this actual number is unknown).

Taking as a whole, reducing fluid secretion, means improving SBS patient quality of life: patients can receive oral food, their transit and enterostomy fluid outputs can be reduced and parenteral nutrition and rehydration regimen as well as their potential risks (infection and metabolic) can be diminished. The main medical field is cancer.

item.title: Merz Re-enters US Toxin Market
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Merz North America has announced that effective today, the court ordered injunction has been lifted and patients and physicians now have access to " a broader range of treatment options in aesthetic medicine, dermatology and neurology".
The press release states that:-
"The violations that led to this injunction were directly attributable to the acts of several individuals, and were entirely incompatible with Merz's culture. We accepted the injunction as a challenge to us to reinforce compliance training throughout the company and to re-imagine a company-wide compliance program. Last summer we directed all our efforts and resources toward the remediation process, and were pleased when the court agreed to a partial lift of the injunction in November 2012,” said Katrina Church, Vice President - Chief Compliance Officer of Merz, Inc. “We believe that compliance policies are an investment in our company's future.”
Merz North America is now permitted to sell and promote its entire portfolio of FDA-approved products, including XEOMIN® (incobotulinumtoxinA), BELOTERO BALANCE® Dermal Filler, and Radiesse® Volumizing Filler, in the U.S. with no restrictions imposed by the court order.
Source:www.merz.com

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: A Newly Formed Big Cap Pharma Highlights Its Strategic Ambitions
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The newly formed Abbvie, the pharmaceutical business spun out of Abbott gave its first presentation at the JP Morgan H/C conference yesterday. Hiighlighting were the key areas of product growth which includes a focus on endometriosis, uterine fibroids and Parkinson's disease.

item.title: Telormedix granted IND for Phase II Bladder Cancer Study
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Telormedix, a clinical stage biopharmaceutical company focused on TLR7 agonists has received FDA authorisation for Phase II trial of its lead product TMX-101, a TLR-7 agonist, in CIS (carcinoma in situ) in the bladder.
Next Steps
The planned Phase II study is due to commence in March 2013 and will involve a small number of CIS patients recruited from private urology clinics in the USA to examine at the efficacy of TMX-101 over six doses.
Supportive Data
Dr Johanna Holldack, CEO of Telormedix, commenting in the company's press release notes that:-
“Our recently completed safety trial of TMX-101 showed it induced a strong disease-modifying cytokine response in patients with non-muscle invasive bladder cancer (NMIBC). We have high hopes that this means TMX-101 will demonstrate disease modifying efficacy in CIS. “
Dr Stuart Holden, a prominent practicing uro-oncologist and Telormedix board member, added:
“We have known for many years that CIS patients respond well to immunotherapeutic interventions such as BCG. So there are already good reasons to be optimistic that TLR-7 mediated treatments such as TMX-101 will offer a new and effective clinical tool in the treatment of this aggressive carcinoma.”
Company Profile
Telormedix was founded in October 2007, is a biopharmaceutical company focused on targeted immunity and modulation of the innate immune system for treating cancer and autoimmune diseases. The Company’s lead product is TMX-101, In addition, Telormedix is developing novel TLR7-targeted agonists. One of these molecules, TMX-202, has recently been selected for preclinical study for the topical treatment of skin cancers and other indications. Telormedix also has a pipeline of programs for inflammatory and autoimmune diseases, which includes TMX-302, a TLR7-binding small molecule showing anti-inflammatory properties in vivo.
Located in Switzerland, Telormedix is led by a highly experienced management team and backed by an international consortium of venture capitalists including Aravis Venture (Basel, Switzerland) and Proquest Investments (Princeton-San Diego, USA).
Source: www.telormedix.com

item.title: Efficacy of Using Umbilical Cord Blood for Cerebral Palsy (CP)
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Cryo-Cell first results of a Ph2 study have been published in Stem Cells and conclude that umbilical cord blood (UCB) treatment ameliorated motor and cognitive dysfunction in children with CP undergoing active rehabilitation, accompanied by structural and metabolic changes in the brain.
- Recruitment: 96 children were treated (between the ages of 10 months and 10 years).
- Protocol: Patients were divided into 3 groups: those treated with HLA-matched cord blood from unrelated donor along with EPO - those treated with placebo + EPO - those treated with placebo alone.
- See full paper attached @1
Founded in 1989
Location: Tampa Bay Area in Florida (USA)
Became the first private cord blood bank in the world to separate and store stem cells

item.title: Novartis Strategy for Future Growth
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: At the J.P Morgan H/C Conference, Joseph Jimenez (CEO) outlined that '2013 will be a year of two halves'. The first one to be significantly impacted by the Diovan patent expiration. The second half begins the next growth phase, driven by launch products, emerging growth markets and lower impact of generics after 2013.
In terms of innovation, Novartis received 17 key approvals across its divisions and 9 positive Ph3 trials.
  • Afinitor in advanced breast cancer was approved in Europe and the US. Management believes that this will be a significant new indication for Afinitor and have pegged it over $1 billion for that one indication alone.
In terms of growth, newly launched products accounted for almost 30% of total group sales through the first three quarters.
Key Products
In terms of productivity, Novartis generated $900M in procurement savings, reduced marketing and sales as percent of sales.

item.title: Valeant's New Financial Guidance & Strategic Ambitions
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Valeant hosted a call with analysts on Friday to provide better guidance on the outlook for the new entity post the acquisition of Medicis. Top-line guidance seems to have been below consensus but cost synergies from the acquisition higher than anticipated. Management also appears to have floated the idea of a potential merger with a larger peer that could allow Valeant to maintain control as well as its tax rate.
CEO Mike Pearson envisions transforming Valeant from a $4.6bn company in 2013 to a $10-20bn revenue company "in the foreseeable future". While current leverage may preclude a transformative cash deal over the near term, Pearson believe that a merger of equals may allow for signficant value creation and deleveraging.

item.title: ASCO-GU Upcoming Data Of Significance
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Yesterday at the JP Morgan H/C Conference, Medivation confirmed that data from its phII hormone-naive trial with Xtandi (enzalutamide) will be presented for the first time at ASCO GU in February. This will be an important congress for prostate cancer data as additionally there will be CPRC data released from two phIII studies. One with Aflibercept (Zaltrap Sanofi) which is known not to have reached its primary endpoint and the other with dastinib (BMS) results of which are eagerly awaited.
Medivation Data
Medivation's Phase 2 hormone-naïve trial completed enrollment in January 2011. This trial enrolled 67 patients who are first-line (prior to even Lupron therapy). The primary endpoint is PSA response and the dose of enzalutamide being tested is 160 mg given once-a-day. The goal of this trial is to explore the use of enzalutamide in first-line patients.
The other new indication that Medivation is exploring in a phII setting is as a neadjuvant prior to prostatectomy. A phII trial in 50 patients started in this setting in June 2012.
BMS Data
Dasatinib (Sprycel, Bristol-Myers Squibb), approved for treatment of adults with newly diagnosed Philadelphia chromosome-positive chronic myeloid leukemia (Ph+ CML), demonstrated some encouraging results in a phase I-II study in 46 patients with CRPC. Dasatinib targets both the tumor and bone microenvironment in CRPC via the Src pathway,

In the phase I-II study, 18 of 30 patients with measurable disease had a partial PSA response.1 Treatment with dasatinib also resulted in improvement in bone markers, with 87% of patients experiencing decreases in urinary N-telopeptide and 76% showing a decrease in bone-specific alkaline phosphatase levels. The combination of dasatinib and docetaxel was generally well tolerated; 28% of patients had grade 3-4 toxicity.
The results led to the development of a phase III trial of docetaxel with and without dasatinib in 1500 patients with metastatic CRPC with evidence of progression. The trial’s primary endpoint is overall survival.
Sanofi Data
Sanofi will report in more detail the results of the VENICE trial at ASCO GU. This was a phIII trial that evaluated the effect of the angiogenic drug aflibercept (VEGF-trap) in first-line combination with docetaxel in 1,224 CRPC patients. Sanofi reported back in April 2012 that the study did not meet its primary endpoint in terms of efficacy i.e. an improvement in overall survival.
VEGF Trap, is an angiogenesis inhibitor with a unique mechanism of action. The fusion protein binds multiple forms of Vascular Endothelial Growth Factor-A (VEGF-A), as well as VEGF-B and placental growth factor (PIGF), additional angiogenic growth factors that appear to play a role in tumor angiogenesis and inflammation.
The results of this trial provide yet further evidence of the lack of benefit obtained with pure anti-angiogenic agents in the CRPC setting, with similar phIII trials undertaken with sunitinib and bevacizumab also having failed to demonstrate efficacy in CRPC patients.
Source: www.medivation.com and ASCO GU programme

item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:

Kendrick will handle corporate affairs and PR for Allergan’s medical aesthetics business, which includes Botox and dermal filler products, across the EMEA region.
Turkoglu will manage corporate affairs and PR for the firm’s neuroscience and ophthalmology business, including chronic migraine and overactive bladder conditions throughout the EMEA region.

item.title: Aspireo Reports Somatoprim Phase I b Interim Data
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The preliminary data confirms the safety profile of Somatoprim, with the maximum tolerated dose not reached. No serious adverse events were reported.
The single centre study is investigating the safety, side effect profile, as well as pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic profile of multiple ascending doses of Somatoprim in healthy male volunteers, when administered alone and in combination with octreotide.
Somatoprim also demonstrated a dose-dependent lowering effect on growth hormone, as shown by an analysis of the pharmacodynamic effect on hGH, when stimulated by growth hormone releasing hormone.
Aspireo expects final data to be available in Q2 2013.
See also Endocrinology7158: Aspireo Starts Ph2a Study with Somatoprim for Acromegaly
Source: Aspireo Pharmaceuticals 7 January 2013

item.title: New Friedreich Ataxia Drug Moves Into PhIIb
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Pricate company Edison Pharmaceuticals Inc has announced the initiation of a phIIb study entitled "Safety and efficacy of EPO-743 on visual function in patients with Friedreich's Ataxia
Study Design
The trial is a placebo-controlled study lasting six months, followed by an extension phase in which all subjects will receive EPI-743.
The primary endpoint of the trial is visual function, with sedonary endpoint including neurological and neuromuscular function.
Trial Logistics
The trial is being conducted with the assistance of investigators from the Friedreich's Ataxia Research Alliance (FARA) Clinical Research Network and FARA's Patient registry. Three clinical trial sites have been selected in the US: University of South Florida, Children's Hospital of Philadelphia and the University of California
What is EPI-743
It is an orally bioavailable small molecule which is a member of the para-benzoquinone class of drugs. It acts as a cofactor for a new drug target NADPH quinone oxidase. The drug augments endogenous glutathione biosynthesis - a process essential for the control of oxidative stress.
edspharma.com

item.title: Study: Cost Utility Analysis of Primary Treatments for Clinically Localised Prostate Cancer
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Analysis of 232 papers published in the last decade that report results from clinical studies following patients with low-, intermediate- and high-risk forms of prostate cancer who were treated with one or more of the standard treatments. Costs were determined from the USA payer perspective.
Overall, the analysis showed small differences in outcomes and substantial differences in payer and patient costs across treatment alternatives.
The analysis shows that for people with low-risk prostate cancer, the various forms of treatment vary only slightly in terms of survival, but the cost of radiation therapy is significantly more expensive than surgery. For intermediate- and high-risk cancers, both survival and cost generally favored surgery over other forms of treatment -- although combination external-beam radiation and brachytherapy together were comparable in terms of quality of life-adjusted survival for high-risk prostate cancer.
Link to full text (Ipsen subscription) onlinelibrary.wil…
Source: BJU International 28 December 2012

item.title: New OAB Drug May Overcome Some Of The Limitations Of Existing Products
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Theravida has announced positive results from a phII trial of its lead combination product (Tolenix) for iOAB. Tolerix is a twice daily combination of tolteridine, a muscarinic antagonist commonly used to treat iOAB and pilocarpine, a muscarinic agonist approved to treat dry mouth, a common side-effect experienced with many existing OAB drugs.
Study Design & Key Findings
Patient receiving Tolenix (2mg tolterodine plus 9mg pilocarpine) experienced significant improvement in their OAB and urge incontinence symptoms compared to placebo. Efficacy was similar in magnitude to Detrol (2mg tolterodine) administered alone. However, patients receiving Tolenix exhibited no significant safety issues and clinically meaningful improvements in their saliva and dry mouth side effeccts compared to active control Detrol.
Potential For Greater Efficacy Associated With Higher Doses
The phII study also demonstrated a favourable therapeutic index, which may enable higher dosing of Tolenix. A higher dose study in a 12-week open label extension period demonstrated the ability to provide greater bladder control with minimal dry mouth side-effects.
Tolenix is a new, patent-protected therapeutic combination that utilises a proprietary combination drug delivery technology.

item.title: Biogen-Idec Drug Fails In PhIII ALS Study
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Dexapramipexole, viewed as a potentially promising new approach for the debilitating neurological disorder ALS, failed to meet its primary endpoint in the PhIII EMPOWER study.
EMPOWER was a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled Phase 3 trial which enrolled 943 people with ALS at 81 sites in 11 countries. Patients were randomized on a one-to-one basis to receive either dexpramipexole or placebo.
The trial did not meet its primary endpoint, a joint rank analysis of function and survival, and no efficacy was seen in the individual components of function or survival. The trial also failed to show efficacy in its key secondary endpoints. Additional analyses of multiple subpopulations failed to demonstrate any efficacy among these groups. Based on these results, Biogen Idec will discontinue development of dexpramipexole in ALS.
Biogen in-licensed dexpramipexole from Knopp BioSciences in August 2010 in a deal at the time worth $345m. To date, we believe it has paid out $80, $60m in stock plus a $20m upfront payment. The drug was poised to enter phIII at this point.
Biogen-Idec's Ongoing Commitment To ALS
Biogen Idec has several programs underway in ALS. The company recently entered into a research collaboration with Duke University and HudsonAlpha Institute to sequence the genomes of up to 1,000 people with ALS over the next five years in an effort to gain a deeper understanding about the fundamental genetic causes of the disease. Duke and HudsonAlpha will work with several world-class researchers who have deep expertise and experience with ALS and the genes associated with the disease.
Biogen Idec recently created a research consortium in collaboration with several leading academic research centers to identify new approaches to treating ALS. Each of the centers involved in this consortium brings different scientific and technical expertise and a shared goal of improving the understanding of ALS from a basic science perspective.
In addition, Biogen Idec has committed significant funds to the University of Massachusetts Medical School ALS Champion Fund. The funding will drive awareness of ALS and support basic and clinical science research into potential treatments for ALS and other neurodegenerative diseases
Source: www.biogenidec.com

Dicerna Achieves POP With Previously Non Druggable Target

Kyowa Hakko Kirin Co., Ltd. has elected to advance the 2nd therapeutic oncology candidate from the research to development stage. The achievement of this milestone triggers a $5 million payment from KHK to Dicerna.
"The speed with which this second oncology program has moved from concept to development candidate is impressive. Highly active DsiRNAs combined with KHK's proprietary lipid nanoparticle delivery technology can be validated in vivo in less than a year.” said Etsuo Ohshima, Ph.D., managing officer and vice president, head, research division at KHK.
Along with Dicerna's own hepatocellular carcinoma program, the company now has 3 oncology candidates, all utilizing Dicerna's Dicer Substrate Technology™ (see Oncology8476: Dicerna Presents Positive HCC Preclinical Data At the ILCA Meeting).

item.title: re: Review - Novel Pathway for Somatostatin Analogs in Patients with Acromegaly
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Review - Novel Pathway for Somatostatin Analogs in Patients with Acromegaly 
Comment: In a considerable percentage of patients with acromegaly, disease activity cannot be fully controlled with somatostatin analogs. The mechanisms involved in SSA resistance are not completely understood.  ...
Very interesting insights into MOA of SSA resistance and why patients with germline mutations in AIP are usually poorly-responsive to SSA therapy. One of the authors (MK) very interested in exploring this further in ESS work that maybe worth following-up; potentially interesting research link too between Europe and Intercontinental medical personnel.
In the meantime, proposal to retroactively examine samples collected in the Ipsen-sponsored Primary Medical Treatment Study (-207) for patients' AIP gene status and T2 MRI imaging currently under consideration.
I wonder too if the emerging ZAC1 story in acromegaly suggests this disease could be an interesting target in the wider development programme for TASQ.


Comments
We are reviewing this area in research at the moment. I caution against any approaches to MK at the present time.

item.title: Pfizer to Advance Repligen's Spinal Muscular Atrophy (SMA) Program
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The program includes RG3039, a small molecule in clinical development for SMA as well as backup compounds, and enabling technologies.
Financial
Repligen is to receive >$70M from Pfizer, commencing with an upfront payment of $5M
Total potential future milestone payments >$65M
Drug Development
Repligen is responsible for completing the first two cohorts of a Ph1 study evaluating RG3039 in healthy volunteers in Q1:13.
Families of SMA, a patient organization dedicated to funding research to advance therapies for SMA, funded and directed the PC development of RG3039 with an investment of more than $13M. This was the first drug discovery program ever conducted specifically for SMA. Repligen’s research and clinical efforts, including the current Ph1b trial, have been partially supported by a $1.4M grant from the Muscular Dystrophy Association.
RG3039 received US Orphan Drug and Fast Track designations for SMA as well as Orphan Medicinal Poduct designation in the EU.
Source: Repligen

item.content:encoded:
Endo Discontinues Second Ph3 Trial with Urocidin for Non-muscle Invasive Bladder Cancer 
Comment: The trial, being run by Endo Pharm., has not been recruiting at the expected rate. Endo and Bioniche are jointly considering potential next steps for the program in order to build on the outome of the first Ph3 and to continue to work toward regulatory approval.  ...
Last week, Bioniche and Endo came to an agreement that a mutually favourable path forward for the product is to return global rights to Bioniche. In exchange for this agreement, Endo will receive a royalty on future revenue.
Bioniche now has the opportunity to seek alternate partnership arrangements, which would be expected to generate income to offset the costs of any additional clinical trial work required.

item.title: New Study Concludes Botox Induces Remission in Depression
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: This second of Dr Finzi's studies comes to the conclusion that Botox relieved symptoms in more than a quarter of patients, compared to just 7% of those receiving placebo.
Recruitment: 84 people with severe depression (> than an average of 2 years, and who had not fully responded to treatment with antidepressants).
Treatment: 29U of Botox to smooth frown lines or a placebo injection into the same facial region.
Assessment: at 3 weeks and at 6 weeks
In 2006 Dr Finzi and Dr Wasserman recruited 10 women (between 36 and 63) with a medical history of depression.
Patient description: Average period of depression was 3.5 years although 1 patient had been ill for 17 years and had not responded well to conventional treatments.
7/10 had been on anti-depressants, but continued to be dogged by severe depression before taking part in the trial.
Findings: 9/10 were no longer clinical depressed and the one who still was reported a significant improvement in symptoms.
Dr Finzi is Medical Director at the Chevy Chase Cosmetic Cneter, in Maryland (USA).

item.title: NPS Sets Price for Newly Approved Gattex
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: NPS has set the annual list price for its short bowel syndrome (SBS) drug Gattex teduglutide at $295,000 (well in excess of consensus). The company, which plans to launch the Orphan drug in February, said it has identified more than 1,000 patients who are eligible for Gattex and expects to have 200-300 patients on the drug by the end of 2013.
NPS's estimates of prevalence of 3000-5000 patients is lower than some previous estimates of 10-15,000 but its price is considerably higher. It expects payers to provide broad access to Gattex" and now estimates peak revenues will be "well in excess of" its previous estimate of $350 million. In late December, FDA approved the analog of glucagon-like peptide-2 (GLP-2) to treat adults with SBS who are dependent on parenteral support.
Sales Expectations
Analysts expect the launch take-off to be gradual as patients who are stably treated with home parenteral nutrition typically see a gastroenterologists annually, along with reimbursement approval typically taking 90-120 days and a requirement for a colonoscopy prior to the start of Gattex therapy,
Accordingly Wedbush securties has adjusted its revenue estimated to $15.2m, $97M, $212m and $312m in years 2013-2016 from $21.6m, $68m, $145m and $211m.. It has modeled the launch on a similar ultra-rare orphan drug launch such as Myozyme.
Tedglutide ia already approved in Europe and will be marketed in this region by Takeda that gained access to the drug through its acquisition of Nycomed.
Source: www.nps.com

Recruitment: approx. 400
Start date: Dec 2012 - Completion: June 2014

item.title: POC Trial of Zytiga (Abiraterone) in Japan for CRPC
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Clinicaltrials.gov is listing a Ph2 study evaluating safety and efficacy of abiraterone in Japanse patients with mCRPC, and who have not received prior chemotherapy. Primary endpoint will assess percentage of participants achieving PSA response up to 12wks.
Recruitment: approx. 45
Completion date: Sept 2014
Location: >20 sites (Jpn)
The study consists of 3 phases:
  • Screening phase (consists of 14 days before study commences on Day -1);
  • Treatment phase (consists of 28-daily dosing cycles wherein abiraterone 1000 milligram [mg] once daily along with 5 mg prednisolone twice daily will be given until disease progression or unacceptable toxicity is observed);
  • Follow-up phase (up to 5 years or until survival after the first dose of study drug).

item.title: Review - Novel Pathway for Somatostatin Analogs in Patients with Acromegaly
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: In a considerable percentage of patients with acromegaly, disease activity cannot be fully controlled with somatostatin analogs. The mechanisms involved in SSA resistance are not completely understood.
Patients with AIP germline mutations or patients with somatotropinomas with low AIP protein expression typically show a poor response to SSA therapy. SSAs increase AIP and ZAC1 mRNA and protein expression. These data suggest that AIP and ZAC1 play important roles in the SSTRs signaling cascade. Further deciphering these molecular pathways, including studies with novel SSAs such as pasireotide, which exhibit a different affinity profile for the SSTRs, will provide a better understanding of the mechanism of action of this class of drugs, and will have important therapeutic implications.
Link to full text: (Ipsen subscription) sciencedirect.com…
Source: Trends Endocrinol Metab. 2012 Dec 25

Comments
Very interesting insights into MOA of SSA resistance and why patients with germline mutations in AIP are usually poorly-responsive to SSA therapy. One of the authors (MK) very interested in exploring this further in ESS work that maybe worth following-up; potentially interesting research link too between Europe and Intercontinental medical personnel.
In the meantime, proposal to retroactively examine samples collected in the Ipsen-sponsored Primary Medical Treatment Study (-207) for patients' AIP gene status and T2 MRI imaging currently under consideration.
I wonder too if the emerging ZAC1 story in acromegaly suggests this disease could be an interesting target in the wider development programme for TASQ.

We are reviewing this area in research at the moment. I caution against any approaches to MK at the present time.

item.title: re: Proteologics Reports Progress in Research Collaboration with Teva
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Proteologics Reports Progress in Research Collaboration with Teva 
Comment: Proteologics and Teva partner in two independent, yet complementary projects, focusing on specific components of the ubiquitin system. Specific components of the ubiqutin pathway, such as E3's, are believed to offer novel targets for cancer, viral diseases, and CNS related pathologies  ...
Following Teva's decision to refocus R&D on branded specialty drugs for CNS and respiratory diseases as well ascomplex and combination generics called new therapeutic entities (NTEs), the company will return rights to 3 compounds in PC development for cancer and inflammation to Proteologics.
Last November, Teva sold its 31.5% stake in Proteologics.

item.title: re: Novel medicines approved in 2012
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Novel medicines approved in 2012 
Comment : in a recent report issued by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) “Fiscal Year 2012 Innovative Drug Approvals,” the agency highlighted 35 new drug approvals. This marks the second year in a row where FDA has issued 35 approvals and continues the trend of more annual approvals than in years past.  ...
I just put a focus in Oncology. FDA uses a range of tools to expedite the development, review, and approval of the most promising new therapies. These tools include Fast Track, Priority Review, and Accelerated Approval. For 2012, in oncology, 8 drugs (listed below) were approved as Fast Track drugs.
  1. Erivedge (vismodegib)for late-stage skin cancer Hedgehog inhibitor
  2. Xtandi (enzalutamide) for late-stage prostate cancer Androgen inhibitor
  3. Jakafi (ruxolitinib) for myelofibrosis Janus Associated Kinase (JAK) inhibitor
  4. Voraxaze (glucarpidase) to lower toxic levels of the chemotherapy drug methotrexate
  5. Erwinaze (asparaginase erwinia chrysthemi) for acute leukemia
  6. Stivarga (reborafenib) for late-stage colorectal cancer A multi-kinase inhibitor
  7. Perjeta (pertuzumab) for late-stage breast cancer Anti HER2 inhibitor
  8. Bosulif (bosutinib) for chronic leukemia
